studies.title: Epigenetic modification of the oxytocin receptor gene influences the perception of anger and fear in the human brain.
studies.abstract: In humans, the neuropeptide oxytocin plays a critical role in social and emotional behavior. The actions of this molecule are dependent on a protein that acts as its receptor, which is encoded by the oxytocin receptor gene (OXTR). DNA methylation of OXTR, an epigenetic modification, directly influences gene transcription and is variable in humans. However, the impact of this variability on specific social behaviors is unknown. We hypothesized that variability in OXTR methylation impacts social perceptual processes often linked with oxytocin, such as perception of facial emotions. Using an imaging epigenetic approach, we established a relationship between OXTR methylation and neural activity in response to emotional face processing. Specifically, high levels of OXTR methylation were associated with greater amounts of activity in regions associated with face and emotion processing including amygdala, fusiform, and insula. Importantly, we found that these higher levels of OXTR methylation were also associated with decreased functional coupling of amygdala with regions involved in affect appraisal and emotion regulation. These data indicate that the human endogenous oxytocin system is involved in attenuation of the fear response, corroborating research implicating intranasal oxytocin in the same processes. Our findings highlight the importance of including epigenetic mechanisms in the description of the endogenous oxytocin system and further support a central role for oxytocin in social cognition. This approach linking epigenetic variability with neural endophenotypes may broadly explain individual differences in phenotype including susceptibility or resilience to disease.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI neural activity during emotional face processing (a social perception task) with effects in amygdala, fusiform, and insula, meeting the review’s focus on social-related fMRI. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI during a social perception task (emotional face processing of anger and fear), involving healthy adult participants. The full text describes group-level neural activity in face- and emotion-processing regions (amygdala, fusiform, insula) and discusses task-evoked whole-brain effects; these constitute univariate, voxelwise, group-level results generalizable to healthy adults. Although functional coupling analyses are also reported, the paper clearly provides whole-brain task activation findings rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participant age range and healthy-group analyses are implicit in the methods and results focusing on nonclinical adult samples. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: How the human brain exchanges information across sensory modalities to recognize other people.
studies.abstract: Recognizing the identity of other individuals across different sensory modalities is critical for successful social interaction. In the human brain, face- and voice-sensitive areas are separate, but structurally connected. What kind of information is exchanged between these specialized areas during cross-modal recognition of other individuals is currently unclear. For faces, specific areas are sensitive to identity and to physical properties. It is an open question whether voices activate representations of face identity or physical facial properties in these areas. To address this question, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging in humans and a voice-face priming design. In this design, familiar voices were followed by morphed faces that matched or mismatched with respect to identity or physical properties. The results showed that responses in face-sensitive regions were modulated when face identity or physical properties did not match to the preceding voice. The strength of this mismatch signal depended on the level of certainty the participant had about the voice identity. This suggests that both identity and physical property information was provided by the voice to face areas. The activity and connectivity profiles differed between face-sensitive areas: (i) the occipital face area seemed to receive information about both physical properties and identity, (ii) the fusiform face area seemed to receive identity, and (iii) the anterior temporal lobe seemed to receive predominantly identity information from the voice. We interpret these results within a prediction coding scheme in which both identity and physical property information is used across sensory modalities to recognize individuals.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study uses fMRI in human participants on social-related task (cross-modal recognition of other people’s identity — perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy sample; given insufficient detail on age/health, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=16, ages 20–31) that investigates cross-modal person recognition (voice–face), a social perception task relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Group-level, voxelwise second-level analyses were performed and reported with MNI coordinates for task contrasts and connectivity; results are described for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although many results are reported with ROI-based correction, the manuscript describes whole-brain voxelwise analysis procedures and provides group-level univariate task contrasts and peak coordinates. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Perceived patient-parent relationships and neural representation of parents in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Having a relationship with one's parents is a fundamental social interaction and is a significant environmental factor in the long-term course of illness in schizophrenia. We explored subjective reports regarding the communicative relationship with parents and the implicit behavioral and neural responses of patients toward stimuli that referred to parents. Fourteen outpatients with schizophrenia and 15 healthy volunteers with living parents were scanned using a functional magnetic resonance imaging while performing an imaginary sentence completion test that involved contemplation of their mothers and fathers. In patients with schizophrenia, subjective reports of better communicative fluency with one's mother were associated with faster response time and lower incomplete rate, reflecting favorable responses toward mothers. Relative to control participants, patients with schizophrenia demonstrated greater neural activation in the superior temporal sulcus and the parahippocampal gyrus for parental stimuli. When patients with schizophrenia contemplated their mothers, activities in these regions were associated with a level of negative symptoms or affective ambivalence in patients. The results indicated that parental cues are processed in a more socially driven manner, and that perceived communicative relationships with one's parents can be used to estimate implicit responses, especially in relation to mothers in patients with schizophrenia. Furthermore, the findings of the current study suggest that affective ambivalence toward one's mother is one such implicit response and emphasize the importance of prudent family interventions in the psychiatric rehabilitation of patients with schizophrenia.
studies.journal: European archives of psychiatry and clinical neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was conducted during a social-related task (contemplation/imaginary sentence completion about mothers and fathers). The study includes a healthy control group of volunteers (ages not specified but likely adults) alongside patients with schizophrenia, and it is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This paper reports an fMRI task probing social/attachment processing (imagery sentence completion about ‘My mother’/‘My father’). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15) alongside patients, with participants described as adults. The authors report within-group, voxelwise whole-brain task activations for the healthy/control group (one-sample t-tests; significant clusters and MNI coordinates presented in Table 2, precuneus etc.), satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. The study is empirical fMRI work of social processing in healthy adults, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Social gating of sensory information during ongoing communication.
studies.abstract: Social context plays an important role in human communication. Depending on the nature of the source, the same communication signal might be processed in fundamentally different ways. However, the selective modulation (or "gating") of the flow of neural information during communication is not fully understood. Here, we use multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) and multivoxel connectivity analysis (MVCA), a novel technique that allows to analyse context-dependent changes of the strength interregional coupling between ensembles of voxels, to examine how the human brain differentially gates content-specific sensory information during ongoing perception of communication signals. In a simulated electronic communication experiment, participants received two alternative text messages during fMRI ("happy" or "sad") which they believed had been sent either by their real-life friend outside the scanner or by a computer. A region in the dorsal medial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) selectively increased its functional coupling with sensory-content encoding regions in the visual cortex when a text message was perceived as being sent by the participant's friend, and decreased its functional coupling with these regions when a text message was perceived as being sent by the computer. Furthermore, the strength of neural encoding of content-specific information of text messages in the dmPFC was modulated by the social tie between the participant and her friend: the more of her spare time a participant reported to spend with her friend the stronger was the neural encoding. This suggests that the human brain selectively gates sensory information into the relevant network for processing the mental states of others, depending on the source of the communication signal.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while healthy participants performed a social communication task (perceiving messages believed to be from a friend vs a computer). The study examines social processing (social communication, perception of others) and is an original research article, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, females, age 19–28) investigating social communication (perceived friend vs computer). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., friend > computer) with thresholded statistical parametric maps and a table of significant whole-brain clusters (dmPFC, precuneus, TPJ, temporal poles). Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches; whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly described and generalized to the healthy sample. The task probes social-related processing (mentalizing/communication) and meets the age and sample criteria. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Regional brain responses in nulliparous women to emotional infant stimuli.
studies.abstract: Infant cries and facial expressions influence social interactions and elicit caretaking behaviors from adults. Recent neuroimaging studies suggest that neural responses to infant stimuli involve brain regions that process rewards. However, these studies have yet to investigate individual differences in tendencies to engage or withdraw from motivationally relevant stimuli. To investigate this, we used event-related fMRI to scan 17 nulliparous women. Participants were presented with novel infant cries of two distress levels (low and high) and unknown infant faces of varying affect (happy, sad, and neutral) in a randomized, counter-balanced order. Brain activation was subsequently correlated with scores on the Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System scale. Infant cries activated bilateral superior and middle temporal gyri (STG and MTG) and precentral and postcentral gyri. Activation was greater in bilateral temporal cortices for low- relative to high-distress cries. Happy relative to neutral faces activated the ventral striatum, caudate, ventromedial prefrontal, and orbitofrontal cortices. Sad versus neutral faces activated the precuneus, cuneus, and posterior cingulate cortex, and behavioral activation drive correlated with occipital cortical activations in this contrast. Behavioral inhibition correlated with activation in the right STG for high- and low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Behavioral drive correlated inversely with putamen, caudate, and thalamic activations for the comparison of high-distress cries to pink noise. Reward-responsiveness correlated with activation in the left precentral gyrus during the perception of low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Our findings indicate that infant cry stimuli elicit activations in areas implicated in auditory processing and social cognition. Happy infant faces may be encoded as rewarding, whereas sad faces activate regions associated with empathic processing. Differences in motivational tendencies may modulate neural responses to infant cues.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI measured responses to infant cries/faces (social stimuli involving affiliation/attachment and perception of others) in 17 healthy nulliparous adult women. Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult group) and is not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (nulliparous women, ages 19–29) performing social-related tasks (perception of infant emotional cries and faces; relevant to social communication/perception of others/affiliation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., high- vs low-distress cries; happy vs neutral faces) with voxelwise results, cluster correction, coordinates, and images generalizable to the healthy adult sample. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

studies.title: Do implicit and explicit belief processing share neural substrates?
studies.abstract: Humans rely on their ability to infer another person's mental state to understand and predict others' behavior ("theory of mind," ToM). Multiple lines of research suggest that not only are humans able to consciously process another person's belief state, but also are able to do so implicitly. Here we explored how general implicit belief states are represented in the brain, compared to those substrates involved in explicit ToM processes. Previous work on this topic has yielded conflicting results, and thus, the extent to which the implicit and explicit ToM systems draw on common neural bases is unclear. Participants were presented with "Sally-Anne" type movies in which a protagonist was falsely led to believe a ball was in one location, only for a puppet to later move it to another location in their absence (false-belief condition). In other movies, the protagonist had their back turned the entire time the puppet moved the ball between the two locations, meaning that they had no opportunity to develop any pre-existing beliefs about the scenario (no-belief condition). Using a group of independently localized explicit ToM brain regions, we found greater activity for false-belief trials, relative to no-belief trials, in the right temporoparietal junction, right superior temporal sulcus, precuneus, and left middle prefrontal gyrus. These findings extend upon previous work on the neural bases of implicit ToM by showing substantial overlap between this system and the explicit ToM system, suggesting that both abilities might recruit a common set of mentalizing processes/functional brain regions. Hum Brain Mapp 38:4760-4772, 2017. © 2017 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition/perception and understanding of others) in human participants; reports task-based activation in canonical ToM regions. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original research article (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind/implicit belief processing) in healthy adults (final N=22; mean age 24.4 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects GLM results from an explicit general-belief localizer contrast (false-belief vs false-photograph) at q(FDR)<0.05 with peak Talairach coordinates and a whole-brain statistical map (Fig.2A and text). Although some analyses used ROIs, the study includes clearly reported whole-brain, task-evoked healthy-group results that are generalizable to healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria.

studies.title: fMRI evidence of neural abnormalities in the subcortical face processing system in ASD.
studies.abstract: Recent evidence suggests that a rapid, automatic face detection system is supported by subcortical structures including the amygdala, pulvinar, and superior colliculus. Early-emerging abnormalities in these structures may be related to reduced social orienting in children with autism, and subsequently, to aberrant development of cortical circuits involved in face processing. Our objective was to determine whether functional abnormalities in the subcortical face processing system are present in adults with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) during supraliminal fearful face processing. Participants included twenty-eight individuals with ASD and 25 controls group-matched on age, IQ, and behavioral performance. The ASD group met diagnostic criteria on the ADI-R, ADOS-G, and DSM-IV. Both the ASD and control groups showed significant activation in bilateral fusiform gyri. The control group exhibited additional significant responses in the right amygdala, right pulvinar, and bilateral superior colliculi. In the direct group comparison, the controls showed significantly greater activation in the left amygdala, bilateral fusiform gyrus, right pulvinar, and bilateral superior colliculi. No brain region showed significantly greater activation in the ASD group compared to the controls. Thus, basic rapid face identification mechanisms appear to be functional in ASD. However, individuals with ASD failed to engage the subcortical brain regions involved in face detection and automatic emotional face processing, suggesting a core mechanism for impaired socioemotional processing in ASD. Neural abnormalities in this system may contribute to early-emerging deficits in social orienting and attention, the putative precursors to abnormalities in social cognition and cortical face processing specialization.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=25). Task is social-related; participants are adults. No exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, mean age ~23), uses task-based fMRI during social-related processing (rapid fearful face perception), and reports group-level univariate activation results for the control group. Within-group control activations are provided (e.g., bilateral fusiform, right amygdala, pulvinar, superior colliculi) in Table 2 and Supplementary materials, and whole-brain analyses are described in the supplement. Although ROIs were used, whole-brain mixed-effects analyses (FLAME) and coordinate clusters for the healthy/control group are reported, satisfying the requirement for an univariate whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults.

studies.title: Limbic Interference During Social Action Planning in Schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Schizophrenia is characterized by social interaction deficits contributing to poor functional outcome. Hand gesture use is particularly impaired, linked to frontal lobe dysfunction and frontal grey matter deficits. The functional neural correlates of impaired gesturing are currently unclear. We therefore investigated aberrant brain activity during impaired gesturing in schizophrenia. We included 22 patients with schizophrenia and 25 healthy control participants matched for age, gender, and education level. We obtained functional magnetic resonance imaging data using an event-related paradigm to assess brain activation during gesture planning and execution. Group differences in whole brain effects were calculated using factorial designs. Gesture ratings were performed by a single rater, blind to diagnoses and clinical presentation. During gesture planning and execution both groups activated brain areas of the praxis network. However, patients had reduced dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and increased inferior parietal lobe (IPL) activity. Performance accuracy was associated with IPL activity in patients. Furthermore, patients activated temporal poles, amygdala and hippocampus during gesture planning, which was associated with delusion severity. Finally, patients demonstrated increased dorsomedial prefrontal cortex activity during planning of novel gestures. We demonstrate less prefrontal, but more IPL and limbic activity during gesturing in schizophrenia. IPL activity was associated with performance accuracy, whereas limbic activity was linked to delusion severity. These findings may reflect impaired social action planning and a limbic interference with gestures in schizophrenia contributing to poor gesture performance and consequently poor social functioning in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating gesture planning/execution (social communication) with both schizophrenia patients and a healthy control group matched for age and demographics. Task assesses social action/communication relevant to review. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of gesture planning/execution—a social communication task (pantomime gestures) relevant to Social Communication. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group effects and contrasts for controls) with explicit thresholds (P≤.001) and cluster criteria; within-group/control maps/results are described in the main text and supplementary materials. The study is empirical and not ROI-, connectivity-only, or resting-state-only. Although a patient group is included, healthy-control whole-brain task activation is clearly provided and generalizable to healthy adults. Participant ages are not explicitly listed but recruitment sources (staff, students, matched adults) indicate an adult sample within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

studies.title: Distinct regions of the medial prefrontal cortex are associated with self-referential processing and perspective taking.
studies.abstract: The medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC) appears to play a prominent role in two fundamental aspects of social cognition, that is, self-referential processing and perspective taking. However, it is currently unclear whether the same or different regions of the MPFC mediate these two interdependent processes. This functional magnetic resonance imaging study sought to clarify the issue by manipulating both dimensions in a factorial design. Participants judged the extent to which trait adjectives described their own personality (e.g., "Are you sociable?") or the personality of a close friend (e.g., "Is Caroline sociable?") and were also asked to put themselves in the place of their friend (i.e., to take a third-person perspective) and estimate how this person would judge the adjectives, with the target of the judgments again being either the self (e.g., "According to Caroline, are you sociable?") or the other person (e.g., "According to Caroline, is she sociable?"). We found that self-referential processing (i.e., judgments targeting the self vs. the other person) yielded activation in the ventral and dorsal anterior MPFC, whereas perspective taking (i.e., adopting the other person's perspective, rather than one's own, when making judgments) resulted in activation in the posterior dorsal MPFC; the interaction between the two dimensions yielded activation in the left dorsal MPFC. These findings show that self-referential processing and perspective taking recruit distinct regions of the MPFC and suggest that the left dorsal MPFC may be involved in decoupling one's own from other people's perspectives on the self.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants investigating social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking). Fits review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking). The task is explicitly social-related, and the paper reports group-level task-evoked whole-brain univariate activations (activation in ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, and left dorsal MPFC for the interaction), which indicates whole-brain voxelwise contrasts rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are healthy adults (university sample), and results are presented as generalizable group-level effects. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy or out-of-range sample, or non-empirical paper) appear to be violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Reduced activation of the ventromedial prefrontal cortex during self-referential processing in individuals at ultra-high risk for psychosis.
studies.abstract: Defects in self-referential processing and perspective-taking are core characteristics that may underlie psychotic symptoms and impaired social cognition in schizophrenia. Here, we investigated the neural correlates of self-referential processing regardless of the perspective taken and third-person perspective-taking regardless of the target person to judge relevance in individuals at ultra-high risk for psychosis. We also explored relationships between alterations in neural activity and neurocognitive function and basic self ('
studies.journal: The Australian and New Zealand journal of psychiatry
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI study of self-referential (social-related) processing, matching the review topic. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study includes a healthy control group of adults (n=28, mean age 21.6) and reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group (e.g., self>other and 3PP>1PP activation maps and tables of clusters). The task probes social-related constructs (self-referential processing and perspective-taking), which fit the review’s scope (Perception and Understanding of Self). Whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented in tables and text. Although recruitment targeted ages 15–35, group means indicate adult participants within the 17–65 range and the study is not limited to underage-only samples. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain task activation maps reported.

studies.title: The impact of aging on the neural networks involved in gaze and emotional processing.
studies.abstract: Normal adult aging is associated with difficulties in processing social cues to emotions such as anger and also altered motivation to focus more on positive than negative information. Gaze direction is an important modifier of the social signals conveyed by an emotion, for example, an angry face looking directly at you is considerably more threatening than an angry face looking away. In the present study we tested the hypothesis that older adults would show less neural differentiation to angry faces with direct and avert gaze compared to younger people, with the opposite prediction for happy faces. Healthy older (65-75 years; mean = 69.75) and younger (17-27 years; mean = 20.65) adults completed a functional magnetic resonance imaging experiment in which they were asked to identify happy and angry expressions displayed either with direct or averted gaze. While younger adults showed neural sensitivity to eye-gaze direction during recognition of angry expressions, older adults showed no effect of eye-gaze direction on neural response. In contrast, older adults showed sensitivity to eye-gaze direction during recognition of happy expressions but younger adults did not. Additionally, brain-behavior correlations were conducted to investigate the relationships between emotion recognition and mentalizing brain network in both age groups. Younger (but not older) adults' social cognitive performance was differentially correlated with activation in 2 brain networks when looking at angry faces with direct compared to averted gaze. These novel findings provide evidence for age-related differences in the neural substrates underlying the capacity to integrate facial affect and eye-gaze cues. The results of this study suggest that age-related differences in integrating facial cues may be related to engagement of the mentalizing network, with potentially important implications for social cognitive functioning in late adulthood.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social processing (integration of facial emotion and eye-gaze) in healthy adults. Includes a healthy younger participant group aged 17–27 (within required 17–65 range), satisfying inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition with direct/averted gaze), reporting group-level whole-brain results. It includes a healthy younger adult group (17–27 years) within the 17–65 range and presents whole-brain voxelwise findings (PLS-derived maps with peak coordinates and cluster tables) clearly attributed to the healthy participants. Results for younger controls are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity-only, and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/coordinates. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Differential activation of the amygdala and the 'social brain' during fearful face-processing in Asperger Syndrome.
studies.abstract: Impaired social cognition is a core feature of autism. There is much evidence showing people with autism use a different cognitive style than controls for face-processing. We tested if people with autism would show differential activation of social brain areas during a face-processing task. Thirteen adults with high-functioning autism or Asperger Syndrome (HFA/AS) and 13 matched controls. We used fMRI to investigate 'social brain' activity during perception of fearful faces. We employed stimuli known to reliably activate the amygdala and other social brain areas, and ROI analyses to investigate brain areas responding to facial threat as well as those showing a linear response to varying threat intensities. We predicted: (1) the HFA/AS group would show differential activation (as opposed to merely deficits) of the social brain compared to controls and (2) that social brain areas would respond to varied intensity of fear in the control group, but not the HFA/AS group. Both predictions were confirmed. The controls showed greater activation in the left amygdala and left orbito-frontal cortex, while the HFA/AS group showed greater activation in the anterior cingulate gyrus and superior temporal cortex. The control group also showed varying responses in social brain areas to varying intensities of fearful expression, including differential activations in the left and right amygdala. This response in the social brain was absent in the HFA/AS group. HFA/AS are associated with different patterns of activation of social brain areas during fearful emotion processing, and the absence in the HFA/AS brain of a response to varying emotional intensity.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) including a matched healthy adult control group (ages consistent with adults). Task probes social brain areas; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (perception of fearful faces) including a healthy adult control group (N=13; mean age 25.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., main effect of faces vs scrambled baseline and linear contrasts of fear intensity) with coordinates and figures, using a random-effects GLM and whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001 uncorrected) and reporting activations (with small-volume corrections for a priori ROIs). Results for the healthy/control group are presented separately from the clinical (HFA/AS) group. Although ROI/SVC procedures were applied to hypothesized social-brain regions, the study provides univariate, whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates for the healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Increased neural response related to neutral faces in individuals at risk for psychosis.
studies.abstract: The reliable discrimination of emotional expressions in faces is essential for adequate social interaction. Deficits in facial emotion processing are an important impairment in schizophrenia with major consequences for social functioning and subjective well-being. Whether neural circuits underlying emotion processing are already altered before illness onset is yet unclear. Investigating neural correlates of emotion processing in individuals clinically at risk for psychosis offers the possibility to examine neural processes unchanged by the manifest disorder and to study trait aspects of emotion dysfunctions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract describes an fMRI study of facial emotion processing (a social-related task). It studies individuals at clinical risk for psychosis, but the abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study uses a social-related task (facial emotion discrimination/perception of others) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, ages ~24.5). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (within-group contrasts such as sad>neutral shown separately for controls and described in the text and figures) using SPM2 with voxelwise inference and cluster reporting. Healthy-group results are presented (figures and text) and thus satisfy the requirement for an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map. Although the clinical high-risk group is also included, the healthy control group’s whole-brain task effects are reported separately. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Shifted inferior frontal laterality in women with major depressive disorder is related to emotion-processing deficits.
studies.abstract: Facial emotion perception (FEP) is a critical human skill for successful social interaction, and a substantial body of literature suggests that explicit FEP is disrupted in major depressive disorder (MDD). Prior research suggests that weakness in FEP may be an important phenomenon underlying patterns of emotion-processing challenges in MDD and the disproportionate frequency of MDD in women. Method Women with (n = 24) and without (n = 22) MDD, equivalent in age and education, completed a FEP task during functional magnetic resonance imaging.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of facial emotion perception (a social processing task) with both women with MDD and a healthy control group. Healthy adult participants included; meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: Task is an explicit facial emotion perception fMRI paradigm (social communication/perception of others). Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Oxytocin Facilitates Approach Behavior to Positive Social Stimuli via Decreasing Anterior Insula Activity.
studies.abstract: The neuropeptide oxytocin can extensively modulate human social behavior and affective processing, and its effects can be interpreted in terms of mediating approach-avoidance motivational processes. However, little is known about how oxytocin mediates approach-avoidance behavior and particularly the underlying neural mechanisms.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract does not specify methods or participant details, but title/aim indicate neural mechanisms of oxytocin on social stimuli—likely an fMRI study of social processing. Given insufficient methodological detail in the abstract to confirm fMRI and sample, include for full-text review to verify that a functional MRI task was used with healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using a social-related approach-avoidance task with social and nonsocial stimuli in a healthy adult sample (male, mean age 21.35, within 17–65). Group-level task-based neuroimaging analyses were performed (first- and second-level contrasts), and the paper reports task-evoked activation results including whole-brain analyses (supplementary/ exploratory whole-brain results are reported beyond ROI/SVC findings). The study is empirical, not clinical-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes healthy-group results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (task fMRI of social processing; healthy adult sample; group-level whole-brain task results reported).

studies.title: Concrete versus abstract forms of social concept: an fMRI comparison of knowledge about people versus social terms.
studies.abstract: The anterior temporal lobes (ATLs) play a key role in conceptual knowledge representation. The hub-and-spoke theory suggests that the contribution of the ATLs to semantic representation is (a) transmodal, i.e. integrating information from multiple sensorimotor and verbal modalities, and (b) pan-categorical, representing concepts from all categories. Another literature, however, suggests that this region's responses are modality- and category-selective; prominent examples include category selectivity for socially relevant concepts and face recognition. The predictions of each approach have never been directly compared. We used data from three studies to compare category-selective responses within the ATLs. Study 1 compared ATL responses to famous people versus another conceptual category (landmarks) from visual versus auditory inputs. Study 2 compared ATL responses to famous people from pictorial and written word inputs. Study 3 compared ATL responses to a different kind of socially relevant stimuli, namely abstract non-person-related words, in order to ascertain whether ATL subregions are engaged for social concepts more generally or only for person-related knowledge. Across all three studies a dominant bilateral ventral ATL cluster responded to
studies.journal: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Primary data fMRI study examining neural responses to famous people and abstract social words (social concepts), across modalities. Tasks assess social-related processing (knowledge about others/social concepts). Likely conducted in healthy adult participants and not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This paper reports original fMRI data in healthy adult participants (three studies, combined N=59; all participants unique and within adult age range). Each study implemented social-related tasks (person knowledge, famous names, socially relevant words) and appropriate non-social controls. The authors conducted voxelwise, group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8) reporting contrasts of interest (social > non-social semantics) with cluster- and voxel-level thresholds and provide peak coordinates and whole-brain results in text/tables/figures. Analyses are clearly identified as coming from the healthy control groups. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task activations, healthy adult sample). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Effects of a genome-wide supported psychosis risk variant on neural activation during a theory-of-mind task.
studies.abstract: Schizophrenia is associated with marked deficits in theory of mind (ToM), a higher-order form of social cognition representing the thoughts, emotions and intentions of others. Altered brain activation in the medial prefrontal cortex and temporo-parietal cortex during ToM tasks has been found in patients with schizophrenia, but the relevance of these neuroimaging findings for the heritable risk for schizophrenia is unclear. We tested the hypothesis that activation of the ToM network is altered in healthy risk allele carriers of the single-nucleotide polymorphism rs1344706 in the gene ZNF804A, a recently discovered risk variant for psychosis with genome-wide support. In all, 109 healthy volunteers of both sexes in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium for rs1344706 were investigated with functional magnetic resonance imaging during a ToM task. As hypothesised, risk carriers exhibited a significant (P<0.05 false discovery rate, corrected for multiple comparisons) risk allele dose effect on neural activity in the medial prefrontal cortex and left temporo-parietal cortex. Moreover, the same effect was found in the left inferior parietal cortex and left inferior frontal cortex, which are part of the human analogue of the mirror neuron system. In addition, in an exploratory analysis (P<0.001 uncorrected), we found evidence for aberrant functional connectivity between the frontal and temporo-parietal regions in risk allele carriers. To conclude, we show that a dysfunction of the ToM network is associated with a genome-wide supported genetic risk variant for schizophrenia and has promise as an intermediate phenotype that can be mined for the development of biological interventions targeted to social dysfunction in psychiatry.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in 109 healthy adult volunteers. Meets inclusion: social-related task, healthy adults within 17–65. Not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (a social-cognition task) in healthy adult volunteers (n=109). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrast (ToM>control) with significant main effects (P<0.01 FWE) and provides coordinates/figures/tables of activation; genotype effects are also reported at whole-brain corrected levels. The sample is healthy adults and results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Seeing it my way or your way: frontoparietal brain areas sustain viewpoint-independent perspective selection processes.
studies.abstract: A hallmark of human social interaction is the ability to consider other people's mental states, such as what they see, believe, or desire. Prior neuroimaging research has predominantly investigated the neural mechanisms involved in computing one's own or another person's perspective and largely ignored the question of perspective selection. That is, which brain regions are engaged in the process of selecting between self and other perspectives? To address this question, the current fMRI study used a behavioral paradigm that required participants to select between competing visual perspectives. We provide two main extensions to current knowledge. First, we demonstrate that brain regions within dorsolateral prefrontal and parietal cortices respond in a viewpoint-independent manner during the selection of task-relevant over task-irrelevant perspectives. More specifically, following the computation of two competing visual perspectives, common regions of frontoparietal cortex are engaged to select one's own viewpoint over another's as well as select another's viewpoint over one's own. Second, in the absence of conflict between the content of competing perspectives, we showed a reduced engagement of frontoparietal cortex when judging another's visual perspective relative to one's own. This latter finding provides the first brain-based evidence for the hypothesis that, in some situations, another person's perspective is automatically and effortlessly computed, and thus, less cognitive control is required to select it over one's own perspective. In doing so, we provide stronger evidence for the claim that we not only automatically compute what other people see but also, in some cases, we compute this even before we are explicitly aware of our own perspective.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Primary data fMRI study of social cognition (visual perspective-taking/understanding others) in humans; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults (typical cognitive neuroscience sample). Meets inclusion criteria—include for full-text review to confirm exact ages and participant health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of visual perspective taking/theory-of-mind in healthy adults (n=16, mean age ~22.4). The task is social (self vs other visual perspective judgments). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts with voxelwise results and tables of coordinates (cluster-level FWE correction reported), including multiple contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other) generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes a healthy adult sample within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Differential role of the Mentalizing and the Mirror Neuron system in the imitation of communicative gestures.
studies.abstract: Successful social interaction requires recognising the intention of another person's communicative gestures. At a neural level, this process may involve neural activity in different systems, such as the mentalizing system (MS) and the mirror neuron system (MNS). The aim of the present study was to explore the neural correlates of communicative gestures during observation and execution of these gestures. Twenty participants watched video clips of an actor executing social gestures (S), non-social gestures (NS) and meaningless gestures (ML). During fMRI data acquisition, participants were asked to observe (O) and subsequently to execute (E) one of two tasks: imitate the gesture presented (IMI) or perform a motor control task (CT). For the contrast IMI>CT we found activations in the core areas of the MNS [inferior parietal lobule (IPL) and inferior frontal cortex, the posterior part of pars opercularis], as well as in areas related to the MS [superior temporal sulcus (STS) and middle cingulate cortex]. For S>NS, we found activations in the left medial orbitofrontal cortex (mOFC), right superior frontal cortex and middle cingulate cortex. The interaction of stimulus condition (S vs NS) and task (IMI vs CT) revealed activation in the right IPL. For the interaction between observation vs execution (O vs E), task (IMI vs CT) and stimulus condition (S vs NS) we found activation in the right mOFC. Our data suggest that imitation is differentially processed in the MNS as well as in the MS. The activation in IPL is enhanced during the processing of social gestures most likely due to their communicative intention. The activation of IPL together with medial frontal areas may contribute to mentalizing processes. The interaction in the mOFC suggests an involvement of self-referential processes in the processing of social gesture.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in 20 adult participants performing observation and imitation of communicative (social) vs non-social gestures, directly addressing social communication processing. No clinical population indicated; meets inclusion criteria for healthy adults performing a social-related task.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (27 recruited, 20 analyzed; mean age 24.6), investigating social-communication processes (observation and imitation of social vs non-social gestures). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., IMI > CT; S > NS), cluster-corrected results and tables/coordinates in MNI space, clearly from the healthy/control sample. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods. The healthy adult results are reported and generalizable (whole-brain contrasts and coordinates). Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

abstract_screening_results.reason: fMRI study of social-related processing (peer influence via ‘likes’) in healthy participants. Age described as ‘adolescents’ without specific ages; inclusion criterion requires participants aged 17–65. Age eligibility is unclear from the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This article is a critical appraisal/review of naturalistic stimuli in neuroscience, not an original fMRI study reporting data on social-related processing in healthy adults. The abstract describes a review, with no primary fMRI methods or participant data; thus it meets exclusion (review) criteria.

This abstract is a narrative review of naturalistic fMRI approaches rather than an original empirical fMRI study. It does not report participant groups, methods, or data from healthy adult participants, and fits the exclusion criterion of being a review/meta-analytic article.

This publication is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with human participants. Per the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), it should be excluded from the review.

This is a review/chapter summarizing oxytocin research in schizophrenia spectrum (systematic overview), not an original fMRI study reporting data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. Meets exclusion criterion for reviews; insufficient primary fMRI data for inclusion.

This article is a review and meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract indicates it synthesizes existing literature and does not report primary functional MRI data from healthy participants performing social tasks, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract describes a conceptual/book chapter review synthesizing behavioral and neuroimaging literature rather than reporting original task-based fMRI data in human participants. No methods, participant ages, or primary fMRI results are provided. As a review (exclusion criterion), exclude.

This is a review article summarizing fMRI findings in autism spectrum disorders, not an original fMRI study of healthy adult participants performing social tasks. It does not report primary data on healthy adults (age 17–65) and thus does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract explicitly states this is a review article integrating human fMRI and animal studies. It is not an original fMRI study of healthy adults. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), exclude.

This article is a review/perspective on resting-state fMRI and social cognition, not an original fMRI study in which participants performed a social-related task. Resting-state data are context-independent (no social task), and the abstract indicates synthesis of existing evidence rather than reporting task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

The article is a narrative review/overview of social neuroscience in psychiatry rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract indicates it synthesizes findings and discusses implications, with no primary data of human participants performing fMRI social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.
This study is a coordinate-based meta-analysis (Activation Likelihood Estimation). Exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses are excluded, so it should be excluded.

This is a review article reappraising social cognition in multiple sclerosis, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. The abstract describes a review of neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies in MS; no task-based fMRI data in healthy participants are reported. Exclude per exclusion criterion for reviews.

This is a narrative review of fMRI reliability, not an original fMRI study. It does not report an fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study administering an ecologically valid social-cognition task (inferring mental states from film extracts) with healthy control participants (28 and 14 HCs reported). Primary research on social processing in adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract is a narrative review of neuroimaging in autism focusing on findings in autistic patients, not an original fMRI study of social tasks in healthy adults. It does not report task-based fMRI data from healthy participants and appears to be a review article; therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a systematic review (explicitly stated), which meets the exclusion criterion. It summarizes neuroimaging studies in patients with schizophrenia rather than reporting primary fMRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks, so it does not address the review objective.

Abstract reports fMRI during standardized probes of social reward and threat processing and a facial affect recognition task (social-related tasks). It includes a matched control group of non-cocaine users aged 50–60 (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI collected while participants performed social-related tasks. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social processing task, so it does not meet the criterion.
Participants were children aged 8–12. The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65, so the study population does not meet inclusion age criteria.
Abstract explicitly states this is a review article ('In this review') rather than original fMRI research; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of social perception and cognition in human participants (measuring STS responses to social and linguistic stimuli). This meets the review objective and inclusion criteria (functional MRI, social-related tasks, human participants); it is not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social (vs non-social) anticipation and feedback; addresses social processing. It focuses on borderline patients but does not state whether healthy control group is present; inclusion is uncertain from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of a healthy adult comparison group (17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.
This fMRI study was conducted in macaque monkeys (non-human primates). The review requires fMRI studies in healthy human adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This article is a meta-analysis/review (not an original fMRI study). Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses — even though it addresses social cognition among other domains, it does not report primary fMRI data in healthy adults.

This is a review/discussion of resting-state fMRI findings in ASD (and neurofeedback), not an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion (review) and does not report a social task with healthy 17–65 participants.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in human subjects during a dyadic social interaction task (social processing). It addresses the review objective. Health status/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract addresses neurobiological correlates of social-cognitive (empathy/emotion) alterations but does not state whether fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine inclusion—include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an original fMRI experiment investigating social influence on decision-making using a social task (group foraging). It involves neural (fMRI) data in human participants and is not a review. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

Abstract is a methods/review commentary on hyperscanning techniques (EEG, fMRI, fNIRS) and future directions; it does not report original fMRI data or a social task performed by healthy adult participants. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria for primary fMRI studies.

This publication is a meta-analysis of neural correlates in ASD and schizophrenia rather than an original fMRI study of human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic review/meta-analysis) and therefore is excluded from inclusion.

Abstract describes a research program and fMRI studies of social perception in typically developing adults but does not report specific methods, participant ages, or primary data. It is unclear from the abstract whether this paper presents original fMRI results meeting inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports examination of neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in healthy young adults but does not specify that fMRI was used or describe a social-task. Insufficient detail to confirm modality/task from abstract alone — include for full-text review to verify fMRI and task details.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion/support paradigm in healthy undergraduates (n=46), examining neural responses to social interaction and emotional support (ACC, DLPFC). Participants are healthy adults and the task probes social processing. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a socio-emotional face-processing task with a healthy control group, meeting the social-processing and healthy-participant criteria; however the abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 requirement). Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

fMRI study using a valence classification task targeting agency and communion—core social-cognition constructs. Meets review objective of social-related processing during fMRI. Abstract does not report participant age/health status, so inclusion is prudent for full-text screening to confirm healthy adult sample and ages 17–65.

This is a narrative review of semantic dementia (neuroimaging, genetics, pathology), not a primary task-based fMRI study in healthy adults. The abstract does not describe an fMRI experiment with healthy participants performing a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Abstract explicitly states this is a review article; no primary fMRI experiment or participant sample described. Excluded per criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The article is a selective review (review paper), not an original fMRI study reporting primary data. Exclusion criterion disallows reviews/meta-analyses; abstract provides no new task-based fMRI data in healthy adults.

The study reports three meta-analyses of fMRI studies (explicitly a meta-analysis) rather than presenting original fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews or meta-analyses are excluded.

fMRI study probing processing of social versus nonsocial gestures, directly addressing social-related processing. Abstract implies typical healthy adult participants but does not report ages or explicit health status; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health.

This is a narrative review/proposal about deep brain stimulation for severe autism and discusses pathophysiology and a single case. It does not report an fMRI study with participants performing a social-related task in healthy adults. Not eligible for the fMRI social-processing meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social cognition during live reciprocal imitation (social interaction). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly say ‘healthy adults’, so demographics are uncertain — but the task and imaging modality match inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm participant health status and ages.

Functional MRI study of self–other processing (social cognition) using a task involving judgments about self vs. other; includes a matched typically developing (healthy) control group of young adults (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies the fMRI + social task + healthy participant group inclusion criteria.

This paper is a meta-analysis of over 200 fMRI studies (systematic review), not an original fMRI study with primary data. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

This publication is a review article summarizing fMRI and behavioural studies in adolescence rather than a primary fMRI study. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Also population focuses on adolescents rather than reporting a healthy adult (17–65) group in original data.

fMRI study examining social-interactive processing (mentalizing) during speech perception; involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and directly assesses social cognition. Not a review/meta-analysis. Includes social-related task and neural measures, meeting inclusion criteria; full text can confirm ages if needed.
Study uses resting-state fMRI (no task) in ASD vs controls; does not involve a social-related task in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the task-based inclusion criterion.

Abstract describes fMRI investigation of mentalizing in first-episode schizophrenia but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because presence of healthy participants is unclear, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study is a voxel-based multimodal meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies. The review’s exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded based on the abstract.

fMRI study measuring neural responses during observation of dynamic facial expressions (a social communication/perception task) in a sample of adults (n=51). Meets inclusion of fMRI social-related task in human participants; not a review. Age/health not explicitly stated but likely healthy adult sample; full text can confirm if needed.

Empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=34) performing social-emotional tasks (schadenfreude and fremdscham) involving perception/understanding of others. Fits the review focus on social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports neural processing of biological motion and includes healthy control group (age-matched). However, it does not specify that functional MRI was used or clearly describe a social-related task. Insufficient modality/task detail in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and social-task eligibility.

This is an fMRI experiment investigating self-referential and implicit social stimulus processing in humans, reporting neural correlates of social processing (e.g., temporo-parietal junction). It involves healthy adult participants and directly addresses social-related processing, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing social-related tasks (eye-gaze, self-propelling motion, implicit mental-inference). Meets review objective; abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range 17–65.

Event-related fMRI study examining neural responses to social (face) vs non-social stimuli; addresses social perception/processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or that sample is healthy, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study is a multimodal coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI and VBM studies in first-degree relatives of schizophrenia patients. It is a meta-analysis (an explicit exclusion criterion). The abstract does not describe original fMRI data of social-processing tasks in healthy adults.

fMRI study (38 participants) using a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) probing social reward/affiliation; sample appears to be healthy adults within the eligible age range; not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review discussing emotion, facial affect recognition, and imaging studies in schizophrenia rather than a primary fMRI study. The abstract does not report fMRI scans conducted on healthy adult participants (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring a functional MRI scan on human participants in a social task.

This is a review/chapter that summarizes oxytocin effects in ASD and neuroimaging findings rather than reporting original fMRI data in healthy adults. It does not meet the review objective of fMRI studies in healthy participants.

Empirical fMRI study examining social working memory and perspective-taking, reporting neural responses during social-cognitive task demands. It directly addresses social-related processing and is not a review or meta-analysis. Although participant ages/health are not specified in the abstract, the study clearly fits the review objective; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

Abstract describes fMRI data acquired during a protocol including a ‘social perception and reasoning’ functional localizer in 78 individuals who appear to be healthy. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 17–65 criterion and to extract task details.

Study used an fMRI social-reward task with healthy participants, meeting the modality and social-processing criteria. However, participants are described as adolescents aged 14–18, so it is unclear from the abstract whether a sufficient subset falls within the required adult age range (17–65). Abstract lacks detail to confirm eligibility on age. Include for full-text review to determine age composition and eligibility.

fMRI study examining understanding of others' regret (perception/understanding of others) using a gambling task — a social-related task. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Abstract identifies the article as a mini-review integrating prior MRI and genetic findings rather than reporting original fMRI data from human participants. It is a review article (systematic review/meta-analysis exclusion criterion applies), so it does not meet inclusion as an fMRI study of healthy adults.

Study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI rather than a task in which participants performed social-related processing. Although it relates to social cognition in autism, it does not meet the inclusion requirement of a social task during scanning.

Abstract reports longitudinal fMRI in early-course schizophrenia addressing social and non-social cognition but does not specify whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included or whether the fMRI task was social. Insufficient information—include for full-text review.

This is a review/theoretical paper summarizing neuroimaging literature on the cerebellum, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and does not report a task-based social fMRI in healthy participants.

fMRI study examining social vs non-social context during episodic memory retrieval in healthy participants; addresses social interaction processing (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not state ages explicitly, but participants appear to be healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm age range and participant details.
Participants were middle childhood children (approximately ages 7–13), not adults within the required 17–65 age range; therefore the study does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion.

This is an essay/review advocating cross-species social neuroscience and does not report an original fMRI study or any human participant methods/results. It lacks fMRI data from healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study of children (age 7–12) including ASD and typically developing controls; no task-based social processing in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria (age range and task-based social fMRI).

Abstract describes an fMRI experiment where human perceivers performed a social emotion-inference task (learning about others’ emotions), directly addressing social cognition. It is empirical original research (not a review). Participant health/age not specified in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are early adolescents (aged 10.5–13.4), outside the included adult age range (17–65). Additionally, the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based fMRI social processing paradigm, so it does not meet the task-based fMRI criterion.

Abstract suggests an empirical neuroimaging study of social inference in PTSD but does not explicitly state that an fMRI task was used or that healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Not a review/meta-analysis. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

This is a review article discussing neuroimaging and behavioral studies in high-functioning autism rather than an original fMRI study with healthy adult participants; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Abstract describes a narrative/review on development of the social brain in adolescence, summarizing structural MRI and fMRI findings and speculating about implications. It is not an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults (17–65) and meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study where participants made self-descriptiveness judgments (perception/understanding of self), which is social-related processing; participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies (neuroimaging meta-analysis), not a primary fMRI experiment with human participants; exclusion criterion disallows reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI conducted in healthy human participants (15 healthy males) examining oxytocin effects on amygdala during fear-inducing stimuli; topic aligns with social cognition. Abstract lacks detail on whether the stimuli are explicitly social (e.g., faces) and does not state participant ages, so full-text review warranted to confirm social-task relevance and age range.

Task involved social interaction (provocation/retaliation) during fMRI in healthy adult participants (healthy males), addressing social-emotional processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Dual (hyperscanning) functional MRI conducted while participants engaged in interactive social exchange (cooperation vs competition). Study investigates social cognition processes in (presumably) healthy adult pairs and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports two fMRI experiments testing theory-of-mind/social interaction processing (intentions in social contexts). This matches the review objective (social-related fMRI tasks). Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study in human participants (N=17) using social stimuli (love and power movie clips) probing affiliation and power motivations—social processing relevant to review. Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

This publication is a large-scale meta-analysis of ~10,000 fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The review/meta-analysis exclusion criterion is met, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI was conducted during social tasks (face-to-face conversation vs repetition) and the study includes a group of typically developing (healthy) control adults age-matched to autistic participants. Thus it fits the review’s focus on social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI study in individuals with autism spectrum conditions (clinical sample), not a task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults. No healthy adult group or social task described, so does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating communicative actions (speech acts) and neural correlates of social communication—directly relevant to social-related processing. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

Primary research using fMRI to examine social cognitive processing (social working memory) in humans; not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants (individual differences reported) and addresses perception/understanding of others, meeting inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

Abstract reports fMRI of reward processing and maternal affiliation (a social/affiliation construct) but participants are described as 'adolescents' with no ages given. Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65; age/adult status is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and eligibility.

fMRI task contrasted social vs non-social stimuli and included a matched healthy control group (14 controls). Study involves social perception processing in humans and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for healthy adult participants.

fMRI was conducted while human participants performed social-cognitive tasks (passive observation and emotion attribution/judgment), targeting perception/understanding of others. Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social cognition (face judgments of trustworthiness/age). Includes a nonclinical control group (healthy participants). Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion not explicitly confirmed), so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study using emotional face (social) go/no-go tasks and includes a neurotypical control group (healthy participants). Not a review. Abstract doesn’t state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm age range.

This is a narrative review of early brain development and infant fMRI methods rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 17–65). It is a review article (not primary data) and focuses on infants, so does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a social-related face-encoding task and includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group. The abstract does not report participants’ ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

The paper is explicitly an fMRI Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis. The review's exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses should be excluded, so this study is excluded based on the abstract alone.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) acquired before and after rTMS, with no social-related task or social processing during scanning. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion of task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in human participants involving social interaction (eye gaze, socially relevant facial expressions) and social-communication/self-relevance processes. Abstract implies healthy human participants and directly addresses the review objective. No exclusion criteria met; age not specified but sufficient to include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted during an empathy task (social processing) and the study included a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients. Abstract does not report participant ages explicitly, so full text should confirm they fall within 17–65, but inclusion criteria for having at least one healthy adult group are met based on abstract.

fMRI study of social-cognitive processing with a healthy control group, but participants are aged 10–18. Abstract does not confirm presence of healthy adults within the required 17–65 range. Insufficient information to determine adult-only inclusion, so include for full-text review.
