This study used structural MRI covariance analysis, not functional MRI during a social task. The review requires task-based fMRI in healthy adults; although controls are included, no fMRI social-task data are reported, so exclude.

fMRI study examining memory for neutral faces presented in goal-relevant vs goal-irrelevant social situations; task involves social processing (face identity, social context) and reports activation in social brain regions. No indication it is a review; likely healthy adult participants. Include for full-text to confirm ages/health.

fMRI study examining neural representations of observed actions (perception/understanding of others), using human participants—meets social-processing criterion. Abstract does not report participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

The study includes a healthy control group (n=18) aged as adults, uses fMRI during social-related tasks (action observation/execution and action-understanding) probing mirror neuron system and theory-of-mind, and reports behavioral ToM (RME). It directly addresses social processing in healthy participants; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI BOLD study administering a social-cognitive task (trustworthiness judgments of faces) and includes a healthy control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not specified in the abstract, the presence of healthy adult controls and relevant social processing task meets inclusion or warrants full-text review.

fMRI was used during a social task (social exclusion/inclusion) probing mentalizing and social processing in human participants. The sample are adolescents but ages/health status not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65 and are healthy.

Human fMRI study investigating neural representation of action meaning (mirror system) using auditory/semantic tasks; assesses perception/understanding of others’ actions — fits social-related processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract describes empirical dfMRI (dyadic fMRI) investigating BOLD responses during reciprocal eye contact/social interaction, which aligns with social processing. However, participant health and age range are not specified in the abstract; full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than task-based fMRI while participants performed social-cognitive tasks. Although healthy controls were included, the meta-analysis requires fMRI acquired during a social-related task. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports brain imaging of self/other-reflection in schizophrenia, a social-processing task. It likely uses fMRI and is relevant, but the abstract doesn’t explicitly state fMRI or confirm healthy adult controls. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to verify modality and presence of healthy participants.

This article is a narrative review/perspective, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract describes field-level discussion without reporting original methods, participants, or fMRI data from healthy adult subjects performing social tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in 22 healthy adult male participants performing social judgments (allocentric social hierarchies and social alliance), clearly a social-processing task in healthy adults within the eligible age range. Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neural hyperscanning during a social communication task in (presumably) healthy adults but does not specify the imaging modality. Inclusion requires fMRI; methods are unclear from the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm whether a functional MRI was used.

Study examines executive function and frontoparietal-insular network connectivity in autism spectrum disorder, not social-related processing. Participants are clinical (ASD) rather than a healthy adult sample performing a social task. Does not meet the review’s requirement for fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study uses a social interaction task (reaction-time competition with opponents) probing reactive aggression, which maps onto social processing/perception of others. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; likely healthy adults but not confirmed. Include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics and ages.
All healthy participants are described as youth/typically developing children/adolescents, not adults aged 17–65; study therefore lacks a healthy adult group required for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating perception of emotions in dynamic crowds—a clear social processing task relevant to the review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status; likely healthy adults but not confirmed. Per screening rules, include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics and eligibility.

fMRI study of affective creativity (reappraisal of anger-evoking events) notes recruitment of default-mode network 'implicated in social cognition.' The abstract does not explicitly state whether stimuli/tasks were social or interpersonal, so inclusion is uncertain; recommend full-text review to confirm social-related processing.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than an fMRI task involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires task-based social fMRI; despite having healthy controls and social cognition measures, it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI data collected while healthy volunteers performed psychometric assessments of body-odour peptides (self vs non-self), a social/self-perception task related to mate choice. Activation in right middle frontal cortex reported; no patient groups mentioned.

Abstract reports simultaneous fMRI (with PET) probing mothers’ neural responses to their infants and connectivity within social-affiliation networks; participants are healthy adult mothers engaged in a social/attachment task. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study of social cognition (prediction of others' mental states) in human participants, matching review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state participants were healthy; information is insufficient to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify inclusion criteria.

The study investigates memory control and recognition processes using fMRI, with no mention of social-related tasks or constructs (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Although participants are healthy adults, the primary task is non-social, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants completed social tasks (charitable giving, EmpaToM) probing empathy, perspective taking, and attention—core social processes. Study involves human participants and is empirical (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social task (judgments of fairness/moral status from cooperative interactions). Targets perception/understanding of others and social cognition; not a review or meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a review of ecstatic/orgasmic/musicogenic seizures and related phenomena, not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Participants appear to be patients/case studies; no social-related task or healthy control group is reported. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The article is explicitly a review of the authors’ research program rather than an original fMRI study reporting primary data. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses despite being relevant to social perception.

Study reports fMRI while human participants observed human and robot agents experiencing pain/pleasure—a social cognition/empathy task (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises 26 human participants (presumed healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI research where participants considered others' mental states (social cognition/perception of others). Appears to include healthy adult participants and reports neural data; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are children (mean age 10.1 years), which falls well below the review's required adult age range of 17–65. Although an fMRI social task was used with healthy participants, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study of social perception (face processing, attention to emotional valence) in human participants, addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant age or health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet age (17–65) and healthy criteria.

fMRI study with a non-clinical sample of 20 young adult males performing social-related tasks (empathic processing of realistic social interactions). Participants viewed first-person social interaction videos, addressing perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (sighted controls and congenitally blind) performing voice-based identity and emotion recognition — social perception of others. This directly addresses social-related processing in humans and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI was collected while human participants performed a social-cognitive (mind perception) task, and the study links neural activation to social attention behavior. The abstract describes healthy adult participants (no clinical groups mentioned) and it is an original empirical study, not a review.

Study used resting-state and structural MRI in boys (mean age ~11); no task-based fMRI during social-related processing. The healthy participants are children/adolescents, not an adult (17–65) healthy group required by inclusion criteria.

Study reports an fMRI emotional task and includes a healthy control group. The abstract does not clearly state the task is explicitly social-related (ambiguous), so include for full-text review to determine relevance to social processing.

Resting-state fMRI study in a sample of Major Depressive Disorder patients; no task-based social processing paradigm and no healthy adult group reported. Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review of adolescent neurobiology, not an original fMRI study reporting primary data. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it does not meet inclusion as an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI-pupillometry study examining pupil mimicry effects on trust and recruitment of theory-of-mind network (precuneus, TPJ, STS, mPFC), i.e. social cognitive processing. Not a review; likely healthy adult participants. Include for full-text review.

fMRI experiment reported neural responses to viewing disfigured faces, a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be human adults and no exclusion criteria apply. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevant social-related fMRI in (likely) healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

All participants were recruited while entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety; the abstract does not report any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.

Block-design fMRI study investigating neural responses to perception of others' facial expressions (social communication/perception). Appears to involve healthy human participants and targets relevant social processing in face-selective regions. No indication it is a review or that participants are clinical only. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI in young children (ages 3–7) including an ASD group; not a task-based social-processing fMRI study and participants are not healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using the Prisoner’s Dilemma, a social interaction task probing cooperation/non-cooperation. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and reports neural responses; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults based on abstract.

fMRI study examining emotional reactions during decisions made in social scenarios (social cognition task). Participants are healthy late adolescents and young adults; at least one group (young adults) likely falls within the 17–65 range. Abstract does not suggest a review/meta-analysis. Age detail slightly unclear, so include for full-text review to confirm exact ages and health status.

3T fMRI BOLD study of healthy adult subjects (14F/15M) performing a humor-processing task (humorous cartoons). Humor processing is a form of social cognition/perception and understanding of others; meets inclusion. Ages not specified but participants described as healthy subjects—include for full-text if needed.

This is an RCT study protocol of a behavioral intervention for individuals with psychotic disorder; no functional MRI methods or social-processing fMRI task in healthy adults are reported in the abstract. Does not meet fMRI/social-processing/healthy adult criteria.

Original fMRI study investigating communicative intention processing (social communication/perception of others) in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not specified in the abstract, it clearly fits the review objective and likely involves healthy adult subjects; include for full-text to confirm age and health details.

fMRI study where participants retrieved biographical/person knowledge—clearly social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Reports 50 participants across two studies (presumably healthy adults). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not state exact ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI study investigating how humans simulate others’ decision-making (social cognition/perception of others). Although participant health/ages aren’t specified in the abstract, the study uses human fMRI and addresses social processing; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample.

Primary fMRI study in humans (n=60) examining neural mechanisms of controlling interpersonal trust/distrust — a social-processing task. Participants appear to be healthy adults; ages fall in typical adult range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using an audio-visual 'social norm inference' task probing social perception/understanding; includes matched typically developing adult control group (healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in human participants examining processing of angry voice prosody (social communication). Task is social-related (emotion in voices) and involves healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) task, directly assessing perception/understanding of others. Includes a healthy adult control group (25 age- and gender-matched adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

Task examines gesture-speech integration (social communication) using fMRI; includes healthy adult participants (replication group n=19 and matched controls n=17). Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Human fMRI study that includes social-distance trials (photographs of participants' friends vs acquaintances), investigates social familiarity/other-processing in healthy adults; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

fMRI study where participants played the Trust Game (a social decision-making/social-processing task) examining neural correlates of Machiavellian traits. The abstract reports human participants and implies typical, nonclinical adults. This fits the review objective and inclusion criteria and is not a review article.

fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing (social communication/perception of others) in a sample of healthy subjects. Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task with healthy participants (adult sample). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used while participants viewed/listened to animated faces producing non-verbal vocalizations—a social communication/perception task relevant to social processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so information is insufficient to confirm the 17–65 healthy adult criterion; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

fMRI study using a Theory of Mind (mentalizing) task, which is social processing (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a matched healthy control group (n=13), presumably adult participants, and is an empirical study (not a review).

Human fMRI study examining how learning from another person’s values alters mPFC value representations and preference malleability — clearly social processing (understanding others/social influence). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

Event-related fMRI performed in healthy adult participants (mean age 29) during perception of others' emotional facial expressions, which is social processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy participants investigating observation and mental imagery of face and limb movements; addresses social communication and perception of others (gesture processing). Abstract does not report clinical-only samples or that it is a review. Insufficient detail on ages but meets inclusion for full-text review.

Study is a resting-state fMRI investigation of cocaine-dependent individuals (no social task). It does not report an fMRI social-related task or clearly include a healthy adult group performing social processing, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study includes a social task (theory-of-mind/social attribution) alongside other tasks and reports task-related TPJ activations. Subjects were scanned (implying human participants) and the study is empirical (not a review). Age range not specified in abstract, but it likely involves healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

fMRI study investigating social communication (‘vitality forms’) during speech and action tasks, which aligns with social-related processing. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly that sample were healthy adults—insufficient information to confirm—but likely eligible; therefore include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics and age range.

fMRI study of social-related processing (direct and reflected self-appraisals). Includes a healthy adult participant group aged 23–30, within 17–65 range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study investigating implicit Theory of Mind/false-belief processing (perception/understanding of others), a social-related task. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of processing emotional facial expressions (social perception/communication). Includes a healthy control group of adults (mean age 27, within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

fMRI study in healthy adult women (ages 25–50) measuring neural responses to erotic pictures/videos. It’s unclear whether the task counts as social-related processing, though authors report activations in areas linked to social cognition—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI examining multiple domains including social cognition (social task domain) and thus addresses social processing. However the abstract does not specify participant health status or ages. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) and other eligibility details.

This publication is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation of 125 fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it should be excluded based on abstract alone.

fMRI study where participants played an interactive ball-toss game examining neural responses to social exclusion — a social-processing task. Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

Primary fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing social tasks (collaboration vs competition) investigating neural mechanisms of social motivation; directly addresses social processing and meets inclusion criteria. Not a review.

fMRI study with 37 healthy participants watching social-evaluative videos investigating neural processing of social evaluation (perception/understanding of others/self). Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria (healthy adult fMRI social task). Not a review or meta-analysis. Age range not stated but participants are described as healthy adults; include for full-text verification if needed.

Abstract reports neural tracking of self and others during cooperative and competitive social tasks, indicating social processing and neuroimaging of brain regions (area 9, perigenual ACC). The abstract does not explicitly state 'fMRI' or participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant characteristics.

This is a resting-state fMRI parcellation study of the lateral frontal cortex with no task-based or social-related processing described in the abstract. It does not meet the requirement of an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Therefore exclude.

This is a narrative review of neuroimaging literature, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing social-related tasks. It does not report primary fMRI data on healthy adults, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment where participants performed a social-attribution task (attributing awareness to a cartoon face) with TPJ activation. This is a social-related fMRI study in human participants (presumed healthy adults) and is not a review. Age not specified—include for full-text confirmation.

Abstract reports an fMRI hyperscanning study of real-time social interaction (mutual gaze and joint attention), clearly addressing social processing in human participants. It is an original empirical study (not a review). Although participant ages/health status aren’t specified in the abstract, there is no indication of clinical populations; include for full-text review to confirm ages and health criteria.

Abstract reports a 3T fMRI study of explicit emotion recognition (perception/understanding of others) in 21 healthy young males (within 17–65). This is a social-related task in healthy adults and not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study reporting a functional MRI experiment on inhibition of imitative responses and control of shared representations, relating to social-cognitive processes (self–other distinction, mental state attribution). It involves a social-related task and is not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages aren’t specified, the study context implies healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing tasks manipulating abstract vs. concrete mindsets. Abstract does not clearly state social stimuli but situates work in social cognition; insufficient detail to confirm social-related task. Include for full-text review to verify relevance to social processing.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; thus it does not meet the task-based criterion despite assessing social functioning.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing an auditory task (listening to human footsteps) that engages regions linked to social cognition (posterior STS). Not a review; meets social perception/understanding of others construct. Age not specified—include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI study of social appraisal (judging liking of emotional faces) and includes a healthy adult control group (21 healthy subjects). Task is social-related and not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study investigating social perception/understanding of others (viewing social-group photographs) in healthy adult participants (n=10). Tasks are social-related; study is original empirical fMRI work, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study used fMRI while participants performed social-related tasks involving peer observation and social influence (Stoplight task), assessing social cognition and decision-making. Participants are healthy young adults, fitting the 17–65 range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of 22 healthy adult participants performing emotional prosody categorization and metrical stress tasks, which is social communication/perception of others — directly aligns with review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis and sufficient abstract detail to include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while mothers were exposed to infant cries (a social/attachment-related stimulus). Participants are healthy adult mothers (within 17–65). Study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

All participants are individuals with alcohol use disorder (no healthy control group). Although the fMRI task probes emotion/social processing, inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults (17–65). Therefore the study does not meet the healthy-participant criterion.

fMRI study administered social cognition tasks (reasoning about others’ mental states) to neurologically normal participants, meeting the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages/numbers, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.
This article is a meta-analysis/systematic review rather than an original fMRI study reporting primary data; exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) is clearly met.

fMRI study in healthy adults viewing a moral dilemma movie manipulating perceived kinship, directly assessing social cognition (moral/emotional conflict, mentalizing). The task is social-related and uses functional MRI; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social-processing fMRI) in toddlers with ASD and comparison groups. Participants are young children/clinical ASD subgroups, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no task) to examine functional connectivity between memory and mentalizing regions. Inclusion requires fMRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task; that criterion is not met. Abstract does not indicate task-based social processing.

Abstract does not specify that fMRI was used or that a healthy adult group (age 17–65) was included. Topic (visual personal familiarity) may be social-related, but information is insufficient to confirm fMRI task or eligible healthy participants. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This abstract is a narrative review synthesizing lesion and fMRI findings rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment with participants and task details. No methods, participant group, or fMRI task are described, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of an original fMRI study in healthy adults.

fMRI study on emotional prosody comprehension—a social communication task probing perception/understanding of others—investigates neural correlates (mPFC). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original fMRI empirical study (not a review). Abstract contains sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI in healthy adults (n=8) where participants received interpersonal manual touch (left hand touched by two individuals). Interpersonal touch is a social-related stimulus linked to social interaction/perception, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

This is a narrative review/chapter summarizing amygdala findings across neurodevelopmental disorders, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The abstract describes a review of postmortem, structural MRI, and functional MRI results rather than reporting a functional MRI experiment with a healthy adult sample. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion (review) and lacks necessary participant/task details for inclusion.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis of neuroimaging (fMRI and PET) studies rather than a primary fMRI study reporting original participant-level data. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

Abstract reports neural activation and connectivity (DLPFC, nucleus accumbens) associated with compassion training and increased altruistic behavior in healthy adults; this involves social cognition/understanding of others and implies fMRI during a social-related task. No exclusion criteria met.

This is a book chapter/review linking behavioral and developmental social neuroscience literature about adolescents, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract does not report an fMRI scan or participants performing a social task, and it focuses on adolescents rather than healthy adult participants (17–65).

Abstract examines neural responses to emotionally salient human eyes in Tourette syndrome patients compared with healthy controls (a social cognition/mentalizing task). It implies neuroimaging but does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages. Include for full-text review to confirm that an fMRI scan was used and that healthy participants are aged 17–65.

Study sample is described as adolescents across three phases of adolescence; no adult (age 17–65) healthy participant group is reported in the abstract. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion for the review.

Functional MRI was used during social-cognitive tasks (self vs friend personality and memory judgments), addressing perception/understanding of self and others. The study reports healthy adult participants (typical fMRI sample) and is not a review. Age range not specified in the abstract, but per screening rules this contains sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study investigates recognition memory and emotional valence effects (repetition suppression/enhancement) for visual stimuli, not social-related processing or social cognition. Abstract provides no evidence of tasks involving affiliation, communication, or perception/understanding of others. Therefore it does not meet the review’s social-task criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in human subjects examining perception of others' actions and engagement of the mentalizing network (social cognition). No indication of patient groups; fits healthy adult social-processing criterion. Not a review.

This paper is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis). The review's exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded based on the abstract.

This article is a coordinate-based meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation of 30 articles). The review’s exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so exclude based on abstract.
fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=21 males) performing a social-related task (perception/understanding of dyadic nonverbal behavior). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed mentalizing/social-cognition tasks about individuals and groups (perception/understanding of others). Primary research article (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Functional MRI study in healthy volunteers including an experimental task contrasting anticipation of touching an animate (human) versus inanimate (mannequin) target—directly assesses social-related processing (social approach/interaction). Not a review and meets participant criteria; include for full-text review.

Study population is preschool-aged children with ASD (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Additionally, the focus is on amygdala functional connectivity (likely in resting-state) rather than task-based social processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants playing the Trust Game (a social reciprocity task), directly assessing social cognitive/neural processes. Participants are healthy adults (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Not an fMRI study: qualitative focus group and questionnaire with adolescents; no functional MRI task reported. Also participants are teenagers rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social-inclusion task (social processing). Includes a healthy control group (n=17). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age of participants not reported in abstract—include for full-text to confirm 17–65 eligibility.

fMRI study of language/semantic comprehension in schizophrenia patients; task is language processing rather than social-related processing, and abstract does not report a healthy adult group. Does not meet review’s social-task or healthy-participant criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (not adults 17–65) and include an ASD clinical group; the task is low-level auditory/visual perception (crossmodal modulation), not a social-related processing task. Therefore it does not meet the adult healthy social fMRI inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI to examine hypnotic-suggestion-induced pain and sensory/prefrontal correlates, not a social-processing task. The manipulation targets pain perception, with no social stimuli or measures of affiliation, social communication, or self/other perception. Thus it does not meet the ‘social-related task’ inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining processing of conspecific disgust facial expressions (social perception/understanding of others). Appears to use healthy adult participants and involves a social-related task; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI studies.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing a social gambling task (wins/losses for self, best friend, disliked other), directly examining neural processing of others (mPFC, TPJ) and reward-related social processing. Matches review objective (social-related processing in healthy adults) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state exact ages, so include for full-text if age needs confirmation.

The study used rTMS to create a virtual lesion; no functional MRI scanning was performed during a social task. Inclusion requires a functional MRI scan; therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in humans examining neural and behavioural responses to gaze shifts (social processing). Task is explicitly social (joint attention, gaze direction). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and reports fMRI activation. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

7T fMRI study in healthy participants (n=23 for imaging) using a rest-task-rest paradigm where participants listened to attachment-related narratives (social/affiliation processing). This is social-related fMRI in healthy adults, matching inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes an fMRI experiment in which participants (presumably healthy adults) performed a social perception task (judging direction/social intent of point-light displays and human-like walkers). This fits the review objective. Age/health not fully detailed; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI study examining mental state attribution (attribution of intentions) to human vs computer-generated music—addresses perception/understanding of others, a social cognition task. Involves human participants and neural activation data; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study examining gender perception from faces, which is social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports a task involving face-based social judgments (attending to attractiveness). No indication of patient groups or that it is a review. Meets inclusion criteria; ages not specified in abstract but likely healthy adult sample—full text can confirm exact ages.

Abstract reports fMRI during verbal fluency and nonsense sentence completion in PAX6 mutation subjects with deficits in social cognition. The tasks described are language/executive, not clearly social-processing, and the abstract does not explicitly state a healthy control group. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.
Participants are children with autism spectrum disorder; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Does not meet population/age inclusion criteria for review of healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI study using the Trust Game (social reciprocity), directly assessing social cognitive processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not report participant age/health, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adults processing abstract vs. concrete descriptions of human actions, implicating default mode network (often linked to social cognition). The abstract does not explicitly state a social task, so include for full-text review to determine whether it meets social-related processing criteria (e.g., mentalizing/understanding others).

This article is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (meta-analysis of fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria explicitly remove systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study using dynamic facial-expression stimuli targeting pSTS—directly probes social perception/processing in humans. Abstract indicates neurofeedback was performed across subjects but does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status. Insufficient participant detail in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age/health criteria.

fMRI study examining mentalizing, empathy, and prosocial behavior—clearly social-related processing. Involves human participants (healthy adults implied). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria; sufficient information in abstract to include for full-text review.

Primary empirical fMRI study of social evaluation (in-group/out-group politician trait ratings), directly examining social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participants appear to be healthy adults performing a social task, meeting inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=29) measuring brain responses while observing others’ actions (social perception/understanding of others). Fits inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review.

Functional MRI was used to measure brain response to fearful faces (social/emotional processing). Study includes a group of healthy male controls (adult participants) matched to premutation carriers, meeting the criterion of at least one healthy adult group. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract does not specify whether an fMRI scan was used or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. The study examines mirror-neuron embodied simulation and emotion in first-episode schizophrenia, which could involve social tasks and fMRI, but details are insufficient. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Resting-state fMRI in a pediatric sample (children, including ASD-LI and typically developing children) rather than task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults (17–65). No social task was used; population and paradigm do not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining empathy for pain (a social/other-understanding task) with acute stress and prosocial behavior; appears to involve healthy adult participants and reports neural responses during a social task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used while participants made social evaluations of person information (social cognition/perception of others). The task clearly involves social processing and is not a review. No clinical population is indicated, suggesting healthy adult participants. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Participants aged 8–19 include some individuals within the 17–65 range, but the abstract does not report a distinct adult-only healthy group or analyses restricted to ≥17. Insufficient information to confirm eligibility based on adults; include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants performed social-category judgments (stereotype activation), a social cognition task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract addresses social-cognitive task (visual perspective-taking) and neural function/connectivity. However it does not explicitly state use of fMRI nor whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient detail to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review to verify fMRI and healthy participant criteria.

fMRI study where pairs of (presumably healthy adult) participants performed a social task—rating and communicating emotional arousal—while neural activity (insula, PFC, ventral striatum) was measured. This directly examines social processing in adults and is not a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI task probing social inclusion/exclusion (social processing). Sample described as adolescents but no specific ages given; insufficient information to confirm participants fall within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and health status.

This study used structural MRI (cortical thickness and structural covariance) in ASD and control samples, not task-based functional MRI of social processing in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy participants.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy human participants examining persuasion/expert influence (social evaluation, trust, attitudes) — a social-related task; meets age/group criterion implicitly; not a review. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining facial emotion recognition (a social cognitive task) with intranasal oxytocin; includes a neurotypical control group of adults alongside individuals with Asperger syndrome, meeting the requirement of at least one healthy participant group. Not a review article.

Original fMRI study comparing social vs non-social image appraisal with ROI BOLD analyses in an independent dataset. Involves healthy adult participants and directly investigates social processing. Although it also reports an automated meta-analysis, the paper contains primary fMRI data and is not solely a review, so it meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI studies investigating perception of dynamic audio-visual emotional cues — a social-related process (emotion perception). Abstract does not specify participant characteristics or ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI study modeling neural representations of sentences that include event types such as 'social interaction.' The abstract indicates participants and generalizability but does not specify explicit social-cognition task details or participant ages. Insufficient information to confirm/deny social-task and age criteria, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adults where tactile stimulation influenced judgments of ambiguous social interactions; neural activation (somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, prefrontal cortex) is described. This meets criteria of fMRI during a social-related task in healthy participants.
Narrative review of fNIRS studies in Autism Spectrum Disorder rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults; also a review article (exclusion criterion).

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) performing a social-related task (observation of mouth actions across species) probing social perception/understanding, mirror neuron and empathy networks—meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract provides insufficient detail to confirm that a functional MRI task was used or that healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. Title and focus on neural basis of naturalistic mentalising suggest relevance to social processing, and likely includes typical-development group; therefore include for full-text review to confirm fMRI methods and participant ages.

fMRI study of social preference judgments (social evaluation) in humans, demonstrating neural activity/connectivity during a socio-emotional task. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI research.

fMRI study measuring neural responses during social competition (social feedback) in human participants; examines social-relevant processes (social-referencing, distraction). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Study investigates resting-state brain activity in bvFTD patients (clinical sample) and does not report a task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring task-based social fMRI with healthy participants aged 17–65.

Abstract focuses on developmental changes in face specialization and does not specify use of fMRI nor whether participants are adults (17–65). It is not a review article. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI in healthy adults, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This article is a review of task-related EEG/fMRI studies in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses, and the focus is on a clinical population, not a healthy adult sample.

The study reports fMRI during an agency inference task (perception/understanding of self — a social-related construct) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=31) likely within 17–65. It is an original fMRI study, not a review, and meets the meta-analysis criteria.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adult participants performing self-face recognition, which falls under ’Perception and Understanding of Self’ (a social-related construct). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social-related processing (judgments of pride and joy, involving social cognition/theory of mind) conducted in healthy volunteers. Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI, healthy adult participants). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study in which participants (presumably healthy adults) performed judgments about social concepts versus non-social concepts — a social-related task. Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

Event-related fMRI in human subjects examining processing of others' decisions and mental states — directly relevant to social cognition/perception of others. Abstract does not report participant ages or health status explicitly; insufficient detail to confirm age range, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study presenting dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset) — a social communication task involving perception of others’ emotions. Abstract reports BOLD responses and subjective ratings, implying human participants likely healthy adults. Meets review objective of social processing in fMRI. If participant health/age not specified in full text, include for full-text review to confirm.

fMRI study examining facial recognition (social perception) during a task; appears to involve healthy participants. Abstract does not report ages or full participant details, so inclusion should be confirmed at full-text stage. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining amygdala responses to masked fearful eyes (social threat cue), addressing social perception/processing. Uses a double-blind, placebo-controlled oxytocin manipulation in humans. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or age range; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65) and other eligibility details.

fMRI study using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task, a social-cognition (mental state recognition) task, with an age-matched healthy control group reported. Participants are human adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met based on the abstract.

Original fMRI study applying a social-cognitive task (neutral face processing) in a sample of healthy participants (n=74), examining social-related processing (pSTS responses). Meets age/group and task-based fMRI inclusion criteria and is not a review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study without participants performing a social-related task during scanning. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing; therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study using a real-world social task (speed-dating) examining responses to romantic interest/rejection and mentalizing in healthy adult participants. Matches review objective of fMRI social processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract describes a narrative synthesis of multiple functional neuroimaging studies rather than reporting original fMRI data or methods/participants. No primary sample or task details provided—appears to be a review article, so excluded per exclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face perception addressing social communication/perception of others. Abstract reports human fMRI data and likely healthy participants but does not specify participant ages or health status; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range (17–65) and health details.

Study used fMRI in preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks PMA), not healthy adults aged 17–65, and investigated somatosensory mapping rather than social-related processing. Does not meet the population or task inclusion criteria.

The abstract explicitly describes a meta-analysis of 33 fMRI studies rather than reporting a primary fMRI experiment with participants. This meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Human fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others (observing violent social interactions) and modulation by personality. Abstract implies healthy participants and meets social-processing task criterion; age not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task (continuous ratings of others' emotions), addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Participants are children (10–15 years), not within the required adult age range (17–65). The fMRI task involves passive auditory change detection (non-social stimuli), so it does not assess social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is a narrative review of perceptual organization in schizophrenia, not an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI scans during social-related tasks in healthy adults; thus it fails the primary inclusion criterion. Exclude.

Study used fMRI during a social cognition task (adapted Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Task) and included a healthy non-offender control group (H). Participants are adult men and the study is original research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies with healthy adults.

Study 2 used fMRI to measure neural responses (mPFC, PCC, temporal poles) during viewing of sexualized and clothed men/women, a social-perception/mental-state attribution task in healthy adult participants (heterosexual men). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The healthy control group comprises adolescents aged 13–19 (includes minors <17). The review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65; this study’s sample is adolescent, not adult, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in which participants performed a social-closeness task (photos of friends vs unknown people), directly addressing social-related processing. It is not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract — include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study manipulating interpersonal space (social processing) in a double-blind intranasal oxytocin study with healthy adult participants; addresses social cognition (affiliation/understanding others). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during theory-of-mind tasks (social cognition) and included a healthy control group (n=14). Participants are adults (siblings and patients), fitting the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy human subjects examining social communication (gaze and pointing cues). The abstract does not report participant ages; per screening instructions, include for full-text review to confirm age range and other methodological details.

Participants are children aged 3–5 (not within 17–65 adult range) and the study used resting-state fMRI examining DMN development rather than an fMRI social-task or social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are preadolescents (children/adolescents), whereas inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Although an fMRI social-cognition task was used, the sample age falls outside the eligible range, so the study is excluded.

Original fMRI study with healthy volunteers performing social cognition tasks (theory-of-mind reasoning about cooperation and deception). Directly assesses perception/understanding of others using fMRI in humans; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI study examining theory of mind and responses to unexpected social vs non-social events—clearly a social-processing task. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65) and other eligibility details.

The study used resting-state functional connectivity and structural analyses in adults with autism spectrum disorder; it does not report task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults, nor clearly include a healthy control group performing a social task. Thus it fails the requirement for task-based social fMRI in healthy participants.

Study reports fMRI during an observe/imitate emotional faces task (social processing) in a sample of healthy adults (n=28, analyses n=20) within the target age range. It is an original empirical study (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract identifies this paper as a review ('we review') rather than an original fMRI study; it does not report a specific fMRI experiment of social processing in healthy adults. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), exclude.

Not a task-based social fMRI study in healthy adults. The paper reports structural MRI subtyping in individuals with autism and resting-state fMRI findings; participants are clinical (ASD), and no task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy 17–65 sample is described.

Abstract focuses on BPD patients and anger/aggression; it does not state whether a social-related task was used or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

Sample consists of adolescents (developmental sample assessed annually), clearly outside the eligible adult age range (17–65). Also the fMRI measures report risk processing/cognitive control (not a clearly social-related task).

fMRI study investigating impression updating (perception/understanding of others) during a social task. Abstract indicates human participants and neural measures; no evidence it's a review or clinical-only sample. Abstract lacks explicit age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study with 18 adult participants performing a social cognition task (predicting others’ behavior, theory-of-mind vs deontic inference). Involves perception/understanding of others and impression updating; participants appear healthy and age range fits. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining social perception of others’ pupillary responses (social salience/other-understanding). Meets inclusion: social-related task, functional MRI, healthy adult sample. Not a review.

Event-related fMRI study comparing processing of emotion words vs control words; includes typically-developing control group (healthy participants). Task probes emotional/social semantic processing relevant to social cognition. No exclusion criteria met; abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining self-face recognition, which fits 'Perception and Understanding of Self' social processing. Functional MRI was used during a self-face recognition task; no clinical populations or review article indicated. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural responses to observed actions (mirror system) in human participants; task involves perception/understanding of others (social cognition). Appears to involve healthy adult participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract examines neural correlates of social cooperation/non-cooperation in a dyadic social interaction and likely involves neuroimaging, addressing social processing. However, it does not explicitly state use of functional MRI or participant ages. Insufficient detail to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI methods and that healthy adult participants (age 17–65) are included.

fMRI study using a social interaction task (virtual handshake; acceptance vs refusal) and includes a healthy control group (n=16) of adults. The study directly examines social processing and is not a review/meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a narrative review of model-based fMRI approaches to social interaction and mentions BOLD imaging in healthy humans, but it is unclear whether the paper reports original fMRI data in healthy adults versus being a review. Not explicitly a systematic review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Participants are autistic children/adolescents and matched typically developing children, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although an fMRI social task was used, no healthy adult group in the target age range is present.

fMRI study of pain empathy (social cognitive processing: perception/understanding of others) with experimental perspective-taking manipulation. Includes a healthy control group (n=21), presumably adults within the 17–65 range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study with 44 healthy participants performing explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) of voices, addressing social evaluation/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of face perception (social processing) using the Thatcher illusion; includes a matched healthy young adult control group (20 neurotypical adults, likely within 17–65). Task probes perception/understanding of others (eyes/mouth), meeting the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (direct vs averted gaze) with human participants; includes a matched healthy control group (23 controls) within typical adult sample. Task targets perception/understanding of others, meets inclusion criteria. Not a review.

The study examines reward circuitry (monetary and object-image incentives) in individuals with ASD and controls, not social-related processing. The task is incentive/reward-based rather than measuring social affiliation, communication, or perception of self/others, so it does not address the review objective.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a social provocation (Taylor aggression) task probing social/emotional processing; sample comprised 93 healthy adult males (within target age range); neural responses to social provocation were measured. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social processing (empathy/sympathy) in healthy human participants; sample age range 7–40 includes adults within 17–65 (17–40). No exclusion criteria (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind/intentional causality (social cognition). Abstract reports group differences with reduced TPJ response in ASD, implying a comparison (likely healthy control) group. Include for full-text review to confirm presence/age range of healthy participants and extract relevant data.
Resting-state fMRI in young children (mean age ~5) with ASD and controls — not a task-based social-processing fMRI study in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet population or task criteria.

The abstract describes a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (lesion work, TMS, MVPA, and Neurosynth analyses) rather than reporting original fMRI data collected from participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study reports functional MRI during a social attribution task with both healthy control participants and BPD patients. Healthy adults were included and neural activity during social processing was measured. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study investigating social communicative intentions/prosody and neural mechanisms—directly relevant to social communication and perception of others. Abstract describes fMRI task involving categorization of prosodic expressions and social inference. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using a passive viewing task of disgusted in-group vs out-group faces—directly addresses social perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy adult sample and task-based fMRI; participant ages/health not explicitly reported, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (social-related processing) and includes a healthy control group alongside clinical groups. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, participants are described as adults (women) and meet the review’s criteria for inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy subjects performing familiarity judgments of personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participant ages not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=30) performing social-emotional tasks (gender identification of angry and happy faces), addressing perception/understanding of others. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of a social attribution task (inferring causes of others’ emotions) and reports a healthy control group (n=16). Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion cannot be confirmed from abstract), so include for full-text review to verify age eligibility and extract details.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (61 white males) performing a social perception task (evaluating faces by race and socioeconomic status). This directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mothers without current mental disorders) performing an emotional face recognition task involving perception/understanding of another (own child) — fits social processing in healthy adults. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.
Participants are adolescents (13-year-olds), outside the required healthy adult age range of 17–65; therefore the study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining neural integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—directly relevant to social perception/understanding of others. Abstract indicates whole-brain fMRI analyses and dynamic causal modeling. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study in healthy college-age participants examining emotional memory retrieval for a competitive social sporting event involving fan identity and group perspective. Task taps social cognition/affiliation (social bonds, fan perspective). Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI studies conducted while participants judged persuasive messages (social-cognitive/mentalizing task). Samples are healthy adult groups (American and Korean) and include video/text media; not a review. Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was performed while participants viewed emotional faces (a social cognition/perception task). The study includes a healthy control group. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and other details.

fMRI study investigating animacy perception/mentalizing (social cognition) using human participants. Abstract indicates social-related task and neural activation in social brain networks. No evidence of exclusion criteria; participant health/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults aged 17–65.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=42, ages within 17–65) performing a social-related task (understanding self and other's internal states in romantic interactions). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI measured brain responses while participants (football supporters) viewed social group–relevant stimuli; study examines social cognition/group bias (social-related processing). Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing.

fMRI task assessed pain anticipation and fear of movement (observing/rating exercise videos), not a social-related task. Although authors mention neural regions linked to social cognition, the study’s primary construct is pain/fear, so it does not meet the review’s social-processing inclusion criterion.

This study used resting-state fMRI to assess intraparietal sulcus functional connectivity and genetic effects (LIMK1). It did not involve a task-based social-related fMRI paradigm, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring a social task, despite involving healthy adults and social-processing regions.

fMRI study assessing social reward (agreement with music experts) and non-social reward; includes a matched stimulant‑naive healthy control group, directly examining social processing. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria.

This study is a quantitative meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with participants; it therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although it included healthy controls, no social-related task was performed, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion of task-based social fMRI.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (rfMRI) to predict gender and does not involve participants performing any social-related task or social processing paradigm. Does not meet the requirement for task-based social fMRI in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study with 27 healthy adult participants performing social interaction tasks probing intention understanding (mentalizing and action understanding). Addresses perception/understanding of others, fits the review objective. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Study reports fMRI of healthy adults performing a Socio-affective Video Task involving witnessing others’ distress (social-related processing: compassion/empathy). Fits population (healthy adults 17–65) and task-based fMRI inclusion criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of action imitation/observation (social cognition via the mirror neuron system), which matches the review’s social-related task requirement. However, the abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included or participant ages. Insufficient info to rule out inclusion, so include for full-text review.

Original fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others—a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic vs. static facial expressions—clearly a social perception/interpretation task. Abstract describes three fMRI experiments but does not specify participant ages/health status. Include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65) and meet inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in Williams syndrome and matched controls, not a task-based fMRI of social-related processing. Inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; no social task is reported, so it is ineligible.

Abstract reports fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social processing) in CHR youth and neural networks, but does not specify inclusion of a healthy control group or participant ages. Insufficient information to determine presence of healthy adults 17–65, so include for full-text review.

fMRI during the Embedded Figures Task, which is a perceptual/visual task rather than a social-related task. Although authors relate activation to social-severity measures, the task itself is not social, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task assessing social-related processing, and participants are described as adolescents (not clearly within the 17–65 adult range). Thus it does not meet the task-based social processing and adult-age inclusion criteria.

fMRI measured neural responses to facial expressions (social cognition). The study includes healthy participants (independent replication sample of healthy Caucasians) alongside clinical groups, and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult participants meets inclusion; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of empathy (social-related task) including a typically developing healthy control group. Abstract reports participant ages 12–31, so it’s unclear whether the healthy group is fully within the 17–65 adult range; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract data.

Abstract addresses social information sharing and neural valuation—relevant to social processing. However, it does not specify that a functional MRI scan was conducted or report participant ages/health status. Insufficient methodological detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study using an interactive face-to-face joint attention task (social processing). Includes neurotypical adult participant groups (n=14 matched, n=22), so meets criterion of at least one healthy adult group (adults likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI tasks were saccadic and pursuit eye movements assessing sensorimotor control in autism, not social-related processing. Although healthy controls were included, the paradigm does not involve social cognition/interaction; abstract provides no social task information.

The study used resting-state fMRI (dFNC) rather than an fMRI task involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task leads to exclusion.

Abstract reports atypical frontal activation during visual attention in autism relatives, suggesting neuroimaging of social/attention processing. However it does not specify fMRI use, participant ages, or that the task is explicitly social. Insufficient details to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review.

fMRI study using emotional face stimuli during a gender-discrimination task (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy genotype groups (no clinical population reported). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study examining action observation and motor pantomime (mirror system) addresses perception and understanding of others—falls under social-related processing. Includes healthy adult participants (sighted volunteers) and uses functional MRI. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants performed a social decision-making task involving another person controlling choices (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy; study is empirical neuroimaging, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are young children with autism (ASD); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included. Study does not examine fMRI social processing in healthy adult participants, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI during affective speech comprehension probes social cognition/Theory-of-Mind processes. Study reports data from 51 participants (presumably healthy adults) performing social-related tasks; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; full text can confirm ages/health status.

fMRI study investigating perception of social actions in LOTC using RSA, clearly addressing social-related processing in humans. Abstract indicates experimental fMRI work with participants but does not specify ages/health status; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adults using a socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation task (psychotherapist instructions). Investigates attachment/affiliation (Adult Attachment Scale) and social cognitive processing with task-based fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social-related emotion attribution/empathy (SELF vs OTHER) in healthy adults, addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating anticipatory sensorimotor processes during active interpersonal touch (human vs inanimate targets), addressing social processing and perception/understanding of others. fMRI was conducted on human participants (implied healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports investigation of brain activation during emotion processing in unaffected siblings of schizophrenia patients — emotion processing is a social cognition task (Perception/Understanding of Others). Participants are described as unaffected (healthy) adults. Modality not explicitly stated as fMRI, so include for full-text review to confirm scan details.

fMRI study in healthy adult mothers (N=23) viewing own/standard infant videos—task assesses social/attachment processing (affiliation). Meets age and task criteria; not a review. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full review.

The article is explicitly a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies (per title/abstract). This meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' so it is not a primary fMRI study for inclusion.

The article is a review summarizing neuroimaging studies in autism rather than an original fMRI study reporting primary data. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide evidence of an fMRI social-task in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used with healthy adult participants performing face perception, similarity-judgement, and face-recognition tasks. These tasks probe perception/understanding of others (social processing), meeting inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.
