Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI data were resting-state (rsfMRI) rather than collected while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; although healthy adults were included and the topic is social-cognitive, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Modality mismatch: study used EEG (ERP and time-frequency analyses) rather than functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task; although participants were healthy adults and task is social, the absence of fMRI means exclusion.

fMRI study involving healthy participants including an adult group (18+), examines social influence (expert advice) during decision-making and reports activity in social-cognition regions (TPJ) — consistent with social-related processing. Not a review article and meets age and methodology inclusion criteria.

Study uses mouse (rodent) resting-state fMRI; no human participants or social-task paradigm. Focuses on mouse connectome and default mode network, so does not meet inclusion criteria requiring human fMRI during social-related tasks.

Empirical fMRI study with 46 healthy adult volunteers performing theory-of-mind tasks (emotion, belief, pain judgments) addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of joint attention (social communication) using an interactive task in human participants; not a review. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI study of healthy human listeners performing auditory emotion discrimination (social communication/perception of others), fits social-related processing in adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates neural responses in auditory cortex and amygdala during affective voice processing, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults (n=98) involving social-processing tasks (judgments about self, friends, and others assessing closeness/similarity). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adult sample within target age range). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Study investigates birdsong and proposes frameworks and animal fMRI; participants are non-human (songbirds). Does not report fMRI in human adults performing social-related tasks. Exclude based on wrong species (animal study).

Study used 3T fMRI during a multiround trust game (a social relationship task) and reports a healthy comparison group of women. This meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing with healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

The study used transcranial magnetic stimulation (disruptive TMS) of the rTPJ, not functional MRI. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

fMRI study in healthy adult men (n=10 per group) using viewing of romantic (affiliation/attachment-related) and sexual stimuli—task probes social/affiliative processing. No psychiatric/neurological disorders reported and not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of automatic neural responses to masked facial emotions (social/attachment-related processing) in a sample of 51 healthy adults; assesses attachment avoidance (affiliation/attachment construct). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of trustworthiness appraisal (social processing) in Borderline Personality Disorder and reports comparisons to controls, implying a healthy adult control group. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) addressing social-related processing, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social self/other evaluations (social-related processing). Includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full review.

fMRI study of healthy participants watching short film scenes evoking emotional conflicts; task involves social-emotional processing and engages regions implicated in social cognition (STS, IPL). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study with healthy participants investigating recognition of visual feedback/self–other distinction, which maps onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Others’ (a social-related construct). No exclusion criteria met; age not specified but includes healthy adults. Include for full-text review.

Abstract explicitly states this is a review presenting results from ERPs and fMRI studies rather than reporting original fMRI data. Excluded per the criteria that systematic reviews/meta-analyses are not eligible.

Abstract does not specify imaging modality or participant details but addresses parental brain and social bonding (social processing). Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and age range, so include for full-text review to determine whether a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults was conducted.

Functional MRI was used in healthy adult participants performing a social task (receiving negative social feedback/social evaluation). Participants are healthy adults (men) within the target age range. Study is original fMRI research, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to eye gaze (social attention perception) in typically developing (healthy) adults; not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text to confirm age range and detailed methods.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants classified emotions from dynamic avatars—task assesses perception and understanding of others (social processing). Abstract reports neural responses in emotion and biological-motion regions. Not a review or meta-analysis. Sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI results linked to hippocampal activity, used an experimentally induced out-of-body illusion during a social interaction task, and involves healthy participants; this fits fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Study used positron emission tomography (PET), not functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although task involves deception/social interaction in healthy adults, the imaging modality does not meet the criterion.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm assessing social-related processing. Although it examines social relationships, there was no social-related task performed during scanning, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social task.

Task-based fMRI using a social-rejection (Cyberball) paradigm assessing social processing. The sample includes an adult group (16 adult female participants), presumed healthy, meeting the review’s adult age criterion. Therefore the study addresses the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI neural activity during emotional face processing (a social perception task) with effects in amygdala, fusiform, and insula, meeting the review’s focus on social-related fMRI. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.
Participants are children in middle childhood (ages 8–12). The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65, so this study does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Participants are described as adolescents with autism and their siblings—i.e., a non-adult sample. The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants age 17–65; abstract indicates adolescent sample, so does not meet age criterion.

Study includes an fMRI facial emotion processing task (social-related) and a healthy control group (n=27). Not a review or meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Randomized, placebo-controlled double-blind fMRI study using an interactive social task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) in human males and females. Examines neural/behavioral responses to social interaction in healthy adults and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI studies.

Study uses fMRI in human participants on social-related task (cross-modal recognition of other people’s identity — perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy sample; given insufficient detail on age/health, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was conducted during a social-related task (contemplation/imaginary sentence completion about mothers and fathers). The study includes a healthy control group of volunteers (ages not specified but likely adults) alongside patients with schizophrenia, and it is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

The study used resting-state fMRI with a pre-scan criticism manipulation rather than an active social-related task performed during scanning. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social task; thus it does not meet the task-based criterion.

This publication is a voxel-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies in schizophrenia. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract does not present primary data with a healthy participant group.

This article is itself a systematic review and meta-analysis of imaging studies (not a primary fMRI study). Exclusion criterion disallows reviews/meta-analyses; abstract does not report original fMRI data on participants. Therefore exclude.

The study examines cognitive emotion regulation to positive/negative pictures but does not investigate social processing (no social stimuli, interactions, or measures of affiliation/communication/understanding of others or self). Therefore it does not meet the review’s social-related task requirement.

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis (title and abstract state this). The exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded. Additionally, it does not report an original fMRI study of healthy adults in the abstract.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion (fear) processing—a social cognition task—includes a healthy control group (24 adults). Task assesses perception/understanding of others; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while healthy participants performed a social communication task (perceiving messages believed to be from a friend vs a computer). The study examines social processing (social communication, perception of others) and is an original research article, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although healthy control participants were included, the inclusion criteria require fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

Event-related fMRI measured responses to infant cries/faces (social stimuli involving affiliation/attachment and perception of others) in 17 healthy nulliparous adult women. Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult group) and is not a review.

Abstract reports resting-state fMRI and meta-analytic/task-related coactivation parcellation but does not state that participants performed an in-scanner social task. Although social cognition is discussed functionally, the abstract lacks clear evidence of a social task with healthy adults. Insufficient information to determine eligibility — include for full-text review.

This article is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies) rather than an original fMRI study with participant data. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The study used magnetoencephalography (MEG) rather than functional MRI. The meta-analysis specifically requires fMRI studies; abstract gives no fMRI data. Although participants are healthy adults, imaging modality exclusion is clear from abstract.

Task-state fMRI examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of self). However abstract does not specify that the task explicitly involved social/self-referential stimuli nor the ages of healthy controls (may be older than 65). Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition/perception and understanding of others) in human participants; reports task-based activation in canonical ToM regions. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original research article (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract lacks details on whether fMRI was task-based during social processing and whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Title indicates social cognition and DMN connectivity (likely fMRI), but information is insufficient to determine inclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm task vs. resting-state and presence of healthy adult participants.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and focused on individuals with autism spectrum disorder; the abstract does not report data from a healthy adult control group aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the task-based social-processing and healthy-participant inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=25). Task is social-related; participants are adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study investigating gesture planning/execution (social communication) with both schizophrenia patients and a healthy control group matched for age and demographics. Task assesses social action/communication relevant to review. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants investigating social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking). Fits review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI and meta-analytic connectivity (MACM) / structural covariance rather than a task-based fMRI of participants performing social-related tasks. No evidence in abstract of an experiment with healthy adults performing social tasks, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social processing fMRI.

Abstract reports fMRI connectivity in autism spectrum disorder and links to clinical severity; it does not describe a social-related task nor a healthy adult participant group (17–65). Does not meet review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of perspective-taking during self- and other-referential processing (social cognition). Includes a healthy adult control group (24 typically developed adults). Meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract reports hyperscanning fMRI of joint attention, a social cognitive task aligning with the review objective. It is not a review/meta-analysis. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants (17–65).

fMRI study of cognitive empathy (a social-related task) conducted during scanning; includes a healthy control group (n=24) alongside schizophrenia patients. Adult sample implied; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of self-referential (social-related) processing, matching the review topic. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Abstract studies amygdala responses to emotional faces (a social-perception task) suggesting functional imaging, but does not explicitly state fMRI or whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient abstract detail to confirm eligibility — include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social processing (integration of facial emotion and eye-gaze) in healthy adults. Includes a healthy younger participant group aged 17–27 (within required 17–65 range), satisfying inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than a task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Although healthy control participants were included and social measures were assessed behaviorally, no fMRI social task was performed, so it does not meet the criterion of a task-based social-related fMRI study.

Study sample comprises children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (and likely age-matched controls), not healthy adults aged 17–65. The review requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (17–65); criterion not met based on abstract.

Abstract reports fMRI functional connectivity related to autistic/social traits in neurotypical adults but does not specify a task-based social paradigm. Because it’s unclear whether scans were task-based vs. resting-state, include for full-text review to determine if a social-related task was performed.

fMRI study of fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) including a matched healthy adult control group (ages consistent with adults). Task probes social brain areas; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract addresses oxytocin modulation of socially relevant cue processing in the human VTA, implying social processing. However the abstract does not explicitly state that a functional MRI task was used or provide participant ages/health. Insufficient methodological detail — include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task and healthy adult sample.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of facial emotion processing (a social-related task). It studies individuals at clinical risk for psychosis, but the abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task) and did not report any social-related task or measures of social behavior. Although healthy controls were included, the review requires task-based fMRI of social processing, so this study does not meet inclusion criteria.
Resting-state fMRI in adolescent early-onset schizophrenia; no social-task paradigm and participants are adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Fails primary inclusion criteria.
fMRI study of facial emotion perception (a social processing task) with both women with MDD and a healthy control group. Healthy adult participants included; meets inclusion criteria.

Study samples pediatric/adolescent participants with social anxiety rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract indicates clinical adolescent groups (pediatric social anxiety) and does not report a healthy adult sample; thus it does not meet the age/participant criteria for inclusion.

Abstract does not specify methods or participant details, but title/aim indicate neural mechanisms of oxytocin on social stimuli—likely an fMRI study of social processing. Given insufficient methodological detail in the abstract to confirm fMRI and sample, include for full-text review to verify that a functional MRI task was used with healthy adults.

The study investigates phonological short-term memory and visuomotor processing of sign language (letters vs. fingerspelling), not social-related processing. The task is a memory span of nonsense syllables rather than social communication, affiliation, or perception/understanding of others. Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for a social-related fMRI task.

Abstract reports fMRI data using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (a social Theory of Mind task) in a non-clinical cohort, matching the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Although structural analyses were performed on stroke patients, the presence of a healthy fMRI group warrants inclusion for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm probing social-related processing. Although it reports prediction of social cognition scores, no social task was performed during scanning, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI social task.

Resting-state and diffusion imaging study of visuospatial working memory in adolescents (including ASD); no social-processing task and participants are adolescents, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in adolescents with autism (clinical sample), not an fMRI task-based study of social processing in healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the review’s population or task-based inclusion criteria.

Primary data fMRI study examining neural responses to famous people and abstract social words (social concepts), across modalities. Tasks assess social-related processing (knowledge about others/social concepts). Likely conducted in healthy adult participants and not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

The study used an fMRI precision visuomotor (sensorimotor) task in individuals with ASD; it does not assess social-related processing and does not report a healthy adult group aged 17–65. Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria.
fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in 109 healthy adult volunteers. Meets inclusion: social-related task, healthy adults within 17–65. Not a review.

Primary data fMRI study of social cognition (visual perspective-taking/understanding others) in humans; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults (typical cognitive neuroscience sample). Meets inclusion criteria—include for full-text review to confirm exact ages and participant health status.

Study uses fMRI to investigate emotional processing (relevant to social cognition), but the abstract does not state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine inclusion based on abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. The meta-analysis requires fMRI during performance of a social-related task; therefore this study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports BOLD functional data focused on the face-processing network in healthy young adults, which is relevant to social processing (facial perception). However, it does not specify whether fMRI was task-based or resting-state; include for full-text review to confirm task-based social paradigm.

fMRI study in 20 adult participants performing observation and imitation of communicative (social) vs non-social gestures, directly addressing social communication processing. No clinical population indicated; meets inclusion criteria for healthy adults performing a social-related task.
Resting-state fMRI in youth aged 8–15 (not adults 17–65) and no social-related task or social processing — does not meet age or task criteria.

Study uses fMRI to investigate social context processing (faces) and includes a group of typically developing (healthy) participants. However, participants are described as 'boys' with no ages reported; inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Age information is insufficient in the abstract to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and other details.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in youth with autism rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, and participants are clinical youth (ASD), not healthy adults aged 17–65; does not meet inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes a review of brain-imaging studies (systematic/narrative review) rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

Abstract describes social-emotional approach–avoidance control in healthy participants but does not specify that functional MRI was used. Insufficient information to determine imaging modality—include for full-text review to confirm whether an fMRI social task was performed.

Abstract mentions social interactive deficits in borderline personality disorder but does not specify use of fMRI or inclusion of healthy control participants. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm task-based fMRI and presence of healthy adults (17–65).

Study used fMRI during a social cognition task (inferring others' emotions/beliefs) and included a group of typically developing (healthy) participants. The abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so full-text review is needed to confirm age eligibility.
Resting-state fMRI study focused on autism spectrum disorder; no task-based social processing paradigm described. Does not meet criterion requiring an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: The sample consists of adolescents (age 13–18) with no separate healthy adult (17–65) group reported. Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social processing and reports group-level whole-brain univariate results, it fails the eligibility criterion requiring at least one healthy adult participant group. No adult-only subgroup analyses or separable adult results are provided, so the study cannot be generalized to a healthy adult population and must be excluded.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study probing social cognition (listening to film excerpts and inferring characters’ mental states). It includes a healthy adult sample (HC-S1, n=28; ages within 18–65) reported separately from the clinical group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps and contrasts for the healthy controls (INT>HIN), with FWE-corrected voxelwise results, tables of cluster coordinates, and figures illustrating the HC activation map. The study therefore provides whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked data generalizable to healthy adults and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes within-group healthy results).

The study uses fMRI with social tasks and includes a healthy control group (ages 50–60), but the paper does not report a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map clearly identified as arising from the healthy/control group alone. Reported whole-brain maps are either for the combined sample (“across the whole group”) or present between-group contrasts and ROI-focused results; supplemental whole-brain tables are group-difference maps. Therefore it fails the requirement that an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect be reported separately. Other inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult sample within 17–65) are met, but the absence of a control-group whole-brain map mandates exclusion under the protocol.

While this is an fMRI study of social processes in a healthy adult sample (n=20) with multiple relevant contrasts (ToM, faces, biological motion, voice, language), the group-level statistical analyses reported in the paper were restricted to a bilateral STS mask (second-level analyses limited to STS voxels). The inclusion criteria require at least one univariate, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the published group results are presented only within a restricted STS ROI (not an unmasked whole-brain group map), the study does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing and includes a healthy adult control group (24 HCs, ages 19–36), the paper does not report any whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Reported whole-brain results are primarily between-group contrasts (BPD > HC in STS) or ROI-based results (amygdala interaction), and group-specific regression effects were significant only in the BPD group (no suprathreshold HC whole-brain maps were reported). Because the inclusion criterion requires at least one healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map (univariate/voxelwise) generalizable to healthy adults, this study does not meet all inclusion criteria and should be excluded.

Although this study uses fMRI during a social interaction task in healthy adult participants, the full text reports ROI-based univariate analyses (MANOVA of averaged ROI betas) and task-based connectivity (gPPI) within a predefined subcortical network. The paper does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps for the healthy/control group; the authors describe that voxelwise GLM analyses were done previously in other publications using the same dataset, but those whole-brain maps are not reported here. Because the review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one whole-brain, task-evoked univariate map from the healthy group, and studies reporting only ROI or connectivity results without whole-brain task maps must be excluded, this paper should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-cognitive task (face processing, emotion recognition, affective theory-of-mind). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=18; male adults in the typical adult age range) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy/control group (coordinates and statistical thresholds are provided for activations in STS, inferior frontal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, and amygdala), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and presents generalizable healthy-group task effects, so it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social decision-making in healthy adult participants (neuroimaging cohort: n=62 after exclusions; ages 18–53). The task probes social influence/processing and the authors report group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate GLM analyses (random-effects), corrected statistical maps (thresholded p<.001, extent), and provide results on NeuroVault. Analyses include task-evoked regressors related to social information and conflict between sources. The sample and reported whole-brain task activations satisfy the review inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria (ROIs-only, resting-state-only, or clinical-only) are violated.

This paper is a narrative synthesis of a program of fMRI studies (review-style), summarizing and adapting results from multiple prior empirical publications rather than reporting new original whole-brain group-level task activation maps for a healthy adult sample. While figures and results from earlier studies of healthy adults are described/adapted, the article itself does not present novel, primary whole-brain univariate task maps that are clearly identified as new, generalizable healthy-adult group-level findings. It therefore does not meet the inclusion requirement for original empirical fMRI data (healthy adults) with a whole-brain task-evoked map reported in this paper. Additionally, the article mixes ages and clinical groups (children, autism) and focuses on developmental synthesis rather than reporting a separable healthy adult whole-brain result.

This empirical study used task-based fMRI (faces versus houses) in a sample of healthy adult undergraduates (N=22 scanned; mean age 18.9 within the 17–65 range). Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses were conducted (second-level GLM) and report significant suprathreshold clusters in bilateral fusiform gyrus and right inferior frontal gyrus. Table 2 provides MNI coordinates, T-scores, and cluster sizes; results are described as group-level activation (p = 0.05, FWE corrected). The task probes social perception (face processing), which maps to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’ No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the article meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results in healthy adults and should be included.

Although this fMRI study uses a social task (Cyberball) in healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain, task-evoked activation maps, the sample includes a clinical subgroup (9 participants meeting criteria for SAD) and the paper does not report a separate group-level whole-brain activation map or clearly-identified analyses restricted to the healthy/control subgroup. The review’s inclusion rules require that studies including clinical groups must report results for the healthy group separately. Therefore the study fails the criterion requiring a clearly-identified healthy-group whole-brain task effect and must be excluded.

While this is an fMRI study of a social task (Socio-emotional Preferential Task) and includes a healthy adult control group (HC, n=13; ages within 17–65), the full text does not present an unambiguous, whole-brain, group-level univariate activation map or contrast that is clearly and solely identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. Reported whole-brain results focus on group effects (HC > SZ), Drug × Group interactions, and combined-sample task effects; the paper provides extracted parameter estimates and between-group contrasts but does not report an unmasked, within-group healthy-control task activation map (e.g., HC main effect or HC-specific within-group contrast) in the main text or figures in a way that meets the inclusion requirement. Therefore it fails the “whole-brain evidence” inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (processing agentic and communal trait words) in healthy adults (N=42, age 18–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (contrasts: agency vs fixation, communion vs fixation, conjunctions, and direct comparisons) using SPM8 with AlphaSim cluster correction and tables/figures of activation coordinates. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are reported for the healthy/control sample. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of dynamic social gesture processing in a sample of healthy young adults (N=20, mean age 21.4) using a social-related task (social vs nonsocial gestures), matching the review’s social-processing constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (cluster-corrected maps, tables of coordinates, and figures) clearly from the healthy/control group. Although the sample range includes one participant just under 17 (16.9), the analyzed group is a general healthy adult sample and results are reported at the group level. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain univariate results); no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of live social interaction (reciprocal imitation) in healthy adult participants (23 right-handed females, ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (imitating, being imitated, observation vs rest) with corrected statistics (FWE p<0.05) and tables/figures of activation coordinates (Table 1, Fig. 3), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although the paper also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally provides the required univariate whole-brain maps for the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of self–other (social) processing that reports within-group whole‑brain univariate activation maps for the typically developing (healthy) control group (TD) (e.g., Self>Letter contrasts with tables/coordinates and figures). The sample includes a healthy control group of adults (age range includes participants within 17–65; group-level results are reported separately from the ASD group). The task probes perception/understanding of self and others, a social cognition construct. Whole‑brain voxelwise results for the healthy/control group are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Although the study also includes an ASD group and a few younger participants (some as young as 16), the TD whole‑group task activation is reported separately and meets the inclusion criteria for whole‑brain, task‑evoked data in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=29, ages 18–27). The task manipulates perceived live versus recorded speech—clearly a social-communication/understanding-of-others paradigm. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (Live > Social; Social > Standard) thresholded and cluster-corrected, with regions/tables/figures described, not limited to ROIs. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy sample are reported. The study does not fall into exclusion categories (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, not between-group-only, and is empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (Animated Triangles Task) that includes a matched healthy adult control group (mean age ~23.6). The paper reports within-group, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy/control group (intentional > random movement), with cluster-corrected whole-brain results (regions listed: pSTS, temporal gyrus, occipital cortex, inferior frontal cortex) and references to group activations in supplementary materials. The healthy-group results are reported separately from patient-group contrasts and are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are within the 17–65 adult range. Therefore it meets all stated inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria. Empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=51; ages mean 22.5, right-handed) using a social task: passive observation of dynamic facial expressions (anger, happiness) vs dynamic mosaic controls. Reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses with FWE-corrected voxelwise thresholds and tables of coordinates and statistical parametric maps for the healthy sample (e.g., expression>mosaic contrast), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only reporting; results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-emotional processing (schadenfreude vs fremdscham) in healthy adult participants (N=34; ages 19–31 and 22–29), within the 17–65 range. The task is social-related (observing others’ social integrity threats) and evoked task-related BOLD responses. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (SIT vs NEUT) with family-wise error correction and tables/figures of activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although some ROI analyses and connectivity analyses are included, whole-brain univariate task effects for the healthy/control group are clearly reported. The sample consists of healthy males only (not an exclusion), and results for the healthy group are presented. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, patient-only, or inappropriate age range) are violated.

Although the study includes an fMRI component with healthy adult controls, the fMRI paradigm is a low-contrast motion (moving vs static concentric rings) task probing motion-sensitive visual cortex—not a social-related task (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). No task-evoked whole-brain healthy-group activation map is reported for any social or emotion-processing task. While behavioral face-emotion recognition was measured and correlated with visual measures, there is no fMRI contrast of social/emotional processing in the healthy group to satisfy the review’s inclusion criteria. Therefore it does not meet the meta-analysis objective.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=28, ages 30–50) that explicitly manipulates self-referentiality and social content during a task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (main effects, conjunctions, and direct contrasts) with corrected statistical thresholds (FDR p<0.05, cluster extent) and tables/figures of results in MNI space. The task probes social-related processing (implicit perception of humans/social stimuli and self/other judgments), which is within the review’s scope. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (n=45 recruited; group analyses reported on subsets aged 19–28). Tasks are social-related (eye-gaze shifts, self-propelling motion, and an implicit mental-inference role-playing task). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (e.g., E−O, S−X; cluster-corrected thresholds) with peak coordinates and tables/figures, clearly from the healthy sample. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Results for healthy adults are presented and generalizable (whole-brain second-level analyses). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing using face targets within a target-detection (oddball) task in healthy adults (N=19; age range 19.3–47.5). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate mixed-effects analyses (cluster-corrected thresholds) with contrasts including face-target > novel and direct comparisons (face > shape), and provides coordinate tables and figures. All inclusion criteria are met (task is social-related, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked maps reported). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing using the Cyberball (ball-toss) paradigm, a social interaction task probing affiliation/belonging. The sample includes healthy adult participants (N=31 analyzed; mean age ~21, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task contrasts (ball-toss high-frequency > normal-frequency contrasted with button-press; voxelwise p<0.005, cluster-level FWE p<0.05) with reported peak coordinates (ventral striatum, precuneus) and beta-value analyses. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses and are generalizable to a healthy adult group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=25; mean age 21.56). The task is explicitly social (social working memory/perspective-taking) and performed during fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (parametric modulation, conjunctions, contrasts) with cluster/voxel thresholds and tables of activated regions/coordinates (e.g., DMPFC, PCC, TPJ, lateral frontoparietal regions). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults within the 17–65 age range. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and presents original empirical data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study reports original task-based fMRI data from 78 healthy adults (age 18–40) performing multiple social-cognition tasks (false belief, animacy/intentional triangles, vocalizations, eyes/face tasks, trustworthiness). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (SPM RFX voxelwise maps, p<0.05 FWE corrected) are presented and peaks listed in supplements. Results for the healthy sample are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. It is empirical task-fMRI work and not ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Sample does not include a healthy adult group (age 17–65). Participants are adolescents aged 14–18 (mean 16.3); no separate analyses of an adult subgroup are reported. Although the study uses task-based fMRI with whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., high positive > neutral feedback) and reports group-level results, the sample falls outside the review’s adult age range. Therefore it fails the sample inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group (17–65). Other criteria (task is social-related, whole-brain results reported) are met, but the age criterion is not, so the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (understanding others’ regret — perception/understanding of others). Samples: two groups of healthy adult participants (Study 1: N=24, age range ~22–31; Study 2: N=24, age range 19–30), all within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked statistical maps (IP–IF and OP–OF contrasts; parametric modulational analyses; conjunctions) using random-effects SPM analyses and reports whole-brain activations (vmPFC, ACC, hippocampus, etc.) thresholded and described in text/figures. Not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not limited to between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI of social processing.

This is an fMRI study conducted entirely in a clinical sample (early-course schizophrenia/schizoaffective patients); no healthy adult control group or healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps are reported. The fMRI paradigm (POP task) targets cognitive control (non-social) rather than social-related processing, and social cognition was assessed only with behavioral measures (MSCEIT), not with a social task fMRI contrast in healthy adults. Therefore it fails the sample criterion (healthy adult group) and the task domain criterion (social-related task), and does not provide the required whole-brain healthy-group task maps.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (representation of social interaction/social context vs self-generation) in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–28). The design manipulates social vs solitary and self vs other during encoding and uses a whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analysis (SPM5) at the group level; results are reported as group contrasts with coordinates, statistical maps, and cluster-corrected thresholds (tables and figures). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked effects generalizable to adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=18, mean age 23.7) using a task that requires social inference with feedback. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (value and prediction-error regressors; conjunctions and direct contrasts) and tables of coordinates for voxelwise results (e.g., VS, vMPFC, TPJ, PCC, fusiform). Participants are within the 17–65 age range and healthy; results are reported for the healthy group. The study includes whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and coordinate tables, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (trauma-exposed veterans without psychiatric diagnoses; ages 18–45), the full text does not report an univariate, whole-brain task activation map (group-level voxelwise contrast) clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The paper emphasizes ROI-based results (using independent masks), group×stimulus interactions, and between-group/interaction whole-brain clusters (PTSD vs control). It does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain within-control-group task effect or map required by the inclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the “whole-brain evidence” inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical fMRI study (Lieberman et al., 2004) that examines self-knowledge — a social cognitive construct (Perception and Understanding of Self). The sample comprises healthy adult participants. The paper reports task-evoked, group-level univariate whole-brain activation results (voxelwise contrasts/figures and tables identifying medial prefrontal and related activations) generalizable to healthy adults rather than limited subgroups. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor is it a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants using a social task (face matching) and reports group-level effects, the reported task-evoked results are restricted to an amygdala region-of-interest (ROI) with ROI-corrected statistics and seed-based functional connectivity. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation map (or whole-brain coordinate table) for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring whole-brain evidence and falls under the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ROI/seed-based results without whole-brain task activation.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 22.3) using the Taylor Aggression Paradigm, a social interaction task probing retaliation/anger (social processing). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses are reported (voxelwise statistical maps, cluster-corrected thresholds) with Talairach coordinates and figures; results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes adults within 17–65). Although sample size is modest, the inclusion criteria do not exclude small-N studies. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical dual‑fMRI hyperscanning study of social interaction (cooperation vs competition, concurrent vs turn‑based) using a social task (pattern game) in healthy adults (N=44, mean age 22.4). The authors report group‑level, whole‑brain, univariate GLM analyses (FEAT/FLAME) with nonparametric permutation correction (randomize), and present cluster coordinates and thresholded group maps for multiple task contrasts (goal, interaction, role, and interactions). The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy participants are reported directly. The paper is not ROI‑only nor connectivity‑only, and provides generalizable healthy‑group task activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study (two separate fMRI experiments) investigating theory-of-mind/social intention processing—clearly a social-related task. The paper reports task-evoked neuroimaging results (activation of the anterior paracingulate cortex) based on group-level analyses in healthy adult participants (J Cogn Neurosci, 2004). It is not a review, ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state study. The reported activations indicate whole-brain univariate task effects generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using film-clip stimuli to probe social motivations (affiliation vs. power) in healthy adult participants (N=17 male students, mean age 23.6), which falls within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (power > control; affiliation > control) and regression analyses linking motive scores to whole-brain activation clusters; coordinates and cluster statistics are provided in tables/figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity/ resting-state methods. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this fMRI study includes a typically developing control group and investigates social conversation, it does not provide a clear, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map reported specifically for a healthy-adult group (analyses focus on functional connectivity/connectedness and group comparisons). In addition, the control sample includes participants younger than 17 (range 15.1–32.0 years) and no separate healthy-adult (17–65) subgroup results are reported. Therefore the paper fails the review’s requirements for (1) a whole-brain, within-healthy-group univariate activation map and (2) an exclusively or separately-reported healthy adult sample in the specified age range. It is thus excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18 analyzed, ages 18–41), investigating social communication (speech act comprehension: Naming vs Requesting). It reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain voxelwise analyses and corrected (FDR p<0.05) contrasts (e.g., Request > Naming) and small-volume-corrected ROIs; whole-brain results are described and thresholded, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and provides task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (‘social working memory’) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 20), meeting the sample criterion (age 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects), parametric contrasts of social load, cluster- and voxel-level thresholds, and lists peak coordinates/figures (Tables S2/S3; Figs. 2–4), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task clearly probes social-related processing (mentalizing, perspective-taking). It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state, nor a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The sample consists of healthy adolescents (mean age 14.24 years, range around 14), not adults. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adult participants aged 17–65; no adult subgroup is reported. Although the study uses task-based fMRI and assesses maternal affiliation (a social construct), the imaging task is a Monetary Incentive Delay reward paradigm (non-social), and the participant age criterion alone disqualifies inclusion. Therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social vs non-social stimuli and includes a healthy adult control group (n=14), the paper's primary reported results are ROI analyses and between-group contrasts. The manuscript does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (only an across-groups main effect and exploratory whole-brain between-group contrasts are reported). Per the meta-analysis inclusion criteria, a healthy-group whole-brain univariate task map is required. Because this criterion is not met, the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (right-handed, neurologically/psychiatrically healthy participants, ages 21–46). Tasks explicitly probe social-related processes (emotion attribution to human, non-human primate, and dog faces; plus an implicit face-viewing one-back), fitting constructs like perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (e.g., Emotion > Expression; Face > Scramble) with cluster-forming voxelwise threshold p<0.001 and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents conjunction and ROI-complementary whole-brain results generalizable to the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, healthy adult group reported).

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related task (trustworthiness judgments of faces). It includes a separate healthy adult control group (n=18; mean age 32.2) within the 17–65 range and reports within-group, whole-brain analyses for the control group (tables and t-maps, thresholding and voxelwise results described). Whole-brain univariate task-evoked effects for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable. The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (face encoding/social cognition) and includes a separate typically-developing healthy control group (n=11; mean age 18.7, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses for the control group (Dm effect; tables of significant clusters with Talairach coordinates and figures), corrected for multiple comparisons. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and task-based (not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social processing (virtual gaze, social interaction vs arbitrary facial movements) in healthy adults (n=18, mean age 25.9). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., SOC>ARB, ARB>SOC, ME>OTHER, OTHER>ME, interactions) using random-effects analysis with voxelwise thresholds, tables of coordinates, and SPM maps. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or patient-group-only results. All inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and whole-brain group-level task activation maps reported) are met, and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports task-based fMRI of a clearly social-related construct (empathy) using an explicit empathy task. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=14) matched to patients and reports within-group (one-sample t-test) whole-brain, voxelwise activation maps for the control group (thresholds and cluster-correction described), with results presented in tables and figures. Although the paper also includes a clinical (schizophrenia) group, the healthy-group whole-brain task effects are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults within the 17–65 age range. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social cognition and reports whole-brain, group-level activation maps for the control group, the sample comprises boys aged 10–18 (mean ages ~12–14) and does not include a healthy adult (age 17–65) group. The inclusion criteria require at least one healthy adult group (17–65) or a separately reported adult subgroup; this study reports only adolescents/children. Therefore it does not meet the sample-age inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study that explicitly investigates social touch (self- vs other-touch), a social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (age range within 17–65) and results for the neurotypical controls are reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., other-touch and self-touch in NC, whole-brain FWE-corrected maps and contrasts described and illustrated), not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Although a clinical ADHD group is included, healthy control whole-brain activation maps are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 18–29) that investigates social cognitive processes (live social interaction and joint attention). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Live > Recorded; Joint Attention > Solo Attention) with corrected voxelwise/cluster results and tables of coordinates. The healthy adult sample is reported separately, and results are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses of social (parent-related) processing, the sample consists of adolescents (N=22; mean age 17.0, range 15.47–18.72). There is no separate healthy adult (age 17–65) group or subgroup-level results reported that are generalizable to healthy adults. Because the participant group includes minors and results are reported for the mixed adolescent sample only, the study does not meet the review’s sample criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group reported separately. Therefore it must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition/empathy in healthy adults (n=16 analysed; mean age 27.8), within the 17–65 range. The task involves viewing social/emotional scenes (emotion vs neutral; two vs one person) and yields group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (EMOT>NEUT; Social relation>Single person) with voxelwise results reported (Talairach coordinates in Table 1) and statistical thresholds (FDR q<0.05, cluster threshold). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social hierarchy processing (a social-related task) in healthy adult participants (n=24 per social experiment; ages reported within 19–43/19–38, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., ‘superior player > inferior player’) with tables of peak coordinates (Tables 1–3), thresholding and FDR correction described, and figures illustrating whole-brain results. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, includes within-group whole-brain task effects). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study reports task-based 7T fMRI during an emotional face discrimination task (social perception/communication), conducted in a sample of 38 healthy adults (mean age 27.5, within 17–65). It presents group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses (FACES>OBJECTS) with SPM results, tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction, and VOI analyses—i.e., clear whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes original empirical fMRI data in healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (affective Theory of Mind, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) including a healthy adult control group (n=22). Whole-brain, voxelwise second-level analyses are reported (main effect of task and group×condition interaction; threshold p<0.005, k=20) with coordinates/tables (Table 3) and supplementary materials that include within-group contrasts (affective ToM > emotion recognition > neutral face processing separately for the groups and group comparisons). Thus it provides univariate, whole-brain task-evoked maps clearly linked to the healthy/control group and meets the sample and reporting requirements of the review. It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results.

Although this is an fMRI study of social/attachment processing with a healthy adult control group (mothers aged within 17–65) and a relevant baby-cry social task, the paper reports results using a priori ROIs with small-volume correction (extended amygdala, NAc, dmPFC). I find no unmasked, whole-brain group-level (healthy/control) task activation maps or voxelwise whole-brain contrasts reported for the healthy group alone. Primary reported effects are ROI-based and between-group contrasts (Depressed vs Healthy). Per the review’s criteria, studies that present only ROI/SVC analyses without whole-brain task activation maps must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition using traffic-awareness campaign videos to elicit socio-cognitive processes (mentalizing/empathy). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (right-handed males aged ~19–30), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (campaign videos vs neutral videos) for groups and within-group analyses (Fig.1 and Tables reporting CV>NV activations), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Results for healthy adult groups are clearly reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social judgment/feedback paradigm and includes a separate healthy adult control group (n=20, mean age 28.15). The paper presents group-level, within-group whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation results for controls (reported in text, figures and cluster-corrected SPM analyses—e.g., ventral striatum, anterior insula, medial prefrontal activations). Whole-brain statistical thresholding and cluster correction methods are described, and within-group/control activations are clearly identified and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, and healthy adult subgroup is analyzed separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy for others’ pain and minimal-group social categorization). Sample: 30 healthy adults, right-handed, ages 18–35, which falls within the required 17–65 range and reports healthy-group results separately. Whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses are presented: SPM8 repeated-measures ANOVA with main effects and interactions reported, FWE-corrected main-effect results and exploratory voxelwise results (tables of cluster coordinates for whole-brain contrasts are provided for pain, condition, and pain×condition). The paper is empirical, reports original fMRI data, and is not limited to ROI/seed/connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (20 men, 20 women; mean age 27.8, no psychiatric/neurological history). The task is social (modified Cyberball combining exclusion and public performance evaluation) addressing social-evaluative processing and mentalizing. Imaging used whole-brain, group-level random-effects GLM analyses; results reported as voxelwise contrasts with FWE correction (p<.05) and MNI coordinates in tables and figures (e.g., Ex>In, PG EX>FG EX). The paper therefore provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for a healthy adult group and meets all inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social decision-making (modified prisoner's dilemma) in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 23–38). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., conjunction of task>control, COMP>COOP and COOP>COMP) with cluster-level correction and tables/coordinates in MNI space. Although additional connectivity analyses are included, the study provides unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group activation maps (coordinates and SPM results), meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

Although the study is an fMRI experiment with healthy adult controls and uses a social-affective (empathic fear) task, it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group. The analyses focus on network cohesion indices (NCI), dynamic functional connectivity within a priori networks (ES and ToM), and ROI-based/network-level comparisons and classifications. No unmasked, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map or coordinate table for a healthy-group main effect is presented that would meet the review’s whole-brain evidence requirement. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy-group whole-brain univariate activation map; exclusion per criteria for studies reporting only ROI/connectivity analyses.

Task-based fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed; mean age 21). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., CC vs. other outcomes; Gain vs. Loss; Outcome×Context interaction) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are included, whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No clinical/special groups confound the healthy sample, and participants are within the 17–65 age range. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20 analyzed; mean age 23.4) investigating social processing (group membership and emotion). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (voxelwise threshold P<0.001 and cluster-level FWE correction P<0.05) with reported activation peaks and coordinates (Table 1; mPFC, STS/TPJ, superior frontal gyrus). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although the study combines EEG with fMRI, it includes standard whole-brain task-evoked BOLD contrasts and coordinates, satisfying the inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy sample) are met.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=31, males age 19–32) that directly examines social/prosocial learning (learning to benefit another person) using a well-defined social-related task. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (e.g., Tables S1–S4 and whole-brain FWE-corrected results; contrasts and statistical parametric maps are presented), not ROI-only or resting-state analyses. Results for the healthy control group are reported and generalizable within the adult range (17–65). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study using an explicit social task (reappraisal of angry faces). Sample: 60 healthy adults (age range 18–57), so within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Observe-angry > Observe-neutral; Observe-angry > Increase+Decrease; Decrease > Observe-angry) with tables of peak MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected cluster thresholds (whole-brain results reported and interpreted). Although resting-state analyses are also included, task-based whole-brain univariate maps for the healthy group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not exclusively connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are reported). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, mean age 26.5, within 17–65) using a social-related task (imagining triadic social interactions versus self/other/iron controls). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., triad>iron, conjunction triad∩self∩other, triad>(self&other)) with peak coordinates and family-wise-error-corrected statistics, and includes tables/figures of results. Both univariate activation maps and conjunction/contrast results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, not between-group-only, and participants are in the eligible age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social reward and reports whole-brain task contrasts, the sample is a mixed clinical/community late-adolescent sample (ages 18–21) with 9 participants meeting current MDD and analyses reported across the entire mixed sample and via regressions on symptom/anhedonia severity. The paper does not report a separate group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map that is clearly identified as coming from a healthy adult/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group with whole-brain task-evoked maps reported separately. Additionally, the authors treat participants as late adolescents rather than a healthy adult control group. For these reasons the study should be excluded.

Although the study uses task-evoked fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=36; ages 20–35) and investigates vocal emotional processing (a social-communication-related paradigm), it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps or contrasts. The analyses are ROI-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical network measures (Power-264 atlas, interregional FC, OMST filtering) rather than voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain task-evoked univariate map for the healthy group.

While this study uses fMRI with a social task (dynamic fearful faces) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=19, ages within 17–65), the full text does not present a clear, unmasked whole‑brain, within‑group task activation map or one‑sample group-level face>place statistical map explicitly for the healthy control group. The paper mainly reports (1) a combined/all‑participants face>place map and (2) between‑group contrasts (HC > RTLE, HC > LTLE). Because the review’s inclusion criteria require a healthy‑group whole‑brain univariate task map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (not only between‑group contrasts), this study does not meet the required reporting and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=37 male adults, mean age 22.9) using a social-role judgment task (Self, Friend, Celebrity) that probes Perception and Understanding of Self and Others. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (Self vs. Celebrity; Friend vs. Celebrity) with voxelwise statistics and FDR correction and provides peak coordinates and cluster sizes. Although additional connectivity (gPPI) analyses are included, the study clearly presents univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy sample, satisfying the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of live social interaction in healthy adults (N=21, mean age 25.8). The task is social (live bidirectional conversations with a human vs conversational robot). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (SPM12; main effects and contrasts HHI vs HRI and HRI vs HHI) with FDR-corrected cluster-level inference; results/maps are available (NeuroVault/OpenNeuro). It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or non-empirical analyses. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study using a social cognition task (approachability judgments from faces). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=24, mean age ≈35) and reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation for the healthy participants (multiple whole-brain clusters with peak coordinates and cluster-corrected P values are provided in the text/figures). Although the study also includes a clinical schizophrenia group, the healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical original fMRI data and not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study (N=178 healthy adults, mean age 40.9 within 17–65) employing a social-cognition task (EmpaToM) that manipulates empathy and Theory-of-Mind. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (emotional vs neutral videos for empathy; ToM vs non-ToM questions/videos) with activation maps and tables of coordinates and random-effects analyses. Although additional connectivity/DCM and resting-state analyses are reported, they are supplementary to clear task-evoked whole-brain results. The sample is healthy adults and results are reported for the healthy/control group. The study is empirical (not a review) and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or out-of-range participants. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing: subjects learned facts about people (versus buildings and hammers) and the paper explicitly tests person-selective responses. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=12; ages 20–32) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (conjunction contrasts, cluster-size correction, Talairach-space maps) identifying person-selective clusters in the anterior temporal lobes and other social cognition regions; results are described as whole-brain statistical maps and ROI/cluster results. Although functional connectivity is also reported, the paper includes task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=37, mean age 20.8) investigating imitation/‘‘urge to imitate,’’ which falls under social processing (perception/understanding of others; social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (parametric modulation, one-sample t-tests, cluster-corrected thresholds) and provides coordinates/brain maps of significant activations (Urge-related SMA and MCC) as well as PPI connectivity results. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and the healthy adult results are reported separately.
