The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and is empirical with original fMRI data. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI studies in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (affiliation vs. isolation) using task-evoked BOLD fMRI. It includes a healthy younger adult group (mean age 20.75, within the 17–65 range) and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate voxelwise analyses with coordinates and tables (see Tables 2–4 and conjunction/contrast results). Although an older group (>65) is also included, results for the healthy younger adults are analyzed and reported separately via conjunctions and contrasts, and whole-brain task effects for the healthy group are presented. The study does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity analyses and provides whole-brain task activation maps/generalizable group results, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study employing a social incentive delay task (social and monetary conditions) in a cohort of healthy adults (N=63; ages ~20–36). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation results (tables and figures) including FWE-corrected whole-brain and ROI-corrected contrasts for social>monetary and monetary>social during anticipation and outcome phases. Healthy participant results are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses and includes coordinate tables/whole-brain maps, meeting all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports original fMRI data in a sample of 20 healthy adult participants performing cross-modal face–voice perception tasks (socially relevant perception/communication). The abstract and methods describe group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts using multiple statistical criteria (super-additive, max, mean) that identified brain regions (e.g., left hippocampus, occipital and temporal cortices) rather than ROI-only results. Although a PPI connectivity analysis is reported, it is supplemental to whole-brain task-evoked findings. The paper is empirical, involves healthy adults within the target age range, and provides group-level voxelwise task activation results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20 young adults) who viewed dynamic social interaction videos during scanning. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activation with statistical results (e.g., significant right>left activation in amygdaloid complex, inferior frontal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, temporal gyri; p<0.0001), indicating whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants fall within the adult age range (17–65). The reported effects are within the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-scene/person interaction perception in healthy adults (N=12; ages 21–31). The task involves social-related processing (judging sex while viewing congruent/incongruent/non-interacting dyads) and the manuscript reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (voxelwise threshold p<.001, cluster-based p<.05) with peak coordinates and tables/figures (e.g., Table 3, whole-brain contrasts incongruent>congruent, etc.). Results for the healthy adult sample are reported directly (not limited to a subgroup), and analyses include both whole-brain and ROI/MVPA but are not ROI-only. The study does not fall under any exclusion criteria (no connectivity-only, no patient-only sample, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task-based fMRI with social stimuli (faces and gaze) in healthy adult men (age range within 17–65). It reports group-level task-evoked activation differences (direct vs averted gaze) in regions including amygdala, fusiform gyrus, and anterior superior temporal cortex, and reports functional connectivity findings; these are empirical, voxelwise group results (not ROI-only or resting-state-only), and results are reported for healthy control groups (normal fear scorers) and a matched healthy subgroup (low fear scorers). Thus it meets the review’s fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-activation reporting criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=25, mean age ~25) using task-based imaging of faces with manipulated facial color — a social-perception/relevant social communication construct (perception/understanding of others: emotion/health cues). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (natural-colored faces vs. scrambled images) with voxelwise results and cluster coordinates (Table 1, group-level maps at P<1e-3 uncorrected), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for healthy participants are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment). Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (ages within 17–65), reported separately. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain random-effects analyses (contrasts G–N, E–N, E–G, G–E) with tables of peak coordinates and figures; results are not limited to ROIs and are task-evoked (block-design emotional judgment). It is empirical fMRI data from healthy adults and meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (whole-brain univariate maps, healthy adult group). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply.

This fMRI study uses a social-processing task (Frith-Happé animations) and includes a healthy adult control group (NT; n=23, ages 19–56). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (one-sample t-tests and whole-brain results for each group, with supplementary whole-brain results referenced) clearly identified for the healthy/control group. The healthy sample falls within the 17–65 age range. The study also provides activation maps and coordinate-based results for within-group contrasts, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is empirical, task-based fMRI (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages ~19–33). It uses a social interactive task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) vs a non-social control, and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (PD > Gamble) with tables of activation coordinates and voxelwise thresholding (random-effects analysis). Whole-brain connectivity and Granger analyses supplement but do not replace the univariate whole-brain results. Participants are healthy adults and results for this group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study does not include a healthy adult control group generalizable to the healthy population: both comparison groups are incarcerated offenders (psychotic and nonpsychotic), i.e., a forensic/special sample rather than a healthy community adult sample. Additionally, the primary neuroimaging results are ICA-based connectivity/component analyses and between-group contrasts; the paper does not report a within-group, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map clearly identified as coming from a healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the sample and whole-brain evidence inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social reflection: self- and other-judgments) in a healthy adult sample (n=22; ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (SR > AL, S > AL, O > AL) with cortical surface maps, cluster-corrected results and Talairach coordinates (Tables/Figures). Although resting-state and ROI analyses are also included, whole-brain univariate task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly reported, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations — Perception/Understanding of Self). Sample: healthy adults (n=31, age range 19–24, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and regression analyses with voxelwise results (e.g., SC vs SA, OA vs OC, SA vs Fixation) and provides coordinate tables and statistical thresholds (voxel-wise p<0.001, cluster-level FWE p<0.05) and figures. Although additional PPI connectivity analyses are included, the study also clearly reports univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=14; ages 18–30) that explicitly probes a social cognitive process (trustworthiness evaluation of faces). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate task-evoked analyses with whole-brain statistical parametric maps and tables of coordinates (including small-volume corrected results in regions of interest and whole-brain contrasts), clearly derived from the healthy/control sample. The design, methods, and outcomes meet the review’s inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and group-level whole-brain univariate results). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study should be included.

Although this study used task fMRI in healthy adult dyads during a social joint-attention paradigm, its primary reported results are multivariate ICA components and cross-brain coupling analyses (hyperscanning connectivity). The paper does not present a conventional group-level, univariate voxelwise task activation map (e.g., INT>NoINT) for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Results are reported as ICA spatial components and component-wise temporal associations/couplings rather than standard whole-brain task-evoked GLM maps or coordinate tables of task activations. According to the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must report at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked map for the healthy group; because this is not clearly provided, the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self, friend, unfamiliar face/name recognition). Sample: healthy adults aged 18–24 (35 subjects after exclusions). Whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level random-effects analyses are reported (SPM5; one-sample t-tests) with tables of coordinates and figures (Tables 2–4, Figs. 1–3). The task and contrasts address perception/understanding of self and others (social cognition). The paper is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state–only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 29.4). The task explicitly probes social perception/understanding (classification of social interaction vs non-social point-light displays). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrast maps (SI > NSI) with multiple-comparison correction (FDR p<0.05) and cluster reporting, listing activated regions and providing figures/tables. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only constraints apply. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=41 included in fMRI analyses; age mean ~22, within 17–65). The task is explicitly social-affective (social-affective mimicry task) addressing affiliation-related processes and perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Incongruent > Congruent; masked contrasts for Happy vs Angry and Out-group vs In-group) with cluster-level correction and tables of MNI coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of audiovisual social signal perception in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 26.6). The task involves social-communication/perception constructs (emotional expressions from voice and face) during task-evoked scanning. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (conjunction AV > A AND AV > V) with tables of coordinates, voxelwise analyses, and random-effects inference; voice- and face-sensitivity experiments and voxelwise correlations are also reported. Although small-volume correction was used for ROIs, whole-brain conjunction/voxelwise results and coordinate tables are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses fMRI with a social-related task (dynamic face processing) and includes a healthy adult control group (N=21, ages within 17–65), the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. The reported results focus on between-group contrasts (patients vs controls) and clusters showing patient>control or patient<control effects; no unmasked/within-control whole-brain main-effect maps or tables of healthy-group voxelwise activations are provided. Therefore it fails the required whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–32). Task involved reading a narrative with online suspense ratings; authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (parametric suspense regressor) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables/figures of activation coordinates. Reported activations include medial frontal cortex and temporo-parietal junction, interpreted as mentalizing/theory-of-mind (perception/understanding of others), which falls within the review’s social-related constructs. Whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state, healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of joint attention (a social cognitive process) in healthy adult participants (n=65; mean age 22.4 years, right-handed, no neurological/psychiatric history). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (GLM contrasts such as IJA, RJA, dIJA, dRJA, CTRL) with second-level random-effects results, cluster-level FWE correction, and anatomical labeling; whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables are described. The task is clearly social (joint attention/eye contact) and the results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (impression formation/updating) in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–45). The task is social (faces paired with valenced behaviors) and uses BOLD fMRI. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (interaction of trial number and consistency; L2>F3 contrasts within target types) with thresholding and cluster correction, and presents results in tables/figures/supplementary materials that reflect healthy-group task-evoked activations. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is a hyperscanning fMRI study of real-time mutual eye contact—a social communication task—conducted in healthy adult participants (mean age ~21.7, N=30 for fMRI analyses), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) with voxelwise/statistical maps and corrected inference (SPM and SnPM), and presents cluster coordinates/figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or resting-state/seed-only connectivity; whole-brain activation results for the healthy sample are clearly described and generalizable. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI or non-empirical work, out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of political/social cognition (processing of politicians’ faces/names using IAT) in healthy adults (N=24 analyzed; ages 21–40). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM2), with subtraction contrasts, conjunctions, correlational analyses, FDR and cluster-threshold corrections, and tables/figures of coordinates. Results for the healthy/control sample are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes within-group whole-brain task effects, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social communication (co-speech gesture processing) in healthy adults (20 right-handed native German participants, age 22–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., low_ID > high_ID; speech > gestures+speech; gestures+speech > speech; interaction) with MNI coordinates, cluster extents, and statistical thresholds (cluster-corrected). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria.

Although the study includes a healthy control group (N=22) and uses fMRI during social perception, the full text reports mainly seed-based/background functional interaction (connectivity) analyses and between-group contrasts. It does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map clearly identified for the healthy/control group; task-related BOLD responses were regressed out and task-evoked activation maps for the healthy group are not reported in this paper (they reference an earlier publication for task activation). Per the inclusion criteria, a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map is required. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and evaluation of different laughter types—social communication and perception of others). Participants: 18 healthy native German-speaking adults (mean age 26), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate, task-evoked whole-brain analyses (voxel-wise contrasts and conjunctions) with tables of peak coordinates and whole-brain results (see Tables 1–3 and corresponding figures), not limited to ROIs. Analyses and results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper).

This is an fMRI study of social processing (learning about others’ generosity) in healthy adults (final N=26, ages 19–37). The task is social-related and participants were scanned performing the task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results (main effects and parametric contrasts, with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected statistical maps), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses and results for the healthy adult group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range participants) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study includes healthy adult control participants and uses fMRI with social-emotion tasks, but the primary reported results are multivariate (MVPA/ROI and searchlight classification) rather than univariate activation maps. The manuscript does not clearly present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (e.g., task>rest or within-group contrast) for the healthy/control group in the main text; univariate analyses are only briefly mentioned as ‘no group difference’ with details deferred to supplementary material or prior reports. Because the review requires an explicit whole-brain univariate task activation map for the healthy adult group that is clearly reported, this paper does not meet the whole-brain univariate evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (N=29, ages 18–24). The task is explicitly social/communicative (talking to familiar vs unfamiliar actors) and probes social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (e.g., communication vs description, communication vs control; familiar vs unfamiliar) with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables of peak coordinates and cluster sizes. Results are reported for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, nor connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (Theory of Mind) using the REMICS task that orthogonally manipulates social vs. physical scenarios and contextual adjustments. Participants: 19 healthy adults aged 20–53 (within 17–65 range). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., SocAdj > PhyConf; Soc > Phy; Adj > Conf) analyzed in SPM8 with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction, and provides coordinates/tables of significant peaks. Analyses are within the healthy control group (no ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting). Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of Theory of Mind/social cognition in healthy adult participants (Studies: N=29, N=10 subset, N=21; ages 19–38). The tasks explicitly probe perception/understanding of others (Why/How and False-Belief/Photo contrasts). The manuscript presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (Why>How, How>Why, Belief>Photo) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of MNI coordinates and peak statistics. Results are reported for healthy/control samples separately. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and contains whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults.

This is an original fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (N=10 right-handed young adults). The task explicitly probes social-related constructs (perception of approaching agents conveying affiliation vs. threat). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise analyses (Angry>Happy and Happy>Angry contrasts) with MNI coordinates, cluster extents, and statistical thresholds described, satisfying the whole-brain univariate map requirement for the healthy/control group. Results for the healthy participants are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 adult range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social perception and reports whole-brain group analyses, the sample consists of adolescents (mean ages ≈15.8–17.0; subject age ranges include many participants <17). There is no separate healthy adult (age 17–65) group reported or analyzed independently. The control group is age-matched adolescents rather than adults, so the healthy-group results are not generalizable to the adult population targeted by the meta-analysis. Therefore the study fails the sample-age inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (14 males, 14 females; ages 20–24). The task is social (processing of positive/negative social reputation), and the paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts and cluster results (e.g., positive vs. neutral, negative vs. neutral; thresholding and MNI coordinates provided in Table 1 and figures). Results are reported for the healthy group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (eye contact and mimicry), using a task that probes social communication/perception of others. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=20; mean age 23, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Congruent > Catch, Incongruent > Congruent, Direct > Averted, and interaction contrasts) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides coordinate tables and figures. Although DCM connectivity was also performed, the study includes univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (emotion processing and theory-of-mind tasks: BET, FToM, EToM) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=14; mean age 28.4 years, within 17–65). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate contrasts (EMOTION vs GENDER) for each group, with figures and supplementary tables showing healthy/control group activation maps and coordinates (threshold p<0.001, cluster extent). It is not ROI-only, nor resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group task effects are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (friendship/affiliation) in healthy adults (N=28, ages 19–27). The task is social interaction simulation probing interpersonal constructs (empathy, reward). Analyses are whole-brain, group-level, univariate voxelwise contrasts using SPM5 with random-effects, reporting FWE-corrected results and cluster statistics (figures and Table 1 with coordinates/clusters). No ROI-only or connectivity-only limitations; results for the healthy adult group are reported separately. Age range and sample meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study of emotion perception (social communication/perception of others) in healthy adult participants (Study 1: 25 right-handed adults aged 19–24; Study 2: 33 adults), which falls within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (3×3 repeated-measures ANOVA; whole-brain results reported with PFWE<0.05, cluster extent thresholds; tables/figures of activations are provided) in addition to ROI analyses. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathy/self–other representation) in healthy adults (N=22, mean age 23.6). The task manipulates threat directed at self, friends, and strangers (socially relevant conditions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (threat minus safe) and conjunction analyses using FSL (easythresh_conj) with whole-brain thresholds and cluster correction; results are presented as coordinates, figures, and tables. Healthy-group results are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and not a review. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The paper reports task-based whole-brain fMRI results, but only for a clinical PTSD sample (n=13 pre- and post-therapy). It does not include or report a group of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) within this study; healthy-subject maps referenced are from a prior publication and are only used as masks rather than presented as an unmasked, group-level whole-brain healthy-task effect in this paper. Therefore the study fails the sample inclusion criterion (no healthy adult group reported) and the whole-brain healthy-group evidence requirement. It also does not present separable healthy-group voxelwise activation maps suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affiliative/attachment-related social processing in healthy adults (final N=27, mean age 27.3±9 years, within 17–65). The task is social-affiliation imagery (affiliative vs nonaffiliative scenarios) performed during BOLD fMRI. The paper reports group-level, univariate, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (affiliative vs nonaffiliative; valence contrasts) with whole-brain inference (FWE-corrected results) and coordinates/tables and figures of activations. Although some ROI small-volume corrections were used for a priori regions, whole-brain results surviving FWE correction are reported. The healthy/control group results are reported independently (no exclusive focus on clinical groups). The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (observation of cooperative vs affective social interactions) conducted in healthy adult participants (N=36; mean ages ~24–25, right-handed). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (parametric and categorical analyses) with cluster-corrected statistical maps and tables of coordinates identifying activations (e.g., pSTS, SPL, vmPFC), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also includes effective connectivity (DCM) analyses, it provides univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy group, so no exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not clinical-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study in healthy adults (n=20, age range 21–32) probing personal prayer vs control conditions. The task directly addresses social-related processing (personal prayer invoking theory-of-mind/reciprocity). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (interaction and individual condition contrasts; Tables 3–4) thresholded at p<0.05 FDR with MNI/Talairach coordinates. Results for the healthy participant group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Full text is unavailable (Cambridge Core error page) so key information cannot be verified. Although the title indicates a study of affective theory of mind in schizophrenia out-patients and may include healthy controls, the provided content contains no methods, participant details, or results. I cannot confirm that (1) a healthy adult group (age 17–65) is reported separately, nor (2) that the paper reports at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Because at least one inclusion criterion (availability of healthy-group whole-brain activation results) cannot be confirmed, the study must be excluded. If the full text becomes available and shows a clearly reported healthy-group whole-brain task effect, this decision could be revisited.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (trustworthiness judgments/perception and understanding of others) using task-evoked BOLD while participants made face-based trustworthiness judgments and received feedback. It includes a healthy younger adult group (ages 20–33) that falls within the 17–65 inclusion range; results for this healthy group are reported separately and in group-level contrasts. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (ANOVA and whole-brain effects, reported in tables and figures) and significant task-evoked activations (e.g., striatum, dmPFC, precuneus) generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and not limited to connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=34, age 20–28) using a social cognition task (modified false-belief/theory-of-mind paradigm) that probes perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (ROMS vs CTRL) with statistical activation maps and peak coordinates (Table 1, Fig. 2) and describes thresholding procedures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy adult data are reported separately and no exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This paper reports task-based fMRI during a virtual social cognition task and explicitly includes a healthy adult control group (n=14, ages 18–45). The authors present within-group, whole-brain univariate activation contrasts for the healthy/control group (e.g., Emotion [angry+happy] vs Control and Neutral vs Control), with voxelwise results, coordinates, cluster thresholds, tables, and figures describing activation in ACC, IFC, and insula. Thus it fulfills: (1) an fMRI social-related task, (2) a healthy adult sample reported separately, and (3) whole-brain task-evoked group-level maps reported in tables/figures. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=30 White, age 18–29). The task probes social cognition (race perception and subsequent trustworthiness evaluations — perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast images and covariate analyses (e.g., [Black > White] contrasts) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster results (Tables 2–3) and thresholding details, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy control group are reported directly. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and presents generalizable healthy-group task activations, so it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of live verbal social interaction (social communication) in healthy adults (22 right-handed women, mean age 27.2, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (first- and second-level voxel-wise t-tests; cluster-corrected results; tables/figures including Table S2 and whole-brain maps for talking, listening, imagining and inter-individual coupling). Results are univariate task-evoked activation maps clearly reported for the healthy sample. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state only, and does not consist solely of between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of verbal irony (social communication/Theory of Mind) in healthy adult participants (n=20, mean age 22), squarely within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate contrasts (Ironic > Literal) with tables of coordinates, cluster-wise FDR-corrected results, and whole-brain figures—i.e., generalizable healthy-group task activation maps. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and includes original empirical fMRI data in healthy adults. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of gaze processing (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). It includes a neurologically normal control group (n=9; mean age 23.4) and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate activation maps and stereotaxic coordinates for the control group (figures and Table 1 show incongruent>congruent activations in the STS and other regions). The task is social (eye-gaze/intentionality) and whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported. Note one control subject is aged 15.5 (slightly below the 17–65 range), but the control group results are reported separately and are otherwise within the adult range; given the presence of explicit whole-brain healthy-group maps, I include this study.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (12 right-handed males, ages 20–51) that used task-based fMRI during social attribution tasks (internal vs external attributions; self-serving vs non-self-serving attributions). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain SPM analyses with corrected voxelwise results and provides tables of peak coordinates and figures of statistical maps for contrasts of interest (internal>external; self-serving>non-self-serving). Although the primary analyses use fixed-effects models and the sample is small (a caveat noted by authors), whole-brain group activation maps/coordinates from the healthy adult sample are reported, satisfying the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked univariate results in healthy adults. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria; note limited generalizability due to sample size and fixed-effects approach.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social evaluation in healthy participants, the sample spans ages 8.0–22.9 and the reported whole-brain group analyses are age-continuous effects across children, adolescents, and young adults. The paper does not report a separate group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map that is clearly identified as coming solely from a healthy adult group (age 17–65). Inclusion requires either an adult-only healthy group or whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults; here results are reported as age-related effects across a mixed-age sample, so the adult-only effect is not separable. Therefore it fails the sample/whole-brain healthy-adult criterion for inclusion.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with healthy control participants during a social/emotion recognition task and reports whole-brain between-group contrasts (HCs > SZs and SZs > HCs) and ROI amygdala analyses, the full text does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (e.g., HC emotion > baseline or within-group HC contrast). Reported results focus on between-group contrasts and ROI findings; no unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation map or coordinates for a healthy-group main effect are provided. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement that a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map be reported and generalizable to healthy adults.

Although this fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (24 TD adults) and uses a social-interaction task, it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group. The authors explicitly state they focused on an ROI analysis of the anterior rostral MPFC (6 mm sphere) rather than performing whole-brain or connectivity analyses due to signal loss in ventral regions. Only ROI results (and between-group comparisons) are presented. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked map from the healthy adult group.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social cognition (impression formation/violations of social expectations) in healthy adults (n=18 analyzed; ages 19–30). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (incongruent > congruent) with FDR-corrected cluster results and a table of MNI coordinates, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from a healthy adult sample. Although ROIs are also examined, whole-brain results are explicitly reported, and no exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI/only connectivity/only between-group contrasts or non-adult sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

While the study uses fMRI during a social task (direct vs. averted gaze) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age ~30), the paper reports psychophysiological interaction (PPI) seed-based connectivity analyses (SC and LC seeds) rather than univariate whole-brain, task-evoked activation maps for the healthy group. The manuscript focuses on seed-based functional connectivity and between-group connectivity contrasts; although it references whole-brain PPI results in the Supplementary Material, there is no clear report of a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map (main effect or within-group contrast) for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the requirement for reporting at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy group and must be excluded per the review?s inclusion/exclusion criteria.

This paper reports voxel-based morphometry (structural MRI) associations between grey matter volume and proneness to moral sentiments. Although it uses a behavioral moral-sentiment task (VMST) and references prior fMRI work (a subgroup of N=29), the current manuscript does not present group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked fMRI statistical maps for healthy participants. The only fMRI-related data are previously acquired SSC-BOLD peak responses used as covariates/exploratory regressors, not new whole-brain healthy-group activation maps. Therefore it fails the mandatory inclusion criterion requiring task-based whole-brain fMRI results for healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (angry facial expressions during a competitive social interaction) in healthy adults (32 male participants, mean age 23.3). The task is social-related (Taylor Aggression Paradigm with video of opponent) and evokes task-based BOLD responses. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., angry > neutral) with cluster-wise FWE correction and tables/figures of significant whole-brain activations as well as ROI analyses. Results are reported for the healthy participant group separately. It is empirical fMRI data (task-evoked), not resting-state or connectivity-only. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 20.65) that manipulates event-simulation tasks including explicit situational inference and future-prediction; these explicitly engage social-cognitive processes (e.g., theory-of-mind/trait inference, MPFC, TP, PCC activations) and include social vs. non-social condition analyses. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Imp–Con, Exp–Imp, Ftr–Exp) analyzed with SPM8 and corrected cluster thresholds (and peak coordinates), satisfying whole-brain univariate reporting requirements. Participants are within the eligible adult age range and results are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=33, ages 18–21). The task contrasted social vs non-social scenes during task-based fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate results (social>non-social) with FDR-corrected maps and a table of peak coordinates, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state only. Healthy adult participant results are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=50, ages 18–29) performing a social cognition task (labeling briefly presented emotional facial expressions — perception/understanding of others). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (HA>NE, AN>NE, FE>NE) and provides cluster coordinates and tables of significant activations (SPM8, FWE-corrected cluster results), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy sample are reported directly. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and not a connectivity-only or resting-state paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social perception (passive viewing of biological vs. scrambled point-light displays), including a healthy adult group (n=48; ages 20–35). Group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported for adults (biological > scrambled motion), with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables of peak coordinates and figures (e.g., Main effect and Sex×Condition adult contrasts, Table 1, Supplementary Table S1). Results are generalizable to healthy adults and are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. Therefore the paper meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI whole-brain task activation in a social-related paradigm.

This is a task-based fMRI study using a social-related facial affect matching task (Emotion Match vs Shape Match). It includes a healthy adult comparison group (n=12; mean age ~32, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses for the healthy group (within-group one-sample t-tests and coordinate tables/figures for Emotion Match > Shape Match), with whole-brain statistical maps and peak coordinates provided. The study is empirical, not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map generalizable to healthy adults.

Sample consists of adolescents (ages 12–18); the healthy/control group is not a healthy adult sample (meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group age 17–65 generalizable to adults). Although the paper reports whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the control group, the participants are primarily minors and the results are not clearly generalizable to a healthy adult population. Therefore it does not meet the age/sample inclusion criterion.

The study uses task-based fMRI of social processing (explicit facial emotion discrimination and a non-emotional face judgment), includes a healthy adult control group (N=27; mean age ~40, within 17–65), and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation results (within-group and between-group contrasts, tables of coordinates and whole-brain maps/figures). It is not ROI-only and presents generalizable healthy-group task effects. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI studying prosocial/family-related social processing (mentalizing, affiliation/attachment). (2) Sample comprises healthy young adults (N=25, Mage=20.2) within 17–65 and reported as a healthy group. (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) with tables of coordinates and whole-brain analyses, not limited to ROI results. (4) Also reports PPI but not solely connectivity; primary univariate whole-brain activation maps are present and generalizable to the healthy group. Not a review or non-empirical paper. Therefore eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction (pseudo-interactive joke task) conducted in healthy adult participants (n=38; ages 19–29). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., SELF vs OTHER; Group vs No Laughter; action–outcome contingency interaction) with thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction and provides peak coordinates and tables/figures. Although connectivity (PPI) analyses are also reported, the study clearly includes whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy adult sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (causal attribution/mentalizing) in a healthy adult sample (N=20; ages 18–41). It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (self > truth, other > truth, situation > truth), conjunctions and between-condition comparisons, with tables of MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected results. Healthy participants are analyzed as a separate group and results are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper also provides whole-brain analyses (not ROI-only), and does not rely exclusively on connectivity or resting-state methods. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (20 right-handed male drivers, age 20–28) that investigates socio-emotional processing (empathy) during viewing of campaign videos. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (CV > NV) with significance set at p<0.05 FWE-corrected and lists significant clusters/peak coordinates; these whole-brain results are clearly described and used to define ROIs. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy/control group are reported separately. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and is empirical with original fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study (Ultimatum Game) probing social decision-making (cooperation/fairness), fitting the review’s social processing constructs. Sample comprises healthy adult participants (MT n=26, CT n=24; mean ages ~31), within the 17–65 range, and results for the healthy groups are reported separately. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task analyses (e.g., conjunction analysis and parametric regressors with reported MNI coordinates and FDR-corrected statistics for anterior insula and septal region; whole-brain GLM contrasts and tables/figures described). Although ROI and PPI analyses are also presented, they are accompanied by unmasked whole-brain activation maps and coordinate tables. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=35, mean age 29) using a task that probes social processing (face identity and emotional expression—perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects ANCOVA; FDR-corrected maps, Talairach coordinates, and contrasts such as angry vs. neutral/happy and load contrasts), clearly from the healthy sample. Results are not ROI-only and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not resting-state, not ROI-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study using a social-interactive task (modified Taylor competitive reaction-time paradigm) probing social processing (retaliation, observing an opponent’s suffering, empathy). Sample: healthy adult participants (male, mean age 28.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses with voxelwise statistics and tables of MNI coordinates for multiple task contrasts (retaliation, watching opponent, receiving aversive stimuli) that are clearly from the healthy group. It is empirical original data, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and does not restrict results to a narrow subgroup. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (dynamic virtual-reality direct vs averted gaze assessing social cognition/mentalizing). (2) The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=16; mean age ~30.6), and control-group results are reported separately. (3) The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses for the control group (full-factorial and within-group contrasts; whole-brain activation tables and figures are provided showing DMPFC, TPJ, temporal pole, etc.). The manuscript also provides ROI analyses, but these do not preclude inclusion because whole-brain control results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore, include this study in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (10 right-handed male adults) using a humor-appreciation task (viewing funny vs non-funny cartoons), which falls under social-related processing (humor/social communication and perception/understanding). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise results (task contrasts and regression with trait cheerfulness) with coordinate tables and figures (e.g., cluster in right inferior parietal lobule, Talairach coordinates, p-values). Although the sample is small and all-male, it meets the inclusion criteria: healthy adult sample, task-evoked whole-brain group results clearly reported, and relevant to social communication. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of biological-motion perception, a social-perception task (Perception and Understanding of Others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15) reported separately and age-/IQ-matched to patients. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (SPM2) and within-group contrasts (biological motion vs scrambled motion) for the healthy controls, with tables/figures of significant activations (thresholds and cluster sizes reported). Although the study also includes an OCD patient group, healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly provided and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (agency attribution/theory-of-mind using Heider-&-Simmel style animations). Participants are healthy adults (n=12, mean age ~25), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (High>Low and Low>High intentionality) analyzed in SPM2 with reported activation loci (STS, IFG, occipital regions, etc.) and statistical thresholds (p<0.001 uncorrected). Whole-brain results are described in the text and shown in figures/tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult whole-brain task activation). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While this is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy young and older adults (fits the review objective), the provided full-text/abstract does not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map that is explicitly identified as coming from the healthy adult group. The abstract reports between-group differences (e.g., young > older activity in medial prefrontal cortex) and descriptions of region involvement, but does not confirm unmasked, within-healthy-group whole-brain results or coordinate tables/figures for the healthy (young) group. Also, participant ages for the older group likely exceed the 17–65 inclusion range, and the text does not show separate whole-brain results confined to a healthy 17–65 subgroup. Because criterion requiring explicit whole-brain healthy-group task maps is not verifiable from the provided content, I must exclude the study. Recommend retrieval of the full article PDF to re-assess if voxelwise healthy-group maps/coordinates are reported.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of eye gaze and face identity) in healthy adults (N=9, mean age 24, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (face vs scrambled; attention to identity vs gaze; averted vs direct gaze), includes voxelwise significance thresholds and stereotaxic coordinates (Table 1) and figures of activations (STS, LFG, IOG, IPS). Analyses are not ROI-only and are generalizable to a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=32, ages mean 22.8) using a social-related task (empathic choice—making decisions for another), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’/social processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (multiple GLMs), with tables/figures of activations and cluster-level whole-brain correction (P<0.05) and conjunction analyses; vmPFC results are reported with small-volume correction but whole-brain results (e.g., IPL, precuneus, middle frontal gyrus) are provided. Although PPI connectivity is included, the manuscript also reports univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20, ages mean ~35) using a social perception task (viewing faces of presidential candidates), which clearly falls under social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (faces vs rest, candidate contrasts, and correlations) with MNI coordinates and thresholded Z maps described and tabulated. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy sample limitations apply. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI task study with 20 healthy adult participants (mean age 22) investigating processing of communicative vs noncommunicative vocal sounds (social communication). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (vocal > nonvocal; communicative > noncommunicative) with thresholded statistical maps and peak coordinates and figures, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Analyses are task-evoked and not limited to ROIs, connectivity, or resting-state. Participants are within the 17–65 age range. Healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (observation of touch on another's hand — relevant to "Perception and Understanding of Others"). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age 26, range 23–39; two excluded for technical reasons), within the required 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate task contrasts (touch observation > control, masked by real touch > rest) with FWE-corrected results and coordinate table (Table 1), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (mirror neuron system; perception/understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (college students, mean age ~20). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses: one-sample within-group contrasts for alexithymia and non-alexithymia groups (with FDR-corrected maps and coordinate tables), a conjunction analysis, and figures/tables of voxelwise results. Healthy control data are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain univariate maps). Not excluded (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes within-group maps).

This is an fMRI study of charitable donation decisions—an explicitly social cognition task involving empathy and perspective-taking. Sample: 22 healthy adult females (ages 19–38), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (GLM contrasts; significant clusters reported with MNI coordinates and whole-brain cluster corrections), including contrasts correlating activity with donation value and free vs. forced trials; results are whole-brain corrected and presented in tables/figures. Although the paper also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it clearly reports primary whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy adult group. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study uses task-based fMRI to assess a social cognition construct (theory of mind) in healthy younger and older adult groups and additionally reports intrinsic (resting-state) connectivity within a task-defined theory-of-mind network. The paper explicitly states that a task-defined network was identified (implying group-level task activation maps) and links task behavior to neural connectivity. Younger adults are included (presumably within the 17–65 range) and results for healthy groups are reported separately. The study is empirical and reports original fMRI data. Although the excerpt does not list exact ages or present the tables/figures of whole-brain activation maps, the description indicates within-group task-defined whole-brain results were used to define the network; thus it meets the inclusion criteria for an fMRI social-task study with whole-brain, healthy-group task effects.

This study used task-based fMRI during observation of socio-affective (social touch) videos, a social-related paradigm. It includes a clearly reported healthy control group of neurotypical adults (n=21, ages within adult range). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts and associated activation results for the control/NT group (mean group effects and coordinate tables shown in the main text and supplementary materials, e.g., Figure S2 and Table S2). Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met for inclusion in a meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-related task (explicit facial emotion recognition) in healthy adult participants (ages within 17–65) and reports ROI and whole-brain analyses, the paper primarily reports between-group contrasts (LDA > HDA and HDA > LDA). It does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from a single healthy/control group (e.g., Emo_Emo > Neu_Age within all healthy subjects or within a defined healthy control group). Because the review requires at least one within-group whole-brain task activation map for healthy adults, and exclusion criteria disallow studies that report only between-group contrasts without a healthy-group whole-brain effect, this paper fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

The study uses task-based fMRI of a social cue (direct vs. averted gaze) and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate contrasts for the typically developing (healthy) group (Table 2), satisfying the imaging and analysis requirements. However, the healthy/control sample is a mixed adolescents-and-adults group (reported ages 16.1–42.4) and includes at least one participant below the review’s adult lower bound (17 years). No separate analysis or subgroup report limited to healthy adults aged 17–65 is provided. Because the inclusion criterion requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65) or a separable adult subgroup, this study does not meet the age/sample criterion and must be excluded.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of empathy for others’ pain (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others) including a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age ~33) reported separately. The authors present group-level, whole-brain univariate activation contrasts (e.g., Painful vs Nonpainful; Painful vs Baseline) with tables of coordinates and figures for the control group (Tables 2, 4 and accompanying text), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes a clinical CIP group, results for the healthy group are clearly identified and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and reports original task-evoked fMRI data in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30, ages ~26) using a social-related task probing perception and understanding of self vs. others (body‑perception and self‑other judgments). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (FEAT/FLAME; cluster-corrected Z-thresholds) with coordinates, maps, and clear contrasts for the healthy control group (own body, same‑sex other, opposite‑sex other, parametric self-similarity). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses, and healthy-group effects are reported and generalizable to adults 17–65. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self- and mother-reflection) in healthy adult participants (Chinese college students, mean age ~19). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (self vs celebrity; mother vs celebrity) and whole-brain regression and moderation analyses with coordinates and cluster data in tables (i.e., group-level voxelwise results generalizable to healthy adults). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain activation maps (tables/figures/supplement). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=19; mean age 19.1, within the 17–65 range) investigating social impression formation (a social cognition task: perception/understanding of others). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise results: a functional localizer contrast (form impression > remember order) and main task effects are reported with Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, and cluster-corrected thresholds (Tables 1 and 2 and corresponding figures). Analyses are whole-brain GLM contrasts (random effects) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=19, ages 18–58). The task probes social communication/perception (production and perception of prosody, emotional intonation) and relates neural activity to empathy—clearly social-related processing. Group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses are reported (random-effects contrasts such as “happy–neutral” and “question–neutral”; thresholds reported p<0.05 FDR, k>5; additional voxelwise contrasts and coordinate lists referenced in supplementary materials). Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity; healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps are explicitly described and used for inference. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI/connectivity, non-healthy sample, out-of-age-range) are violated. Therefore the paper should be included.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm (modified prisoner’s dilemma). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20; ages 23–45) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Task > Control) with cluster-level correction and tables of coordinates (Table 1 shows conjunction and post hoc contrasts, and post hoc t-contrasts report HC(TASK>CONT) > SZ(TASK>CONT) with MNI coordinates). Whole-brain activation maps for the healthy/control condition are therefore available and generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Hence the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (cooperation vs. competition) in healthy adults (N=12, ages 21–28). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., cooperation vs independent, competition vs independent, direct contrasts) with tables of peak coordinates and thresholding details, attributable to the healthy sample. It is not ROI-only, nor connectivity- or resting-state only, and participants fall within the eligible age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

Although this paper reports whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results for a parent–child social-affective task, the sample comprises only depressed mothers (clinical group) with psychiatrically ill children and no healthy adult/control group is reported. The meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65) with group-level whole-brain task maps reported separately. Therefore the study fails the sample inclusion criterion (no healthy adult participants/results) and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: the study uses task-based fMRI of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others via fearful vs. neutral body actions). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=12; ages 18–56) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Dynamic vs. Static; Fearful vs. Neutral) and provides tables of coordinates and Z-scores for control and conjunction analyses (Tables 2–4), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain voxelwise evidence. It is empirical, not ROI-only or resting-state/ connectivity-only, and thus is eligible for inclusion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 1) Task and construct: fMRI study of social-related processing (self-referential processing and intergroup competition — perception/understanding of self and others). 2) Sample: healthy adult participants (final N=21, Mage=23.1, ages within 17–65). 3) Whole-brain evidence: paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses with corrected cluster-wise results and tables of coordinates (Tables 1 and 2), and describes whole-brain random-effects analyses. 4) Not excluded: results are not limited to ROI-only analyses (although an mPFC ROI was used, whole-brain maps are reported), not connectivity/resting-state only, and participants are healthy. Therefore include in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=25, mean age 24) using task-based imaging that probes social-related processing: participants rated LEGO models for meaning (socially constituted meanings) versus physical properties and for own vs. others’ models (self/other). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Meaning > Physical, Own > Other, interaction effects) with statistical thresholding and tables of peak coordinates and figures. Analyses are random-effects, whole-brain, and clearly generalized to the healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants using a social/mentalizing paradigm (Prisoner’s Dilemma). The fMRI sample (n=163; ages 19–35) is within the 17–65 range. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses of the mentalizing contrast (ment > cont), with whole-brain voxel-wise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction; results are reported as tables of clusters/coordinates and figures. Although additional ROI analyses are performed, whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing that includes a neurotypical (NT) adult control group, the paper does not report a whole‑brain, group‑level univariate task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The main whole‑brain activation map is reported collapsed across ASD and NT groups, and the paper emphasizes a between‑group contrast (NT > ASD) for a small cluster. The inclusion criteria require a healthy/control group whole‑brain task map (main effect or within‑group contrast) reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. Because such an unmasked, NT‑only whole‑brain activation map is not presented in the full text (and results for the healthy group are not reported separately at the whole‑brain level), this study fails the ‘whole‑brain evidence from healthy adults’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of vitality-form recognition—an aspect of social perception/understanding of others—conducted in healthy adult participants (N=19; ages 21–29). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses and direct contrasts (e.g., how vs what) with tables of MNI coordinates and PFWE-corrected results, and figures showing activations (insula, parietal, premotor, etc.). Results are reported for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (n=24; mean age 26.2, range 18–39) and investigates social-related processing (pragmatic language/social communication: integration of speaker characteristics and sentence meaning). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for the control group (within-group contrasts speaker-incongruent > speaker-congruent and speaker-congruent > speaker-incongruent) with cluster-corrected results and tables of coordinates (Tables 4 and 5) and figures, not ROI-only analyses. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used resting-state fMRI and connectome-wide analyses (MDMR) to link individual network topology to emotional intelligence (MSCEIT). It does not report any task-based fMRI during social-related tasks nor any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy control group. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must include task fMRI whole-brain results; exclusion criteria explicitly remove studies that report only resting-state analyses. Although healthy adults are included, the absence of qualifying task-evoked whole-brain results requires exclusion.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 18–24) that reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., popular/artistic music vs. notes; artistic vs. popular) with coordinates and cluster statistics. Although the paradigm is aesthetic music appreciation, the authors explicitly test and report activation in social-cognition/ToM/default-mode regions (arMFC, PCC/PC, TPJ/angular gyrus, hippocampus/parahippocampus) and interpret these as reflecting cognitive empathy and mentalizing (perception/understanding of others). Thus the task engages social-related processing as defined by the review (Perception/Understanding of Others), and all inclusion criteria (healthy adult sample, task-based fMRI, whole-brain univariate results) are met.

The study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (interpersonal pleasant touch/social reward). It reports data for a healthy adult control group (24 matched non-using controls) and describes a within-group task contrast in controls (female vs male interaction) showing increased striatal activation. This constitutes a group-level, univariate task-evoked effect in the healthy/control group relevant to social processing. The abstract provides no indication that results are limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or to between-group contrasts only. Therefore the paper meets the inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adult group, and a reported healthy-group task activation). Confidence is moderate-high because the abstract does not explicitly state “whole-brain voxelwise” but the reported striatal activation for the control within-group contrast implies univariate task activation generalizable to healthy adults.

Study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=116 healthy men, mean age 24.7), performing an emotional face recognition task (social perception/processing). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked results (peak coordinates, FWE-corrected p-values, and whole-brain regression analyses) clearly identified for the healthy/control sample. Results are generalizable to healthy adults and are not limited to a narrow subgroup. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathy and forgiveness) in a group of ten healthy volunteers.
