The methods and abstract report task-evoked, group-level activations across multiple whole-brain regions (e.g., left superior frontal gyrus, orbitofrontal gyrus, precuneus, anterior middle temporal and inferior frontal gyri, posterior cingulate), indicating voxelwise whole-brain results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The sample is described as healthy volunteers (adult participants), and the reported contrasts represent within-group task effects generalizable to a healthy adult group. Age range is not explicitly provided in the text excerpt, slightly reducing certainty, but all other inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social/emotion processing (Face Matching Task with fearful and neutral faces) in healthy adults (N=10, mean age 25). The paper reports first-level and second-level GLM whole-brain analyses (one-sample t-tests) and provides group-level voxelwise activation results (thresholds and coordinate tables/figures, with supplementary materials). Although the study also presents ICA connectivity results, it includes univariate, group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy control sample, satisfying the review’s requirements. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; healthy adult group reported separately; includes whole-brain task effects). Therefore it should be included.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, mean age 24.4) investigating perception of others' pain and perceived agency — a clear social-related construct (perception/understanding of others, empathy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., pain>no-pain; social context effects; interaction), with tables of coordinates, statistical thresholds, and ROI and PPI analyses. Results are reported for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults within the 17–65 range. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study used task-based fMRI during a facial emotion discrimination task (social perception/understanding of others). Participants include healthy adult groups (NC: 19–35 years) reported separately from a problematic smartphone group. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results (within-group and condition contrasts for the NC and SP groups) with cluster tables (FWE-corrected p-values and voxel counts), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Age range fits 17–65 and no psychiatric diagnoses were included. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy-group whole-brain effects are provided). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social-emotional/simulation processing and includes a healthy adult control group (ages reported within 20–53) with results reported separately for some ROI analyses, it does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group. The paper’s whole-brain ANOVA reports main effects across the combined HC+SZ sample rather than an unmasked healthy-group task effect; the voxelwise results for HC alone are not provided (only ROI-level and combined-sample whole-brain results). Because the review’s inclusion criteria require at least one healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map, this study does not meet that requirement and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception) in healthy adults (final sample ages 18–32; group-level analyses reported). The paper reports random-effects, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (e.g., faces associated with behaviors vs. novel faces; disgusting vs. aggressive) with Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, and t-values (Tables 2–3 and figures). Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI studies in healthy adults.

This is an event-related BOLD fMRI study of self-face recognition (perception/understanding of self), a social-cognitive task directly relevant to the review. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (12 right-handed males, mean age 19.36, within the 17–65 range) and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., self vs. familiar, familiar vs. unknown, distracter vs. null) with SPM2 analyses and tables of coordinate maxima and figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Although sample is small and male-only, these do not violate inclusion criteria. Therefore include.

The paper reports an fMRI study using a social-related task (Multifaceted Empathy Test assessing cognitive and emotional empathy). The sample includes an age-appropriate healthy adult control group (female controls, mean ages in the 20s–30s). The manuscript presents group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts for the healthy/control group (main effects of cognitive and emotional empathy vs. baseline) with tables of MNI coordinates and figures. It is empirical fMRI work with task-evoked activations and does not rely solely on ROI/seed/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (effects of cognitively and emotionally empathic verbal responses) in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 26). The task manipulated social-empathic comments after negative performance feedback, clearly fitting constructs such as social cognition and perception/understanding of others. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked results with tables of coordinates and clusters (FWE-corrected p<0.05) and figures, i.e., whole-brain activation maps for several contrasts (e.g., empathic > unempathic, negative > positive feedback). No evidence that results are ROI-only, connectivity-only, or limited to clinical/subgroup samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=17, ages 18–27) that investigates social processes (the bystander effect, helping behavior). Participants performed a task while viewing videos of emergencies; the paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate analyses (parametric effects and contrasts) with tables of Talairach coordinates and cluster sizes. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply (no ROI-only, no resting-state/ connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (familiar vs unfamiliar faces — affiliation/attachment/person knowledge). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the healthy control group (N=13) with voxelwise results, coordinates and FWE-corrected statistics (e.g., partner>unfamiliar in left PCC, p<.05 FWE), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. A healthy adult control group is reported separately from the clinical case; controls are older adults (mean age 64.5 ± 5.7) but represent a healthy adult sample and their whole-brain task effects are explicitly presented. The paper also includes relevant behavioral and connectivity analyses, but these do not disqualify inclusion. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Study reports original task-based fMRI in which participants (healthy adults) viewed, imitated, and produced facial expressions and social hand gestures — clearly social-related processing. The abstract and article metadata describe group-level voxelwise task activations (activation in inferior parietal lobule and frontal operculum; locations compared statistically), indicating whole-brain univariate results rather than ROI-only or resting-state analyses. It is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants and therefore meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

The study reports an event-related fMRI task of evaluative judgments (self-referential/social cognition). It includes a healthy adult control group (mean age 26.4 ± 4.6, n=7) and reports within-group whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for control subjects (evaluative judgment vs. semantic retrieval) with statistical maps and coordinate tables (see Fig.2, Table 3), including results surviving correction for multiple comparisons. Analyses used random-effects second-level one-sample t-tests for the control group, satisfying generalizability requirements. The task is clearly social-related (self-referential/evaluative judgments). The paper is empirical fMRI with healthy adult whole-brain results and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=18, mean age 20). The task involves social-related processing (inferring preferences and social-group perception), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects GLM), with whole-brain contrasts, cluster sizes and Talairach coordinates provided. Results include main effects and simple effects with reported thresholds and coordinates (i.e., whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=31, mean age 24.3, right-handed, no neurological/psychiatric history). The tasks are social in nature (take-advice game and subsequent trust game) probing perception and understanding of others (honesty/trustworthiness). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., honesty vs dishonesty, value-related activations) with voxel-level and cluster-level FWE correction and provides GLM details, coordinates, tables, and figures. Results are clearly from the healthy/control sample and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not limited to ROI-only or to resting-state/seed-only connectivity; while it includes connectivity and MVPA, it also provides standard whole-brain activation maps. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind) in healthy adults (Exp.1 N=17 analyzed, mean age ~28.5; Exp.2 N=20, mean age ~21.3), all within the 17–65 range. Participants performed social tasks (listening to narratives about others' beliefs/emotions and moral judgments). The paper reports whole-brain preprocessing and uses a Belief>Photo theory-of-mind localizer (reported in methods and supplement/figures) to define ROIs, indicating group-level/univariate task contrasts are available (SM/Fig. S1). Although the primary analyses are MVPA within ROIs, the study includes whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for the localizer and provides coordinates/figures in the supplement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only without whole-brain results; not resting-state/connectivity-only; healthy adult data reported). Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related imitate/observe emotional face task. Healthy adult participants (controls age 18–55) are included and analyzed separately within the dataset. The paper reports second-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (imitate > observe) with group-level statistical maps (threshold-free cluster enhancement) and indicates that group analyses were run separately for each site and group; group and supplementary figures/tables present whole-brain maps. These results meet the requirement for a healthy/control-group whole-brain task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, within the target age range, and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This study uses task-based fMRI during emotional prosody processing, a social-communication/Perception-and-Understanding-of-Others construct. It includes a healthy adult control group (age range ~20–46) analyzed separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotional vs. neutral prosody) with family-wise error cluster correction and provides activation maps/clusters for controls (and ASD) separately, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design and reported results are task-evoked (not only ROI or connectivity). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review objective.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition using an impression-formation task (forming impressions of people vs inanimate objects). Participants: healthy adult sample (N=14; ages 18.3–23.7). Analyses: group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., person-impression > other trial types; coordinates, cluster sizes, and tables provided). Task-evoked univariate activation maps for the healthy/control group are explicitly described; results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrasts. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level univariate results) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (approachability and intelligence judgements from faces). It includes a healthy adult sample (47 controls, ages ~31–33) with results reported separately from the ASD subgroup. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts (e.g., social > gender) for healthy males and females, with statistical maps/coordinates and cluster-level correction (thresholds and coordinates provided and figures shown). Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult participants reported separately, and (3) univariate whole-brain group-level task activation maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or age out of range) are violated. Therefore include.

The study meets several requirements (fMRI task using social vs nonsocial IAPS images; includes a healthy adult control group within age range). However, the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map or contrast clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (i.e., a whole-brain within-controls main effect or within-group social>nonsocial map). The primary whole-brain analyses reported are between-group (HC vs SZ) t-tests and subsequent ROI follow-ups. The only within-group follow-ups are ROI-based, not whole-brain maps. Per the inclusion criteria, studies reporting only between-group contrasts and ROI follow-ups without an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18, age range 20–45). It uses a social cognition (Theory of Mind) task (an fMRI adaptation of the Movie for the Assessment of Social Cognition) and reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate GLM task contrasts (e.g., ToM > physical inference) with cluster tables and MNI coordinates (Table 1) and statistical thresholds. Although complementary model-free T-PICA analyses are also reported, the paper provides the required whole-brain task-evoked healthy-group maps and coordinates. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

This is an original fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=22, ages 19–32). The task probes social-related processing (identification and attribution of observed emotional behavior; perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (How>Why and Why>How) with tables of MNI coordinates and FDR-corrected results across the whole brain, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy adult results are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy group. Although connectivity (PPI) analyses are also included, they are supplemental to and do not replace the reported whole-brain activation maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, patient-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults (N=41, ages 18–24). The task explicitly probes social processes (decisions to share articles, perspective-taking, self-related processing) and contrasts (share > content, select > content, share > select) are reported. The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (Table 2, Fig. 4) with family-wise error correction, not limited to ROI results. Participants are healthy young adults and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not between-group-only, and not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study used task-based fMRI in a sample of healthy adults (n=21, mean age 24) during action observation and execution paradigms that probe perception/understanding of others’ actions (a social-cognition construct). Group-level, random-effects univariate analyses were conducted and whole-brain results are reported (whole-brain analysis at p<0.001 uncorrected with cluster extent threshold, plus ROI analyses), with peak coordinates and SPMs described. The paper therefore meets: (1) a social-related fMRI task (perception/understanding of others), (2) healthy adult sample within the 17–65 age range, and (3) reporting of group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked results. It does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not only between-group contrasts).

This is an fMRI study of social-affective processing (responses to others’ suffering; compassion/empathy), using a task (SoVT) that depicts people in distress. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=15; ages 45–62) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Compassion > Watch-Negative; Reappraisal > Watch-Negative) with tables/figures and cluster-level correction; not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Results are reported for the healthy adult group (expert meditators) rather than only between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated. Note: sample is a specialized population (long-term meditators), but they are healthy adults and their group-level whole-brain task maps are reported, so the study qualifies for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study using an event-related prisoner’s dilemma task (social decision-making/mentalizing) in healthy adult participants (N=35 analyzed; mean age 24.6, SD 4.5), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM results (contrasts such as proself vs prosocial, cooperation vs defection, and interactions with dispositional trust) with cluster-size correction and presents tables/figures of significant whole-brain clusters/coordinates. It is not ROI-only, nor limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalizable to a healthy adult population. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is a task-based fMRI study of facial emotion processing (a social cognition task) that includes a healthy adult control group (N=31; ages reported within 19.7–36.4). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses for the healthy/control group (paired t-tests, one-sample t-tests; Table 3 and supplementary material) with voxelwise results and stereotactic coordinates and appropriate statistical thresholds. Therefore it meets the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of affective vocalisations/social communication) in healthy adult participants (N=19; mean age 25.9, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (species contrast human > chimpanzee > macaque) with mixed-effects higher-level analysis (FLAME) and MNI coordinates/figures (whole-brain voxelwise results). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI task study of social communication (feeling addressed via body orientation and co-speech gestures) in healthy adult participants (N=37; mean age 25, range 20–39). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (main effects and interactions) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster results (e.g., IC>NG, ego>allo, interaction contrasts), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and healthy. Analyses are task-evoked, not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (linking person perception and person knowledge/ToM) using a task that manipulates bodies vs names and trait vs neutral information. Sample comprises healthy adults (n=21, mean age 24.6) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task results (main effects and interactions) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, plus coordinates and figure descriptions, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study also reports connectivity analyses but also provides the required univariate whole-brain maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-referential processing (self vs. other; valenced self-referential processing) using the VV-SORP-T, which falls squarely under ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ (social-related processing). Sample: 20 healthy adult women aged 18–52 (within 17–65 range) with exclusion of psychiatric history—meets the healthy adult requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses and voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., S-N, S-P vs. fixation and S-N vs O-N, S-P vs O-P) using SPM8, with voxelwise thresholds and cluster reporting; results are described in text, figures and tables of clusters/coordinates. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and provides unmasked whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=19; ages 21–46). The task explicitly probes social attribution (why/how social vs nonsocial stimuli) during fMRI. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (conjunctions and interaction contrasts) with cluster-level family-wise-error correction and tables of peak coordinates (e.g., Table 2); whole-brain contrast images are shared via NeuroVault/OSF. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI of social-related processing.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=24, ages 18–34). The task assesses social communication/perception—integration of facial and vocal emotions (congruency/incongruency) which falls under social-related processing. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM results and voxelwise contrasts (e.g., AV > A, AV > V, CAV > ICAV) with correction and tables of activation clusters, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65, contains original empirical fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (conceptual and agentic self-referential recollection) in healthy adults (N=18, ages 19–29). It reports group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses conducted with SPM8 and presents whole-brain results (including whole-brain FWE-corrected clusters for old>new and other contrasts) as well as ROI analyses; whole-brain activation maps/coordinates are described in the text/tables. The task involves social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). All inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, social-related fMRI task, and reported group-level whole-brain univariate results). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper).

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social expectancy violations along warmth and competence), using a task that probes perception/understanding of others. Participants were healthy adults (Princeton undergraduates; final N=12, mean age 20.4, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (contrasts, Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, corrected thresholds) for main effects and interactions (e.g., striatal, STS, parahippocampal activations). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group task activation maps/effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of fearful faces with direct vs. averted gaze) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, mean age ~23.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation analyses for the control group (within-group contrasts such as AVERTED>DIRECT and DIRECT>FIXATION), using mixed-effects FLAME, permutation testing (TFCE), and FWE-corrected maps (p<0.05) with reported clusters/coordinates and figures. Although a clinical ASD group is also included, control-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (whole-brain results are present, task-based, adult sample). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social reasoning/Theory-of-Mind using the Wason selection task (social exchange vs. precaution vs. descriptive), so it addresses social-related processing. Participants: healthy adults (n=20 recruited; 12 included in final group analysis; mean age 24.6), within the 17–65 range. Imaging: group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts are reported (story and card contrasts, tables of activations/coordinates, cluster thresholds), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The paper presents healthy-group task-evoked maps and contrasts (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only), and reports results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social task (multiround Ultimatum Game) probing social decision-making. The sample includes a separate healthy adult group (n=15; ages 19–28), meeting the 17–65 adult criterion. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (unfair>fair) analyzed in SPM, thresholded and presented with statistical maps, figures, and a table of coordinates (Table 1), clearly reporting results for the healthy adult group. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study provides whole-brain task-evoked activation maps from healthy adults relevant to social processing and should be included.

This is an event-related fMRI study of implicit facial emotion processing (a social perception task) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 27±5) reported separately from the Asperger group. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain, univariate activation analyses for the control group (e.g., neutral vs fixation, emotion vs fixation, linear trend analyses) and provides group activation maps and coordinate tables. The task probes social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others via facial expressions). It therefore meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult sample reported separately, and whole-brain voxelwise group results). No exclusion criteria apply (results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses).

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Social-related fMRI task — participants reacted to idiographic negative self-beliefs embedded in autobiographical social situations (perception/understanding of self and social cognition). (2) Sample: 35 healthy adults, ages 22.6–55.4 (within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts are reported (e.g., react vs. neutral; reappraise vs. react; acceptance vs. react; reappraisal vs. acceptance) with tables/figures and cluster-correction details. Although an amygdala ROI analysis is included, it does not preclude the presence of unmasked whole-brain maps. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy-group whole-brain effects clearly reported). Therefore include for the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study that employs a task-based social judgment paradigm (perception/understanding of others via dominance/trustworthiness judgments). Sample: 23 healthy adults aged 21–43 (within the 17–65 range); results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (Social Judgment > Perceptual Judgment) with cluster-level FWE-corrected results (tables/figures of activation clusters and coordinates). The study therefore provides a healthy-group, voxelwise task-evoked activation map and is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Hence it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (attentional orienting to social gaze vs arrow cues). Participants were healthy adults (N=22, mean age 22.95, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (2×2×2 factorial ANOVA), with whole-brain results and tables of peak coordinates, family-wise error correction and small-volume corrections; contrasts such as gaze>arrow and incongruent>congruent and validity effects are reported. Analyses are not ROI-only, nor are they connectivity- or resting-state-only. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (third-party punishment) in healthy adults (N=26, mean age 26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Decision Phase: Experimental > Control) with FDR-corrected thresholds, tables of activated regions/coordinates, and figures—meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task probes social cognition (evaluation of others’ intentions/responsibility). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and not restricted to between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study that includes a social cognition task contrast (TOM [social] vs Random) in a large sample of healthy adults (n=787, ages within 22–35). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation maps (Cohen's d and level-3 z maps), tabulated cluster peaks and figures showing task-evoked activations for the social contrast. Results for healthy participants are reported and generalizable. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and includes whole-brain voxelwise task effects for the healthy group; therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (altruism task focusing on partner’s feelings, ethics, and other-related valuation — clearly addressing perception/understanding of others and social decision-making). Participants are healthy adults (altruism N=55, subset N=37 for food; ages in range ~28 yrs), and results for the healthy sample are reported. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (searchlight MVPA decoding maps and GLM-based contrasts) with thresholded clusters and MNI coordinates, conjunctions and ROI results summarized at the group level (figures/tables of coordinates). These constitute whole-brain, task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Not excluded by any criterion (not solely ROI/seed/resting-state; empirical fMRI data reported).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (mental state decoding/‘Reading the Mind in the Eyes’), conducted in healthy adult participants (native Japanese and white American, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., RME − gender baseline) with tables and coordinate results and describes significant activations (bilateral pSTS, IFG, etc.), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state methods, and healthy adult results are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=23, mean age 26.4) that investigates social perception/animacy (perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (main effects of agent form, belief manipulation, and interactions) evaluated at voxel-wise thresholds and cluster correction; peaks and cluster locations are reported in tables and figures. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others) and results are generalizable to a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain healthy-group effects). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social gaze and action control in healthy adults (n=30, age range 19–41). The task is Social (gaze perception/interaction), meeting the social-related processing objective. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (main effects of congruency and gaze, and interaction contrasts) with voxelwise results and cluster-level inference (P<0.001 cluster-forming, FWE-corrected cluster thresholds), including coordinates and tables; thus it is not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Healthy adult results are reported separately and generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Naïve n=11, Trained n=10, Expert n=5) using an action-observation task that probes perception and understanding of others’ actions and intentions (motor resonance and mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Acheulean–Oldowan; Toolmaking–Control) with voxelwise results and coordinate tables (FDR-corrected), and provides separate healthy-group results and exclusive masking analyses. It is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state, between-groups-only, clinical-only, or non-empirical paper. Participants are described as adult neurotypical humans. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study using the Cyberball social exclusion/inclusion paradigm (task-based fMRI). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20 females, ages matched to patients) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (flexible factorial, main effects and interaction effects) and reports group- and condition-level effects, with post hoc within-group contrasts and t-contrasts summarized in the main text and Supplementary Tables/Figures. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy-group task-evoked activations and condition contrasts are described (and t-contrasts provided in Supplementary Table S4), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

The paper reports an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (social approval/self-processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 20–51) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation results for the control group (tables of coordinates and figures showing activation maps for controls, e.g., Table 3 and Figures 3–4). The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and presents unmasked whole-brain task effects for healthy adults separate from the clinical group. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=14, ages 20–32). Subjects viewed social interaction stimuli (point-light dyads and shape animations) during task runs. The paper reports group-level, surface-based random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses with significant task-evoked activation maps (e.g., social interaction > independent; peak MNI [54, −43, 18]; P thresholds reported, group maps shown in figures/SI). Results for the healthy participant group are reported and generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). Analyses are task-evoked univariate contrasts (not only ROI or connectivity), so all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study reports an fMRI task of prosodic connected-speech perception, which maps onto social communication/pragmatics (social-related processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=8, ages ~23) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task effects for controls (one-sample t-tests showing activation and deactivation maps, conjunctions, and between-group contrasts with coordinates and correction thresholds). Although the study also includes an autism group, control-group results are reported separately. The task-evoked whole-brain maps are clearly described and meet the meta-analysis requirements. Note the small control sample and group heterogeneity covariate use, but these do not violate inclusion/exclusion criteria.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (theory-of-mind/intentions) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, mean age 24.75). The manuscript provides group-level, whole-brain, univariate second-level analyses for the control group (contrasts of PInt/PSInt/CInt vs physical causality), with statistical thresholds and tables of coordinates (Tables/Figures reporting whole-brain activations). The healthy-group task effects are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The study is not ROI-only, nor limited to connectivity or between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all stated inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults that reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts. Participants: 30 healthy right-handed native Japanese adults (age range 19–31), within inclusion age range. The experimental manipulation explicitly targets Social Communication (communicative vs. descriptive speech) and uses task-based fMRI. Results include whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise contrasts and coordinate tables (multiple tables listing MNI peaks and cluster sizes), demonstrating univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. The study is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and does not rely solely on between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all specified inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study employed a social empathy-for-pain task and included a separate healthy adult control group (n=18; age range 22–63). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., High Pain > Low Pain in Other), provides whole-brain analyses and peak coordinates (Supplementary Table 1 and text), and describes results for the control/healthy group separately. The task probes social processing (empathy) and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study includes a neurotypical (healthy) control group, the full text and abstract focus on effective connectivity/network analyses in ASD versus controls. The manuscript describes effective connectivity and causal/network modeling rather than reporting any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group (no clear whole-brain statistical maps, tables of coordinates, or within-group activation contrasts for controls are provided). This violates the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. Therefore the study should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathic judgments / emotional egocentricity bias) in healthy adult participants (multiple independent samples of right-handed female undergraduates, ages within adult range). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked whole-brain contrasts (e.g., the interaction (Other Incongruent>Congruent) > (Self Incongruent>Congruent)), provides peak coordinates, cluster statistics, tables and figures, and describes whole-brain analyses (fMRI1 exploratory whole-brain; fMRI2 used independent localizer SVC but the study reports group-level activation maps/coordinates). The manuscript is empirical and includes original fMRI data from healthy adults; it is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-communication task (audiovisual speech) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=15), it does not report a group-level whole-brain univariate task activation map specifically for the healthy/control group. The paper reports (1) a main effect of audiovisual congruency across all participants and (2) group-by-congruency interactions and between-group comparisons, but no unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task contrast or map that is clearly identified as coming from controls. This violates the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map; therefore the study must be excluded.

Although the study used task-based fMRI of social cognition (theory of mind and empathy) and included a healthy control group (n=20), the full text does not report an unmasked, group-level, whole-brain, within-group task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control sample. The analyses focus on between-group contrasts (patients vs. controls), conjunctions, and regions where diagnosis influenced activation, and VBM results restricted to fMRI-defined masks. No standalone whole-brain one-sample or group-level healthy-control task maps (e.g., controls: ToM>control or Emp>control) are presented in the paper; the reported coordinates and tables reflect group differences rather than an unambiguous healthy-group whole-brain activation map. According to the review’s inclusion/exclusion criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded.

The paper uses task fMRI of social cognition (action observation/understanding; ToM) and includes a healthy adult control group. However, the reported whole-brain voxelwise results are presented as between-group contrasts (ALS > HC and HC > ALS for the understand>observe contrast). The manuscript does not present an unmasked, within-group (main effect or one-sample) whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Because the study appears to provide only between-group voxelwise contrasts without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task map, it fails the review’s requirement for healthy-group whole-brain evidence and must be excluded.

The sample consists of 80 adolescent males aged 16–17 with no separate healthy adult (17–65) subgroup reported; inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (17–65). Therefore the participant age criterion is not met. Additionally, the paper’s primary analyses focus on task-based functional connectivity and ROI/network-based effects; it does not clearly present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for a healthy adult group (required by inclusion). Because the study fails the age eligibility and does not clearly provide the required whole-brain univariate healthy-group activation map, it should be excluded.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (fMRI subgroup n=11, mean age 24.2) that examines neural processing of others’ actions (auditory mirror system and action understanding), a social cognition construct (Perception/Understanding of Others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (voxelwise contrasts, cluster-corrected maps) with coordinates and tables of activations. It is empirical, task-based fMRI in healthy adults and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI studies of social-related processing.

This is an empirical fMRI study of face-to-face social interaction (eye contact) using dyadic fMRI in healthy adults (19 pairs, ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise GLM analyses and paired t-tests with whole-brain statistical maps (thresholds and cluster results reported), atlas-based cluster labels and MNI coordinates, and describes univariate task-evoked contrasts (tasks A and B, and derived contrasts). The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are presented at the group level. The study is not ROI-only, nor limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults assessing social processing (eye contact).

This study examines social-related processing (self- and other-reflection) using task-based fMRI and includes a healthy adult control group (n=33; ages 18–65) with results reported separately. The paper provides whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task contrasts for the control group (e.g., Self>Facts, Other>Facts, Other>Self) with cluster-level corrected statistics and MNI coordinates. It is not limited to ROI analyses or connectivity/resting-state methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for task-evoked whole-brain fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of allocentric social processing (social hierarchy and social alliance judgments) in healthy adults (n=22 males, mean age 24.2). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects contrasts with voxelwise results (FWE-corrected p<0.05) and coordinate tables/figures. Tasks clearly probe social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of others, social affiliation/status). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=15, mean age 22.9) using a social interaction task (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) that probes perception/understanding of others and social decision-making. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate analyses for task contrasts (decision and outcome phases), with stereotaxic coordinates reported in Tables 1–2 and statistical thresholds (p<0.001, cluster ≥20 voxels). Results are reported specifically for the healthy/control group and are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Age range and sample qualify as healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social perception using a task that explicitly probes perception/understanding of others and social interaction dynamics (viewing dynamic crowds expressing fearful, happy, or neutral emotions; interactive vs. individual). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=16, ages 19–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANOVAs) with tables of coordinates and cluster-level corrected results (Tables 1–3) showing main effects and interactions. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=45, age range 18–34). The task includes a reappraisal generation task (RGT) based on anger-eliciting, interpersonal vignettes (social situations requiring reinterpretation of others’ behavior), which qualifies as social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, social cognition). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (conjunction and RGT>AUT and AUT>RGT contrasts) with voxelwise FWE correction and tables of coordinates, generalizable to the healthy adult sample. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (female, ages 18–35). The task probes self-related social processing (participants rated whether they would like to smell like presented odors—perception/understanding of self). Group-level univariate voxelwise task contrasts are reported (t-contrasts with MNI coordinates for ‘self’-peptide vs solvent and vs ‘non-self’-peptide), with statistical thresholds and FWE values; analyses are not limited to connectivity or single-ROI-only reporting. Results are presented for the healthy participant group and are generalizable within the sampled adult range. Thus the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study examines social affiliation (maternal bonding) in healthy adult mothers using simultaneous fMRI-PET while mothers watched their infants, so sample and task domain meet the review objective. However, the paper’s primary reported outcomes are PET measures of dopamine release and intrinsic/seed-based connectivity within a medial amygdala–striatal–mPFC network. In the provided full text there is no clear report of a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group (results focus on connectivity and PET binding rather than whole-brain task activation maps). Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain univariate task activation map from the healthy group, and this criterion is not met based on the available text, the study should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mental state attribution) in healthy adult participants (N=28 analyzed; ages 18–22). The task involved social-related judgments (rating how scenarios elicit others’ mental states). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: searchlight RSA and voxelwise repetition-suppression analyses with group one-sample t tests and permutation TFCE correction, and provides peak MNI coordinates and cluster extents for significant effects (e.g., dmPFC, precuneus). Results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to an ROI-only or connectivity-only analysis. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (group of 11 right-handed subjects, ages 21–36) using a social task (sequential Prisoner’s Dilemma) probing social judgments of others. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM2 random-effects), with tables of peak coordinates and figures for contrasts (cooperator vs. neutral, defector vs. neutral, intentional vs. nonintentional), and describes ROI and whole-brain reporting thresholds. It is not ROI-only, nor exclusively connectivity/resting-state, and the healthy-group task effects are clearly reported and generalizable to adults 17–65. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, ages 18–27) using a social-related task probing empathy for pain/pleasure toward human and robotic agents. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects, cluster-corrected contrasts), whole-brain contrast maps are available on NeuroVault, and tables/figures describe whole-brain results. It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses and the healthy-group task effects are clearly reported and generalizable to the adult healthy sample. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the paper reports a mega-analysis of four fMRI studies of mental-state representation in healthy adults (so it addresses the review topic and likely uses adult healthy samples), the provided full-text content and abstract do not clearly report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps (e.g., main-effect or within-group contrasts). The reported analyses emphasize representational similarity/neural pattern analyses and model-based accounts of neural variance, which may not satisfy the review's requirement for an identifiable univariate whole-brain task activation map. Because the inclusion criteria require explicit reporting of at least one univariate whole-brain healthy-group task map and that is not verifiable from the provided text, I must exclude the study. If the full paper or supplements contain explicit group-level univariate whole-brain maps/coordinates, this decision could be revisited.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing: participants (n=20 healthy adult males, mean age 24.6) viewed first-person video clips of neutral, social-positive, and reactive-aggressive interactions. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation contrasts (second-level random-effects analyses) with tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2–3), conjunctions, and FDR-corrected thresholds—i.e., voxelwise whole-brain results for the healthy group. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (perception of others via voices; emotion and identity recognition), which falls squarely within 'Perception and Understanding of Others'. Sample includes a healthy adult sighted group (n=15; mean age 32.2) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (main effects of Stimulus-Type, Group, interactions) with voxelwise maps and tables of coordinates and presents random-effects GLM results generalizable to the population; results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Although the study also includes a congenitally blind group, healthy-group data are reported and separable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (trust decisions/social cognition; theory-of-mind network) in healthy adults. The sample includes healthy participants within the 17–65 range (behavioral n=40; fMRI analyses n=34; ages 19.5–32.7). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., pupil-mimicry vs no-mimicry; partner pupil change vs static) with peak coordinates, tables, figures, and cluster-level/FWE-corrected results, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and is empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=31 analyzed; ages 18–35), using a social perception task (viewing faces with/without disfigurement while performing a gender judgment). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (pre- vs post-surgery faces) with familywise-error cluster correction and voxelwise thresholds, and reports significant clusters in ventral occipito-temporal cortex, anterior cingulate, etc., with figures/tables. The task and contrasts address social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, healthy adult group results are reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study (3T BOLD) in healthy adults (n=29, mean age 27) that used a social-cognitive task (humor processing of cartoons involving affective appraisal and mentalizing/ToM). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate results (Cartoons vs Neutral and parametric modulation by subjective funniness) with coordinates, conjunctions, and FWE/cluster-level corrections, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. The healthy-group results are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social communication (understanding communicative vs private intentions). Sample: 23 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 24), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., CInt > PInt, interaction Intention×Orientation) with tables of peak coordinates and thresholding details (voxelwise maps, FDR-corrected results reported). Although PPI connectivity is included, whole-brain task activation maps are explicitly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state, and healthy adult group results are clearly presented). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (person/biographical knowledge retrieval). It used task-based fMRI with healthy adult participants (study 1: N=24, Mage≈23.2; study 2: N=26, Mage≈20.4), all within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., all-memory > baseline; status memory > baseline; trait memory > baseline; face vs name contrasts) with voxelwise inference (FWE-corrected maps and coordinate tables such as Table S6 and Figures S3/S4). Whole-brain results are clearly presented for the healthy/control sample; ROI, PPI, and DCM analyses are additional but do not replace the whole-brain maps. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (learning/simulation of others’ decisions; mentalizing/perception and understanding of others). Participants: healthy adult sample (39 recruited; 3 excluded; n=36 used for behavioral and fMRI analyses). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation results with corrected statistics and coordinates (Tables 1 and 2; whole-brain cluster-level FWE p<0.05) and figures showing activations (vmPFC, dmPFC/dlPFC, TPJ/pSTS, etc.). The task and analyses are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for an fMRI meta-analysis of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (interpersonal trust/distrust) in healthy adults (N=60, mean age ~20, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g., trust > age, distrust > age, trust > distrust) with FWE-corrected results and coordinate tables/figures, clearly from the healthy sample. Analyses include whole-brain maps and ROI follow-ups; it is not limited to ROI-only, resting-state, or between-group-only contrasts. Thus the study satisfies all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level results) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (n=15, mean age 24.4) examining processing of anger prosody — a social-communication task. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., anger vs. neutral; attention × emotion interactions) with coordinate tables and statistical maps described in the text and table 1. Analyses are voxelwise and generalizable to a healthy adult group. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes within-group task-evoked whole-brain results for the healthy/control sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of a social task (Trust Game) conducted in healthy adults (ages 19–30), the paper reports only subgroup comparisons (high-Mach vs low-Mach) rather than an unmasked, whole‑brain task activation map that is generalizable to the healthy adult population. The reported results are voxelwise between-group contrasts and extreme-score subgroup analyses (selected on Mach‑IV), i.e., a narrowly defined subgroup; no whole‑sample or healthy/control group main effect (GAME>CONTROL) unmasked map is provided. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group-level, univariate whole‑brain task‑evoked map from a generalizable healthy adult group, and matches the exclusion criterion for studies that report only between‑group contrasts without an accompanying healthy‑group whole‑brain task effect.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (integration of non-verbal human vocalizations and facial movements—social communication/perception of others). The fMRI sample includes healthy adult participants (n=10, ages 24–37). Group-level voxelwise univariate analyses are reported (voxel-by-voxel t tests, group activation maps versus rest, AV versus AUD+VIS contrasts, cluster-correction and Talairach normalization), with results presented in figures and tables. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related Theory of Mind (visual joke) task. The paper includes a healthy control group (n=13; adults age ~29) and reports within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (ToM vs Physical) for the control group with coordinates and cluster-corrected statistics (see Table 3 and related figures). The study is not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses and provides univariate whole-brain maps/generalizable healthy-group task effects. Although clinical/high-risk groups are also included, results for the healthy adult control group are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (learning others’ inter-temporal preferences and self–other valuation) in healthy adult participants (behavioral N=27; fMRI N=29 with 2 exclusions). The authors report group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (GLM contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) with peak coordinates and statistical values (e.g., mPFC, visual cortex, STS, striatum), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task clearly probes perception/understanding of others and social influence. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (n=14, mean age 25) investigating observation and motor imagery of meaningful face and upper-limb movements, including socially meaningful gestures (social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (conjunctions, main effects, contrasts) with FWE-corrected thresholds and MNI coordinates in tables and SPM figures. Results for the healthy sample are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-, connectivity-, or patient-only focused. Therefore it satisfies the inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level task activation maps).

While the study uses fMRI in healthy adult samples and includes social tasks (theory-of-mind, attribution-of-attention), its primary analyses are localized ICA performed within a temporoparietal ROI and regression of IC time courses to task predictors. The paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map (e.g., a conventional GLM contrast like belief>photo) for the healthy group. Reported voxelwise results are seed-to-voxel connectivity maps (functional connectivity), and the spatial IC maps/winner-take-all maps are constrained to the TPJ ROI. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain univariate task activation evidence and meets the exclusion criteria (ROI/ICA- or connectivity-focused results only).

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=18, ages ~25) investigating social-communication constructs (vitality forms of speech and actions). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Vitality vs Control) with MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected results, including conjunction analyses and tables of activations. Whole-brain analyses (not ROI-only) are presented and clearly described for the healthy control sample. Although PPI connectivity is also reported, univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are available, satisfying inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range participants) are violated.

Empirical fMRI study of implicit false-belief (theory-of-mind) processing — a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (mean age 22.7; final n for MRI analyses reported), within 17–65. Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (whole-brain GLM contrasts; belief > photo/map) with SPMs and peak Talairach coordinates and cluster thresholds; not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalizable. No exclusion criteria met. Therefore study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (right-handed males, mean age ~27) and uses a social-related task (explicit and implicit processing of emotional facial expressions), the paper does not present a clear, unmasked whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The Results primarily report activations for the autistic group, main effects (task and diagnosis) and diagnosis × task interactions, and between-group contrasts (controls > autism), but do not provide an independent within-group whole-brain statistical map or univariate contrast clearly attributable to the healthy group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map and must be excluded.

Although the study uses fMRI with healthy adult participants and reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts, its experimental paradigm probes sexual arousal and incentive/reward responses to erotic stimuli across sexual orientations. The meta-analysis objective targets social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others). The present study’s primary outcomes concern sexual arousal and reward-system activation, not social cognitive processes or social interaction/communication constructs. Therefore it does not address the review’s targeted social-related tasks and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=32, mean age ~24.7). The task manipulated social context (collaborative, individual, competitive) during effort production and explicitly probes social constructs (collaboration/competition, social position). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses using SPM8, with clusterwise FWE correction and reported activation peaks/coordinates (e.g., ventral basal ganglia, TPJ, mPFC). Results for the healthy adult sample are presented separately and are generalizable to the healthy group (no clinical sample reported). The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 1) Task: the study used task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (naturalistic social-evaluative videos probing social evaluation/mentalizing, affiliation/communication and perception of others). 2) Sample: healthy adult participants (N=37; mean age 24.8, within 17–65). 3) Whole-brain evidence: the paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., negative>neutral, positive>neutral), conjunction analyses and FWE-corrected results presented in tables and figures (Tables 2–4, whole-brain FWE-corrected p<.05). 4) No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within the target age range). Therefore this empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

This is a functional MRI study of social processing (self–other merging during cooperation and competition) in healthy adults (final N=24; age 19–31). The task is explicitly social (ratings and decisions about self vs relevant other in cooperative/competitive contexts). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (identifying pgACC and area 9 and other whole-brain effects) rather than only ROI or connectivity results. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy sample. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction (mutual gaze and joint attention) in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~21–23, all right-handed except one). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and cluster-level statistics (Tables 2–5, voxel coordinates, FWE-corrected results) including contrasts for JA conditions (IJA/RJA) and MG1/MG2 (MG2–MG1). Results are generalizable to healthy adults and are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–27) that examines neural correlates of abstract vs. concrete mindsets using Why-How and Categories-Exemplars tasks involving social-cognitive processes (action identification/mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts analyzed with SPM5 (one-sample t-tests) and provides coordinates and cluster-corrected results in Table 2 and figures. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes task-evoked whole-brain maps for the healthy control group. All inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, social-related task, whole-brain univariate results). No exclusion criteria are violated.

Population: Healthy adult participants (n=10, ages 20–29). Task: auditory perception of human footsteps (biological motion) involving perception/understanding of others; authors explicitly reference the ‘social cognition’ area (posterior STS) and biological motion, which maps onto social-related processing constructs. Whole-brain, group-level univariate results: contrast ‘footstep minus rest’ reported with t-values, cluster coordinates and a group random-effects analysis; results presented in Table 1 and supplementary whole-brain maps. Study is empirical fMRI in healthy adults and reports an univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Although the paper also contains connectivity analyses, it includes the required whole-brain task activation data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social appraisal (preference judgments of emotional faces) that includes a healthy adult comparison group (n=21; mean age 39.8±10.3, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (PREF>GENDER) with tables and figures showing within-group activation maps for the control group (coordinates and corrected clusters provided). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and provides univariate, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy participants, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy young adults (ages 21–24) that includes a social-context manipulation (peer observation) relevant to social processing. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate activation contrasts for both tasks (Go/No-Go and Stoplight) and provides thresholded/unthresholded maps (NeuroVault). Healthy adult sample is within 17–65 and results for the healthy group are reported. Although the paper emphasizes connectivity, it also includes traditional whole-brain activation/subtraction analyses (e.g., No-Go > Go, Risk > Safe), satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study of social communication (emotional speech prosody) in healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age 24.8, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (emotional > neutral prosody) with cluster-corrected results (PFDR < 0.05) and associated tables/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain activation maps are clearly reported for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria are met (not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical study), and results are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study uses task-based fMRI including explicit social cognition tasks (social videos and social texts probing others' beliefs/emotions). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=45; mean age 20.5, range 19–23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and random-effects analyses with figures and peak coordinate tables (Appendix A), demonstrating generalizable healthy-group univariate activation maps. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30, ages 19–39) that investigates social-related processing (kinship/affiliation, moral decision-making, mentalizing) using task paradigms. The paper reports group-level whole-brain results: (a) voxelwise inter-subject correlation (ISC) analyses across the whole brain with FDR correction and cluster reporting, and (b) a separate GLM analysis of a moral-dilemma task with whole-brain, cluster-corrected activations (tables of clusters/peak coordinates and unthresholded maps available). The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are presented. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and includes univariate, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of personal familiarity (a social-related process) and reports whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts for the healthy control group, the healthy participants are described as 'healthy elderly' and were recruited as an aging control group. Participant ages are not provided but the term 'elderly' and focus on aging strongly indicate they are older than the review's upper age limit (65). The review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; therefore the study population does not meet the sample age criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others’ emotions) in healthy adult participants (n=19 males, ages 18–51). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple emotions), thresholding and cluster-correction methods, and localization of activations (including medial PFC, STG, IFG, etc.), fulfilling the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. The task is social-related (complex/social emotions, ToM-related processing). The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed connectivity only, not between-group-only contrasts, and is empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (age 18–45) that employed a social-related task (viewing/regulating responses to images of human suffering—perception/understanding of others).
