The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., high- vs low-distress cries; happy vs neutral faces) with voxelwise results, cluster correction, coordinates, and images generalizable to the healthy adult sample. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a sample of aMCI patients and healthy aging controls, but the reported results focus on ROI-based and seed/voxel-level functional connectivity and network analyses (correlation matrices, seed-based connectivity maps, conjunctions). It does not provide a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., task>baseline or within-group activation contrasts). Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only seed-based or connectivity analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation are ineligible. Additionally, participants are described as an aging/aMCI sample (likely older than 65), so the healthy group may fall outside the 17–65 age range, further reducing applicability.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind/implicit belief processing) in healthy adults (final N=22; mean age 24.4 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain random-effects GLM results from an explicit general-belief localizer contrast (false-belief vs false-photograph) at q(FDR)<0.05 with peak Talairach coordinates and a whole-brain statistical map (Fig.2A and text). Although some analyses used ROIs, the study includes clearly reported whole-brain, task-evoked healthy-group results that are generalizable to healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria.

The study includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, mean age ~23), uses task-based fMRI during social-related processing (rapid fearful face perception), and reports group-level univariate activation results for the control group. Within-group control activations are provided (e.g., bilateral fusiform, right amygdala, pulvinar, superior colliculi) in Table 2 and Supplementary materials, and whole-brain analyses are described in the supplement. Although ROIs were used, whole-brain mixed-effects analyses (FLAME) and coordinate clusters for the healthy/control group are reported, satisfying the requirement for an univariate whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of gesture planning/execution—a social communication task (pantomime gestures) relevant to Social Communication. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group effects and contrasts for controls) with explicit thresholds (P≤.001) and cluster criteria; within-group/control maps/results are described in the main text and supplementary materials. The study is empirical and not ROI-, connectivity-only, or resting-state-only. Although a patient group is included, healthy-control whole-brain task activation is clearly provided and generalizable to healthy adults. Participant ages are not explicitly listed but recruitment sources (staff, students, matched adults) indicate an adult sample within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This fMRI study includes a healthy control group of adults (n=28, mean age 21.6) and reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group (e.g., self>other and 3PP>1PP activation maps and tables of clusters). The task probes social-related constructs (self-referential processing and perspective-taking), which fit the review’s scope (Perception and Understanding of Self). Whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented in tables and text. Although recruitment targeted ages 15–35, group means indicate adult participants within the 17–65 range and the study is not limited to underage-only samples. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain task activation maps reported.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition with direct/averted gaze), reporting group-level whole-brain results. It includes a healthy younger adult group (17–27 years) within the 17–65 range and presents whole-brain voxelwise findings (PLS-derived maps with peak coordinates and cluster tables) clearly attributed to the healthy participants. Results for younger controls are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-connectivity-only, and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/coordinates. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (perception of fearful faces) including a healthy adult control group (N=13; mean age 25.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., main effect of faces vs scrambled baseline and linear contrasts of fear intensity) with coordinates and figures, using a random-effects GLM and whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001 uncorrected) and reporting activations (with small-volume corrections for a priori ROIs). Results for the healthy/control group are presented separately from the clinical (HFA/AS) group. Although ROI/SVC procedures were applied to hypothesized social-brain regions, the study provides univariate, whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates for the healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study uses a social-related task (facial emotion discrimination/perception of others) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, ages ~24.5). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (within-group contrasts such as sad>neutral shown separately for controls and described in the text and figures) using SPM2 with voxelwise inference and cluster reporting. Healthy-group results are presented (figures and text) and thus satisfy the requirement for an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map. Although the clinical high-risk group is also included, the healthy control group’s whole-brain task effects are reported separately. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related approach-avoidance task with social and nonsocial stimuli in a healthy adult sample (male, mean age 21.35, within 17–65). Group-level task-based neuroimaging analyses were performed (first- and second-level contrasts), and the paper reports task-evoked activation results including whole-brain analyses (supplementary/ exploratory whole-brain results are reported beyond ROI/SVC findings). The study is empirical, not clinical-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes healthy-group results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (task fMRI of social processing; healthy adult sample; group-level whole-brain task results reported).

Although the study includes an fMRI task of social cognition (RMET) and reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for the healthy participants, the healthy sample is 20 older adults aged 51–84 (mean 68.4) and is not restricted to the review’s required age range (17–65). The paper does not report a separate healthy subgroup within 17–65. Therefore it violates the age eligibility criterion and must be excluded despite meeting other fMRI and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This paper reports original fMRI data in healthy adult participants (three studies, combined N=59; all participants unique and within adult age range). Each study implemented social-related tasks (person knowledge, famous names, socially relevant words) and appropriate non-social controls. The authors conducted voxelwise, group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8) reporting contrasts of interest (social > non-social semantics) with cluster- and voxel-level thresholds and provide peak coordinates and whole-brain results in text/tables/figures. Analyses are clearly identified as coming from the healthy control groups. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task activations, healthy adult sample). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of visual perspective taking/theory-of-mind in healthy adults (n=16, mean age ~22.4). The task is social (self vs other visual perspective judgments). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts with voxelwise results and tables of coordinates (cluster-level FWE correction reported), including multiple contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other) generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes a healthy adult sample within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

While the study uses task fMRI of social/emotional processing and includes healthy adult controls (ages within 17–65), the full text does not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map that is explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. The manuscript emphasizes PPI (seed-based connectivity) results and between-group comparisons, and indicates that activation details are in the supplementary material but does not present an unmasked/control-only whole-brain task effect in the text. Because the review requires a clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task map, and this criterion is not met/unambiguously reported, the study must be excluded.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of face perception (socially-relevant stimuli) in healthy young adults, it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables for the healthy/control group. Analyses are ROI-based interregional BOLD correlations and structural covariance (25 predefined ROIs) and group-level connectivity/covariance matrices; no unmasked whole-brain activation maps or voxelwise contrasts are presented. This violates the inclusion requirement for whole-brain evidence and matches the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ROI analyses without whole-brain results.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (27 recruited, 20 analyzed; mean age 24.6), investigating social-communication processes (observation and imitation of social vs non-social gestures). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., IMI > CT; S > NS), cluster-corrected results and tables/coordinates in MNI space, clearly from the healthy/control sample. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods. The healthy adult results are reported and generalizable (whole-brain contrasts and coordinates). Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (matched typically developing males, age range within 17–65) and uses task-evoked fMRI during a social cognition task, it does not report an unmasked, whole‑brain group-level activation map (or coordinates) for the healthy/control group alone. The paper reports between-group contrasts (typically developing > ASD) and regions where ASD shows reduced activity, but does not present a clearly identified, generalizable healthy-group whole‑brain task effect (e.g., one-sample healthy-group maps or coordinates). Per the review’s inclusion criteria, a separate healthy-group whole-brain univariate result is required. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind and empathy) in a healthy adult sample (76 college students, age 17–21). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain SPM activation maps (task contrasts and a pooled condition analysis) with Random Field Theory correction (αRFT ≤ 0.05) and provides peak coordinates and cluster information. Healthy/control group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, within the age range 17–65, and not limited to ROI-only or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 18–35). It uses two task-based social-cognitive paradigms (emotional perspective-taking and emotion attribution) that target social/mentalizing processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (emotion perspective-taking > shape-match; emotion attribution > gender-match) with corrected statistics and cluster coordinates (see Fig. S3 and reported clusters), and provides voxelwise regression results for the healthy sample. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This item is a conference proceedings abstract with insufficient reporting to meet inclusion criteria. The full text provided does not specify participant sample characteristics (numbers, ages) for a healthy adult group, nor does it report any group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinates from a healthy/control group. The abstract describes data-driven neural bases and networks but gives no clear whole-brain statistical results that are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ and sample reporting requirements and must be excluded.

This study used resting‑state fMRI and graph‑theory (Network Centrality) analyses rather than a task‑evoked fMRI paradigm. Although social cognition and executive tasks were administered behaviorally (outside the scanner) and a healthy control group was included, the paper does not report any group‑level, whole‑brain univariate task‑evoked activation maps for healthy adults. Results are limited to resting‑state connectivity/centrality and between‑group comparisons (bvFTD, stroke, controls). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring task‑based whole‑brain activation maps from healthy adult participants.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (formation of social ties during a repeated public good game). Sample includes healthy adult participants (25 scanned subjects, mean age 22.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (parametric modulation of tie, impulse, and contribution magnitude; MNI coordinates and cluster-wise FWE correction reported; figures and supplementary tables provided). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses (although PPIs are also reported, whole-brain activation maps are primary). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study meets many content criteria (fMRI of social gaze processing in healthy adult participants, voxelwise activation maps are reported). However, the paper’s group-level voxel-based analyses were performed using a fixed-effects averaging across subjects (methods state a “fixed-effects analysis”), which does not provide population-level (random-effects) inference generalizable to the healthy adult population as required by the inclusion criteria. In addition, the effective sample after motion exclusion appears small/unclear. Because the inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level univariate maps that are generalizable to healthy adults, this fixed-effects–only reporting prevents inclusion.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (separate fMRI sample N=26, ages 22–45) that used a social-cognitive task (evaluating political statements; engages perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (second-level contrasts, F and t tests) and provides voxel coordinates, statistical maps, and ROI-corrected results (thresholds and coordinates in tables/figures). Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable within the adult sample. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This article is a non-empirical review (publication type listed as 'Review') discussing functional neuroimaging approaches to development of social cognition; it does not report original fMRI data or group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from healthy adult participants. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring original fMRI whole-brain results in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers.

This JoVE article reports original fMRI data collected in n=15 healthy adult participants (age range not explicitly stated but described as typical adult recruitment) during a social-related task (observing animated guest–host social interactions). The paper presents group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (activation maps and thresholds reported: p=0.001, extent=10 voxels) contrasting social interaction vs. no-interaction, and shows whole-brain results (figures and description) based on the healthy participant group. It is empirical fMRI work in healthy adults and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult subjects performing social-related tasks (self-relevance, attentional and attributional judgements). The abstract reports group-level task-evoked neural activations (specific brain regions and Brodmann areas: e.g., left inferior frontal gyrus BA47/44, right caudate, cingulate BA24, left precentral BA6, left middle temporal BA39), indicating whole-brain univariate activation results generalizable to healthy adults. Sample is described as ‘normal subjects’ (healthy adults). The study does not appear to be ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria (fMRI, social-related task, healthy adult group, whole-brain task activation reported) and does not violate exclusion criteria. Note: full text was not provided here beyond the abstract, but reported group activations in the abstract are sufficient for inclusion at screening.

This is an fMRI study of third-party punishment (a social-cognitive/moral judgment task) in healthy adult participants (N=26; mean age 26, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate GLM results (ANOVA on β parameters) with thresholding (q(FDR)<0.05), including peak coordinates and figures (R TPJ, R anterior insula). Results are clearly described for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and contains original empirical fMRI data — therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is a single-case fMRI report (n=1, one 22-year-old female). Although whole-brain analyses and coordinates are reported, the study does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map generalizable to a healthy adult group. Inclusion criteria require at least one group of healthy adult participants with group-level whole-brain results; that criterion is not met. Therefore the study must be excluded.

Although the study uses task fMRI during face processing (a social-related construct) and includes healthy control subjects, it is a single-case study focused on a clinical patient (ASD + developmental prosopagnosia). The abstract and available full-text information emphasize patient vs control differences and functional connectivity results; there is no clear statement that the paper reports a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group that is unmasked and generalizable to healthy adults. The results appear to rely on between-group contrasts and connectivity analyses rather than providing an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect. Therefore it fails the required 'whole-brain evidence' inclusion criterion.

Although this is an fMRI study of social (facial emotion) processing and includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 37), the paper reports only between-group contrasts (VCFS < controls and VCFS > controls; Table 1) rather than an unmasked, whole‑brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., main effect or within‑group on>off contrast for controls). The inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported whole‑brain univariate task-evoked map from the healthy adult group. Because qualifying healthy-group whole-brain results are not provided (results shown are group differences/contrasts), this study does not meet the whole‑brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n≈302 initially; final groups of 18–22-year-olds), using a social-interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) to probe social cognition. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (GLM contrasts for CC and CD outcomes, cluster-thresholded Z maps) and presents whole-brain activation clusters and coordinates for treatment-by-methylation effects as well as condition contrasts. Participants are within the eligible adult age range (18–22). The study is empirical, reports task-evoked whole-brain results for healthy subjects (separately by sex and genotype), and provides tables/figures of whole-brain findings. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and group-level whole-brain univariate results).

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N≈19, ages 18–32). The task manipulates social inference goals (why/how/what/observe) during action observation and reports group-level, task-evoked univariate analyses (random-effects ANOVA) with voxelwise results and peak coordinates. Although primary ROI/mask-based correction was applied, the paper explicitly states that whole-brain results and mask details are provided in the Supplemental Methods, and reported contrasts are generalizable to the healthy control sample rather than limited to an ROI or connectivity analysis. The study is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy participants. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (attribute framing and self/other evaluations). Sample consists of healthy adults (final N=19 after exclusions), ages 19–41, within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., task vs control, positive minus negative frame, negative minus positive frame, frame-inconsistent minus frame-consistent) with coordinates and cluster-size thresholds described, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group within-subject contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study used task-evoked fMRI in a social-related paradigm (direct vs. averted gaze) with a healthy adult sample (N=55 males), it does not report any group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps for the healthy group. Analyses and reported results are ROI-based (amygdala and inferior occipital gyrus) with FWE correction within those masks; no unmasked whole-brain contrasts, coordinate tables, or whole-brain figures/outputs are provided. Therefore it violates the requirement for whole-brain evidence and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (n=17, mean age 26) investigating social perception (observation of social vs. individual actions with gaze manipulations). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects within-subjects ANOVA) with main effects and interaction maps and coordinates (SPM results, Table 1 and figures). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy adult group are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI with an instructional manipulation (belief of being observed) and reports network-level functional connectivity results. It does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) activation maps from a social task. Analyses are connectivity/resting-state contrasts rather than task-evoked whole-brain activation, so it fails the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and meets the exclusion criterion for resting-state-only studies.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (team membership/group bias) in healthy adult participants (ages 17–43). The study reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., action videos vs fixation; own-team vs other-team; decision vs baseline) with cluster-level family-wise error correction (PFWE < 0.05) and provides coordinates, tables, and figures. The sample comprises healthy adult controls and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper includes whole-brain statistical maps/contrast results rather than ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 17–34) and reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group (Table 2, figures). The task involves imagining performing actions shown by others (body-checking vs neutral actions) and taps social-related processing constructs (perception/understanding of self and others, mentalizing/mirror systems), which fits the review’s social processing domain. Results for healthy controls are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in 40 healthy adult (heterosexual) males (mean age 25.8), using a social-related task (interpersonal touch; manipulation of perceived toucher sex). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical results (whole-brain contrasts and coordinates are provided, with family-wise error corrections and ROI follow-ups). The contrasts of interest (e.g., Female TouchOXT>Female TouchPLC; Female vs Male touch under placebo) are clearly reported for the healthy control sample. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and the reported results are generalizable to healthy adults (not limited to a narrowly defined subgroup). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain activation maps/tables, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI with a social-related task and includes a healthy adult control group (mean age ~32), the reported healthy-group results are presented primarily as region-of-interest (ROI)-restricted voxelwise findings within a predefined composite mask (frontopolar, IFG, temporal poles, TPJ). The paper does not provide or describe an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (no whole-brain, unmasked main-effect maps are reported for controls; reported effects are ROI-corrected or between-group contrasts). Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map clearly identified for the healthy group, this study fails to meet that criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of cooperative vs noncooperative interactions). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=19) reported separately and matched to patients. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group (e.g., C+ > C– within-controls; FDR-corrected p < .05) with coordinates and figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain group-level maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, uses task-based fMRI, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI task study of social-related auditory perception (voice processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=8; mean age 27.1) reported separately from the autism group. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate analyses: controls showed significant bilateral STS activation for voice vs non-voice (random-effects, P < 0.001 corrected) with coordinates/peaks and supplementary tables/figures, satisfying the whole-brain task-evoked map requirement. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group results are clearly described and generalizable to typical adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the review.

This conference study describes simultaneous EEG–rt-fMRI correlations targeting the right pSTS for neurofeedback and reports feature correlations between EEG and fMRI at that region. It appears focused on ROI-based/target-region analyses and feasibility; no group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for healthy adults is reported in the abstract or record. Therefore it fails the review’s requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps and meets the exclusion criterion for ROI-only results. Additionally, the item is a brief conference report with limited methodological detail, reducing ability to verify whole-brain results.

Although the study includes healthy adult controls (n=20, ages 18–50) and uses an fMRI social task (multi-round trust game), it does not report an unmasked, within-group whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. The imaging results focus on ROI analyses and on between-group contrasts (controls > patients) in an exploratory whole-brain analysis. There is no clear presentation of a group-level voxelwise healthy-group task effect (main effect or within-group contrast) generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation reporting.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (message propagation/mentalizing). Participants are healthy adults (interns N=19, mean age 20.55). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses with voxelwise results and coordinate tables (thresholded whole-brain results reported; Table 1 and figures). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (social/moral decision-making—affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=19, mean age 28.2). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects t-tests, conjunctions, coordinate tables/figures) and specifies thresholds and cluster criteria. Results are presented for healthy participants (no reliance on clinical groups) and include whole-brain contrasts (e.g., donation vs. monetary reward; costly vs. noncostly decisions). The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses, and the healthy adult sample falls within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical event-related fMRI study investigating perception of socially relevant facial expressions in an interactive/ social task (virtual characters), matching social-related processing constructs. Participants: 17 healthy right‑handed adult males (mean age 25.9), within 17–65. Analyses: whole‑brain, random‑effects, voxelwise univariate FIR/GLM contrasts are reported (SPMt maps, coordinates, thresholding and tables/figures). Results are reported for the healthy group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI‑only, not connectivity/resting‑state only, and not a non‑empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy young adults reporting task-evoked activations during a social attribution task. The paper describes two linked fMRI studies in healthy adults (within 17–65 range) and reports group-level whole-brain univariate activation (FFA, amygdala, temporal pole, medial prefrontal cortex, inferior frontal cortex, STS). It is a task-based social cognition paradigm and provides whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of racial ingroup vs outgroup faces) in healthy adult participants (subjects identified as White or Black). The abstract reports group-level BOLD differences in the amygdala across subjects to outgroup versus ingroup faces. Although the paper employs an ROI-based analysis for time-course/habituation effects, the text indicates voxels showing significant BOLD signal differences were identified (i.e., voxelwise activation in the amygdala across the healthy sample), satisfying the requirement for a group-level univariate task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. Full text access is limited, so confidence is moderate (0.70).

Although this paper uses task fMRI with healthy adult controls and social stimuli (emotional faces), the reported fMRI results are presented as region-of-interest (amygdala) analyses (corrected within the amygdala) and as between-group contrasts. The full text does not provide an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group (e.g., whole-brain within-group contrast or table/figure of whole-brain activations). Because it reports primarily ROI-focused and between-group findings without a clearly described healthy-group whole-brain activation map, it does not meet the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing an action-observation/anticipation task, which falls under 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (a social-related construct). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., shots–motion control) with random-effects analysis and thresholded t-contrasts (reported in figures and tables of peak coordinates), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are nonclinical adult players (experiments include recreational to international players), and results for healthy adults are reported. The study is empirical, task-based fMRI (not ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

Although this fMRI study used a social task (viewing angry vs. neutral faces) in healthy adults (ages 18–33) and reports group-level seed-based PPI connectivity results and ROI analyses (FFA, amygdala), the paper does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast such as angry>neutral). The primary whole-brain results described are seed-based connectivity (PPI) and ROI percent-signal-change analyses. Per the inclusion criteria, reporting of at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map is required; because this criterion is not met, the study must be excluded.

Although this is an fMRI study of social/affiliative processing in healthy adult mothers (viewing own vs unknown infant faces), the provided full text and abstract only describe between-group differences (preterm vs full-term) and report increased activations in specific regions for preterm mothers. The manuscript does not clearly present an unmasked, group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for a healthy/control group (e.g., within-group own>unknown contrast for full-term mothers) that is generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because I cannot verify criterion #3 (reporting of a healthy-group whole-brain task effect) and the paper appears to emphasize between-group contrasts, it does not meet all inclusion criteria and must be excluded.

This is a conference abstract/brief report with insufficient methodological detail: participant characteristics (n, ages) and analytic approach are not reported in the available text, and the paper does not present or describe a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map for healthy adults. The abstract only describes conceptual/initial evidence from dyadic fMRI (live eye contact) without reporting voxelwise whole-brain results or coordinates. Because the inclusion criteria require clear whole-brain, group-level task activation maps from healthy adult participants, and those criteria cannot be verified from the provided full text, the study must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI of social processing (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma — social decision-making/trust), healthy adult sample (N=20 males, age 21–37), and group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked results are reported (one-sample t-tests, flexible factorial analyses, cluster-level FWE-corrected maps/tables/figures). The paper presents whole-brain activation contrasts clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Note: single-sex sample (males only) is within the 17–65 age range and therefore acceptable for inclusion.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social evaluation (impression formation) in healthy adults. It includes a young adult group within the target age range (20–29 years) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant) using random-effects analyses with correction and tables/figures of coordinates/ROIs. Although an older group (61–85) is also included, the young healthy adult group satisfies the 17–65 age requirement and whole-brain results are reported/partitioned by group (including conjunctions and between-group contrasts). The paper is not ROI-only, not resting-state or purely connectivity, and contains primary task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This article is labeled as a review ('総説') and appears to be a theoretical/overview paper. Although the abstract discusses fMRI-based findings in model-based analyses, the full-text information indicates it is a review rather than an original empirical report: no methods, participant sample, or group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for healthy adults are provided. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring original fMRI data with healthy adult whole-brain results, and it meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical/review papers without original fMRI data.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, ages 22–39) that investigates collective/social memory and medial prefrontal representations—an aspect of social cognition (perception/understanding of others/group narratives). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise searchlight analyses (RSA-derived beta maps) with nonparametric permutation testing and TFCE correction, showing significant clusters (dmPFC/vmPFC and dorsolateral PFC). Results for the healthy adult group are clearly reported. Although primary analyses use multivariate RSA rather than conventional univariate contrasts, they produce whole-brain statistical maps meeting the review’s whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Study used fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 27.5) during a social communication task (charades). However, the paper’s primary reported maps are between-brain Granger-causality (effective connectivity) maps rather than univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation contrasts. The only traditional GLM activation results are referenced as published previously (ref. 33) and are not presented here as group-level, whole-brain task activation maps. The manuscript therefore reports connectivity/effective-connectivity results without providing an accompanying univariate, voxelwise healthy-group task activation map, which violates the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

Although the paper uses fMRI in healthy adults and models ‘social communication’ as one of many categories during passive movie viewing, it does not use a social-related task/contrast per se and does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for a social process in the healthy group. The primary analyses are voxelwise encoding and ROI/cluster analyses of category tuning rather than whole-brain task activation contrasts relevant to social processing. Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for an fMRI study with a social-related task and a whole‑brain healthy-group task activation map.

This is an fMRI study of deception in a healthy adult sample (n=24 males, ages 19–60). The task engages social-cognitive processes (deception/manipulation/theory-of-mind), fitting the review's social-related constructs. Group-level, task-evoked, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects contrasts (lie>truth and truth>lie) are reported with coordinate tables and cluster statistics; results are presented for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Age range and reporting meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The task is a rewarded continuous performance task using monetary incentives (non-social reward) and sustained attention; it does not probe social-related processing constructs (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others). Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (ages within range) and reports whole-brain group-level activation maps for controls, it fails the primary inclusion criterion that the fMRI task assess social-related processing. Therefore it should be excluded.

Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=30 native Japanese speakers) performing communicative (social communication) vs descriptive speech tasks in L1 and L2. The tasks are social-related (communication/social interaction). The abstract describes group-level neural activation findings (e.g., left posterior supramarginal gyrus, left MTG, OFC/insula) consistent with whole-brain univariate task-evoked results rather than ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are healthy adults within the 17–65 range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) appear to apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception (biological-motion task) in healthy adult participants (N=26 analyzed; ages 18–39). The paper reports group-level task-evoked activation contrasts (biological motion > scrambled) and explicitly conducts whole-brain analyses (surface-projected whole-brain GLMs with cluster-wise correction and a significant cluster in right pSTS/TPJ reported). Results are reported at the group level and are generalizable to healthy adults (not limited to a clinical subgroup). Thus it meets the inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults with at least one whole-brain, univariate group-level task activation map).

Although the paper includes an fMRI experiment, the imaging sample comprises only 25 female patients with social anxiety disorder; no fMRI data from a healthy adult group (age 17–65) are reported. The reported imaging results are within-patient regressions (amygdala responsiveness predicted by OXTR methylation) and do not provide a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for healthy/control participants. No whole-brain healthy-group task effect (tables/coordinates/figures) is presented. Therefore the study does not meet the requirement of reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: Empirical fMRI study using task-based auditory stimuli probing social processing (perception/understanding of others—differentiating one vs. two walkers). Sample: 12 healthy adult participants (ages 22–37), reported separately. Whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate analyses are reported (GLM contrasts such as STEP1+STEP2 – REST, STEP1 – NOISE1, STEP2 – NOISE2, with voxelwise thresholds and Talairach coordinates/tables and figures). Not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses; provides whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state, not only between-group contrasts, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore include in meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 24.1) investigating visual sensitivity to social configurations (two-body face-to-face vs back-to-back). The task probes social perception/understanding of others (interaction cueing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., dyads > single bodies; facing > nonfacing dyads) with statistical maps/tables and ROI analyses; whole-brain results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing that meets all inclusion criteria. It uses task-based fMRI while participants imagined encountering neutral faces in social daily-life situations (a social-related task: perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises healthy adults (final N=17, ages 20–36). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses for encoding and recognition contrasts, with cluster-corrected thresholds and coordinate tables/figures (and small-volume corrections where noted). Results are clearly reported for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range sample) apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining perception/recognition of others’ actions (social-related processing: Perception and Understanding of Others). The abstract reports group-level neural effects (action-specific adaptation) in lateral occipitotemporal regions (pSTS, MT/MST, EBA), consistent with univariate task-evoked activation contrasts. The study population (healthy adults) and task domain meet inclusion criteria. Full PDF not accessible here, so I assume standard J Cogn Neurosci reporting includes group-level voxelwise results identifying these regions; however, I recommend verifying the full text or tables for explicit whole-brain voxelwise maps or coordinate tables to confirm compliance with the ‘whole-brain evidence’ requirement.

Although this is an fMRI study of a social task (trustworthiness judgments) that includes a healthy adult control group, the paper reports ROI-based analyses (mean percent signal change extracted from a priori ROIs) and group-level ANOVAs on those ROI values. The full text does not present or describe any unmasked, whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation maps (e.g., healthy-group main-effect or within-group contrast maps) nor tables of whole-brain coordinates for healthy participants. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must report at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Because only ROI results are reported and no whole-brain healthy-group task activation is provided, the study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study of social communication in healthy adults (54 right-handed male participants, ages 18–27). It uses a task requiring dyadic communicative interactions (social communication) during simultaneous fMRI acquisition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects, cluster-level familywise-error correction) with coordinates and figures (e.g., rSTG cluster at [58, −8, 5]) and model-based whole-brain contrasts linked to task dynamics. Results are presented for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROIs or resting-state/seed connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=33, ages 20–34) using social tasks (charitable donation task and EmpaToM assessing empathy and perspective taking). Group-level whole-brain analyses are reported: although much of the paper uses MVPA, the authors also ran univariate GLMs and report whole-brain group results (e.g., GLM5 univariate contrast low>high donations yielded a significant early visual cortex cluster; GLM3 EmpaToM contrasts were tested at group-level with FWE-correction/SVC and provide process-related contrast maps used for feature selection). Results are clearly from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants are within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (face/emotion perception) in healthy adults (final N=25, ages 21–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects second-level t-map for faces > objects used to define ROIs) and presents whole-brain searchlight results with corrected statistics and tables of peaks/coordinates. The task is clearly social (emotion and age judgments of faces) and healthy-group results are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task and construct: Event-related fMRI was collected during a mind-perception/social-cognition task (judging others’ internal states) and related to social-attention (gaze cueing) — clearly social-related processing. (2) Sample: Healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 24.36, right-handed undergraduates) within 17–65. (3) Whole-brain evidence: The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise parametric analyses with cluster-based correction (FWER p<.05) and tables/coordinates (e.g., vmPFC, TPJ, fusiform), including conjunction results; results are presented as whole-brain maps and coordinates. (4) Not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical study. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore include for meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy participants (30 late adolescents and 30 young adults) using social scenarios/risky decisions (a social-related task). The abstract reports group-level task-evoked activations (regret vs. relief/elation; disappointment vs. relief/elation) and names whole-brain regions (OFC, MTG, PCC, precuneus, insula, IFG, pre-SMA, caudate, STS), indicating voxelwise/univariate whole-brain contrasts for the healthy groups. At least one healthy adult group (young adults) falls within the 17–65 range and results are reported separately by age group. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and provides whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=15, ages 20–28) that includes a social-distance task (friends vs acquaintances), it does not report any significant group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked activations for the healthy sample. The authors explicitly state that no voxels survived FDR-corrected threshold in the within-domain t tests and thus present MVPA and RSA multivariate results rather than a usable whole-brain univariate activation map. Because the review requires at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map from the healthy/control group, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI in both healthy adolescents and a separate healthy adult group (ages 22.6–30.4). The adult group is within the 17–65 range. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses and reports coordinates and figures for adult task contrasts (e.g., You-rest, Mom-rest, conjunctions), with unmasked whole-brain results and corrected thresholds described. The task probes social-related constructs (direct and reflected self-appraisals; self-perception and perspective-taking), which fall under the review’s eligible domains. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, adult results reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=20, mean age ~25, within 17–65). The task is social (Cyberball) probing social exclusion/affiliation processes. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected results and figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes within-group healthy adult analyses generalizable to the healthy population. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates; mean age 19.5, within 17–65). The task is explicitly social (viewing photographs of social groups and making affective/social-cognitive judgments about others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM contrasts vs fixation, 3-versus-1 contrasts), random-effects analyses, Talairach coordinates, and cluster statistics (tables/figures), not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Thus it satisfies the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and reports whole-brain univariate healthy-group task activation maps.

Although the study used task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (n=8, ages within 17–65) and investigated socially relevant interpersonal touch, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM contrast maps or tables of voxelwise coordinates). The analysis is based on independent component analysis (ICA) to derive spatial components and time courses; only ICA-derived component maps and time series are presented. Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only ICA/other multivariate/resting-state-like analyses without an accompanying univariate whole-brain healthy-group task activation map must be excluded. Therefore the study does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is an event-related fMRI study of gender perception (a form of ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’), which qualifies as social-related processing. The sample comprises healthy adults (n=15 analyzed; ages 19–42), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxel-wise analyses (random-effects GLM; contrast gender-different > gender-same) with cluster-corrected maps and reported Talairach coordinates and figures, not limited to ROI-only results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, non-healthy-only samples, or non-empirical paper) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study used task-based fMRI (verbal fluency and Hayling sentence completion) assessing verbal executive function and response inhibition, not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Although healthy adult controls are included and whole-brain within-group activation maps are reported, the tasks do not target social cognition. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion of using fMRI during a social-related task.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of a clearly social-related task (vocal emotion recognition) and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate activation maps, the sample consists of adolescents aged 8–19 and no separate healthy adult group (age 17–65) is analyzed or reported independently. While a few participants are aged 17–19, the paper presents results for the combined 8–19 sample and continuous age effects rather than an adult-only subgroup. The review’s inclusion criteria require at least one healthy adult group (17–65) with its own whole-brain task activation results. Because the adult-age subgroup is not separately reported/analysed, the study does not meet the sample criterion and must be excluded.

Task-based fMRI study of social processing (facial emotion recognition) in adults; includes a healthy adult control group (n=14) with results reported separately; reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (within-group contrast NTOXT>PLA showing clusters in inferior frontal gyrus and fusiform gyrus) and full brain tables/coordinates (Table 2). Age range and task meet inclusion; not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described. Therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study used fMRI in healthy adults and includes sentences with some social content, its primary aim was general semantic/sentence representation, not a social-related task per the review constructs. Key inclusion requires a study to report at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group (e.g., GLM contrast or t-map). This paper uses multivariate regression/decoding and factor analysis and reports factor-related voxel clusters, but does not present a conventional univariate, group-level whole-brain task activation map (main effect or within-group contrast) clearly identified as such. Because it does not meet the whole-brain univariate map requirement and is not primarily a social-processing task, it should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (naturalistic mentalising) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, ages 19–46). The paper reports within-group whole-brain univariate task contrasts for the control group (ToM > physical inference), with family-wise error–corrected clusters and peak coordinates presented in Table 3 and figures, satisfying the requirement for group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study also separates control-group results from the ASD group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting) apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social cognition (monitoring others’ decisions/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N=12, mean age 21). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise second-level random-effects analyses (F-contrasts) with reported cluster coordinates and SPM statistics; results were corrected via small-volume correction within an anatomically defined ACC mask but arise from whole-brain voxelwise GLM analyses and are reported for the healthy/control group. The task is social-related and univariate task-evoked effects (informative vs. uninformative feedback interactions) are presented at group level. Thus it meets the review’s inclusion criteria (social fMRI, healthy adults, group-level univariate voxelwise results).

Meets all inclusion criteria: task used event-related fMRI during a social-related face memory/recognition task (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprised healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 19–36). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects contrasts, cluster correction) with peak coordinates and figures for activations (e.g., right precentral and cingulate gyri), which are generalizable to the healthy group. The study is empirical and reports original task-evoked BOLD results for the healthy participants. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and results are not limited to a special clinical subgroup). Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=43, males aged within 17–65) that examines social processing (preconscious processing of fearful eye whites). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain results are presented with coordinates and cluster statistics) in addition to ROI analyses. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not a review, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Participants were healthy adults (reported 16 analyzed subjects, ages 19–24), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses: random-effects contrasts with reported significant clusters (e.g., MPFC, PCC, precuneus) and MNI coordinates and thresholding (voxelwise P<0.001, cluster-level P<0.05 FWE), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses (FFA/OFA) are included, whole-brain results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and is empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (virtual handshake provoking social acceptance vs. rejection). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age 27.4) reported separately from the schizophrenia group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain within-group contrasts for the healthy/control group (refusal > acceptance) with brain regions and statistics described (right pSTS, thalamus; tables/figures reported and corrected clusters described). The task probes social interaction/mentalizing (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes empirical original fMRI data in healthy adults within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this task fMRI study includes healthy adult participants (ages up to 40) and reports whole-brain task activation maps, all reported group-level whole-brain analyses are for the combined sample spanning ages 7–40. The paper does not present a separate group-level, univariate whole-brain activation map or contrast restricted to adults (age 17–65) that is generalizable to a healthy adult population. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group with reported whole-brain task-evoked results.

The study is an empirical task-based fMRI investigation of social processing (self vs other processing in romantic relationships). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=42; ages 23–40) meeting the age criterion. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., self positive > neutral, other negative > neutral) and an ANOVA; results are corrected for multiple comparisons (FWE) and presented in tables/figures (whole-brain activations and SVC reported). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study does use task fMRI and reports whole-brain activation maps, but it does not meet key inclusion criteria for this meta-analysis: (1) Task domain — the fMRI task is a non-social visual attention/divided-attention paradigm, not a social-related task (e.g., perception/understanding of others, social communication, affiliation/attachment). (2) Sample — participants are boys/children and adolescents (ages ~10–16), not healthy adults aged 17–65; although a ‘control’ group is reported, they are minors and thus not generalizable to healthy adults. While clinical groups (ASC) and unaffected siblings are included and whole-brain results are shown, these do not rescue the study because the healthy/control sample is outside the specified adult age range and the task is non-social. Therefore the study should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of action perception/understanding (mirror system) — a social-cognitive process fitting “Perception and Understanding of Others.” Participants include healthy adult groups (14 sighted, 8 blind; mean ages 32 and 44, within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., familiar action sounds vs environmental sounds; motor pantomime vs rest), with correction for multiple comparisons and cluster-size thresholds, and presents statistical maps and coordinate-based results. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state, and provides healthy-group whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social/affiliation processing (mother–infant attachment) in healthy adult participants (N=23 mothers, ages 22–37). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain GLM contrasts (own infant > unfamiliar infant) with whole-brain statistical maps and tables of activated regions, not limited to ROI-only analyses. Healthy-group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults; sample falls within the 17–65 age range. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of face perception/recognition in healthy adults (ages within range) and addresses a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others), the paper’s imaging results are presented as ROI-based MVPA and representational similarity analyses. The manuscript does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., a whole-brain faces>baseline or similar contrast with coordinates or images) for the healthy/control group; instead ROIs were defined using an independent localizer (from a different sample) and analyses focus on ROI and visual-field masks. Because the review’s inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map from the healthy group, this study does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=98; mean age 20.7) that investigates social-related processing (self vs. others, closeness/similarity). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., self > Bush; friends > strangers) with whole-brain maps and region coordinates, and describes preprocessing and GLM analyses. Results are reported for the healthy sample and are generalizable to healthy adults within the 17–65 range. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and it provides whole-brain activation maps/contrasts clearly identified for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21 males, age 21–39), uses a social-related task (negative vs positive social feedback), reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (negative social feedback > positive social feedback) with random-effects analysis, corrected voxelwise thresholds, tables/figures with peak coordinates. Not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria violated.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=21) during episodic retrieval of socially encoded life events (oral social interactions), which qualifies as social-related processing (self and social interaction). The sample consists of healthy adults. Group-level, univariate whole-brain task activations are reported (episodic retrieval network activations; P < .05 corrected), and task-evoked contrasts are clearly described; hippocampal findings used small-volume correction but whole-brain retrieval activations are reported. The design is empirical fMRI (task), not ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only, and results are presented for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a methods/functional-parcellation study using resting-state fMRI in 20 healthy adults and meta-analytic coactivation (MACM) via the BrainMap database. It does not report original task-evoked, group-level whole-brain fMRI activation maps from the authors' healthy sample for a social-related task. Although the paper uses BrainMap to infer associations (including social cognition) via ALE and functional characterization, these are meta-analytic coactivation results rather than within-study univariate task activation maps. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring an original whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from healthy adults participating in a social-related fMRI task.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking). The task is explicitly social-related, and the paper reports group-level task-evoked whole-brain univariate activations (activation in ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, and left dorsal MPFC for the interaction), which indicates whole-brain voxelwise contrasts rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are healthy adults (university sample), and results are presented as generalizable group-level effects. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy or out-of-range sample, or non-empirical paper) appear to be violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social processes (self/other evaluation and perspective-taking) and includes a healthy adult control group, it does not report an unambiguous whole‑brain, group-level (one-sample) task activation map for the healthy/TD group alone. Reported fMRI results are primarily between-group contrasts (ASD vs TD), combined-group main effects, ROI-based analyses, and seed-based beta-series connectivity results. The paper therefore lacks an unmasked, whole-brain, task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group, which is required by the inclusion criteria.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=24) and uses task-based fMRI during a social/empathy task, the paper reports only between-group whole-brain contrasts (control > schizophrenia and schizophrenia > control) and derived percent signal change within those between-group clusters. It does not present or report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical map or within-group main-effect activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group that would be generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

While the study used task fMRI of social processing (implicit emotional face perception) and included a healthy adult control group, the full text does not clearly report an univariate, whole-brain, within-group statistical map for the healthy/control group (only patient within-group maps and patient-vs-control contrasts are reported in detail). The paper describes some control activations qualitatively but does not provide a clear, generalizable whole-brain control-group task effect (coordinates/tables/figures) that can be used for the meta-analysis. Therefore it fails the requirement for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: Task is an explicit facial emotion perception fMRI paradigm (social communication/perception of others). Sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=22; mean age 31.7, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate group-level task activation maps/contrasts for the healthy control group (one-sample t tests for the ‘faces minus animals’ contrast; figures and supplementary tables of activation foci and coordinates are provided). Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (a social-cognition task) in healthy adult volunteers (n=109). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrast (ToM>control) with significant main effects (P<0.01 FWE) and provides coordinates/figures/tables of activation; genotype effects are also reported at whole-brain corrected levels. The sample is healthy adults and results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study used fMRI during a social joint-attention task and included a healthy adult control group (80 HCs), it does not report a clear group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. The paper’s primary analyses focus on ICA-derived cross-brain coupling and between-pair comparisons (permutation tests and group contrasts), and the Results only state absence of group differences in task-related brain activity without providing an unmasked HC within-group whole-brain activation map or coordinates for a HC main-effect contrast in the main text or figures reviewed. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

execution_stats.search_query: ( ('functional MRI'[Title/Abstract] OR 'functional magnetic resonance imaging'[Title/Abstract] OR 'fMRI'[Title/Abstract] ) AND ( 'social communication'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social processing'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social interaction'[Title/Abstract] OR 'affiliation'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social attachment'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social cognition'[Title/Abstract] OR 'understanding others'[Title/Abstract] ) AND 'Humans'[MeSH])
